Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: NEA Presidential Address: Black Economists of the World You Cite!!
Intro: As I negotiate the second half of my life and career as an economist, and black man—the order may matter—I find myself in many instances afflicted with metaphysical anxieties. Chief among these is the extent to which my research interests and achievements mean anything. Have my intellectual inquiries made a difference? Have I moved the science of economics forward? Of course, such concerns could be mere vanity. Maybe I am just a mediocre half-baked black economist who has overestimated his ability, and both the community of scientists to which I think I belong, and the world at-large has the good sense to simply ignore whatever I offer up as a scientific contribution. Nietzsche once opined that “some men are born posthumously”. Perhaps this is my fate—or is this mere posthumous vanity? Quite frankly, I would prefer making a difference today, during this lifetime, as my time preferences like most people are probably hyperbolic. I suspect this may be true of most men who are not ascetic monks—Christian or otherwise—that are indeed interested in their existential significance in the empirical world they currently live in and occupy. If we are willing to assume that reality exists, and that one’s significance has a measure space that corresponds to their worth, then my metaphysical anxieties about whether I have made a difference as a black economist is potentially a trivial empirical exercise. What about others like me? I do not exist in a social vacuum afterall. In fact my social universe is quite complicated. You see, I am also a black man. I do not lament or apologize for being a black man, but it does seem to change things fundamentally. For example, being a black economist seems to lower one’s value in at least one stark way—it diminishes the prospect of having a career as an academic research scientist at a Ph.D. granting economics department ranked by the National Research Council in 1995 has never hired a black economist.Footnote 1 I also find myself contemplating the minds of other black economists, on their significance, and the extent to which they value me and others like them. Why? Being metaphysically anxious, and existentially challenged of late, I engage in some empiricism, take to the data on occasion, and consider the extent to which other economists cite my research. Not including self-citations, as of December 2007 SCOPUS, indicates that approximately 44% of citations to my research were by other economists and/or social scientists.Footnote 2 Apparently I am vain, as I seem to love myself at a higher rate than others. As for the others that do cite my research, approximately 43% are black economists/social scientists. With respect to my published research that engages the economics of race, approximately 37% of the citations are attributed to black economists/social scientists. Given these facts, I wonder why, given that I am cited at all by economists, why don’t I have more citations by black economists?

Title: Acceptance Remarks Samuel Z. Westerfield Award

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Black Enterprise Magazine Ranking of Colleges for African Americans: A Structural Analysis
Intro:
Every 2 years the Black Enterprise Magazine (BE) publishes its rankings of the top 50 colleges for African Americans. This past year’s rankings were quite different than the 2004 published rankings. As a result, both the type and the relative rank of institutions that compose it have changed. In constructing its rankings this year, BE employed a new methodology. According to BE (Sykes 2006, pp. 74–80): [We have] updated and improved the selection process for the list.... ...First, we expanded our pool of survey reviewers, which now includes more than 500 higher education professionals. ... The new approach—combined with giving more weight to graduation rates and other [italics are ours] necessary adjustments to the criteria—bumped some outstanding schools off the list. Nevertheless, all of the top 10 schools returned. ... ...Morehouse, which had been the top school on the listings, slipped 44 spots, from No. 1 to No. 45, primarily because its graduation rate fell from 56% to 49% over the last two years. (p. 76) A question raised by this and other attempts at academic ranking is their usefulness and legitimacy. To the extent that these exercises provide guidance and information based on institutional outcomes (productivity) and value added is a good thing. But for them to fulfill these requirements they should be subject to scholarly review and critique. They should avoid being arbitrary and inconsistent in their application of evaluation/assessment criteria. Moreover, the theoretical and methodological underpinnings of such exercises should be transparent and rigorously presented. The BE report fails on these grounds. The critique of the BE report presented in this short note attempts to address the following two questions. Does the BE report provide an unbiased and consistent assessment of the educational value associated with the institutions included in their listing? Aside from the general conceptual and methodological questions, is the ranking method internally consistent? In the BE report, there is neither articulation of the theoretical framework/context with in which its ranking is determined nor citation of established/peer-reviewed assessment practices. Exercises of the sort undertaken by BE are not trivial neither for those who consume the information contained in the report nor for the institutions which are the subjects of it. Any serious endeavor to assess institutional effectiveness of educational institutions should be subject to scientific scrutiny and have some policy implication. The BE academic ranking is based on a set of quantitative variables listed in Table 1. In its report, BE gives the impression that its ranking method is based on a set of fixed weights, where “[the] variables given the heaviest weighting were Black graduation rate, followed by the average academic and social environment scores (Sykes 2006, p. 76).” In this analysis, the quantitative benchmark will be based on the consistency and importance of these variables over the entire distribution of institutions included in the 2006 BE listing.
 Although not stated in the BE report, it is assumed that the relative importance of the variables used by BE to construct the list is the same across the entire distribution of institutions that are included in it. If this is the case then the structure of the model, used to construct the ranking list should be the same for all subsets of institutions contained in the BE list. If the published ranking is consistent with this weighting scheme, it should hold regardless of the subset.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Increasing Finance, Improving Schools
Intro: In 1993, the 73rd Texas Legislature approved school finance reforms by passing Senate Bill 7 (SB 7), which is commonly known as the “Robin Hood Bill”. In order to increase the per pupil funding in districts that did not have enough tax base to improve funding for their students, SB 7, using a method of fiscal neutralityFootnote 1, required wealthy school districts to share their wealth with poor districts. By assuming a fixed effects model we can examine the changes in academic achievement when state law forces a change in the funding amounts, and address the important policy issue. Do efforts of the legislature to bring about equity in funding to students actually make a difference in improving school quality as measured by academic achievement outcomes? Examination of the elementary schools within 14 school districts of Dallas County, allows us to see that when resources do increase, achievement improves. This study first investigates the inequities in Texas schools that led to school finance reform as legislated by SB 7. It describes and summarizes the data at both the district and the elementary school zone level. It presents the linkage between school quality, home values and the tax base they generate, and funding for students. It reports the findings of the changes in school quality after finance reform by school neighborhoods. It then draws conclusions and policy implications for states considering a fiscally neutral method of funding. Whenever the issue of school finance is placed on the policy-making agenda, and allocation of limited resources is at stake, the question always arises, “Does money really matter?” Taken from the viewpoint that money is an input of the education production function (Hanushek 1986, 1996; Murnane and Levy 1996; Hedges and Greenwald 1996; Iatarola et al. 2002), it is understandable that society would debate the issue. Greater outputs of educational attainment are expected from greater inputs of resources. Student achievement and school finance has been a controversial topic for over 30 years with no concrete answers being discovered. Elizabeth Harter (1999) argued that the relationship between school expenditures and student achievement depends on how money is spent. She tested the relationship of money and achievement by using data from elementary schools in Texas and by holding constant student academic potential, student socioeconomic background, and school characteristics. Her results indicated that only certain types of expenditure play an important part in explaining student achievement. Even though Hanushek’s early work found no positive relationship between money and achievement, he did conclude (1996) that it mattered how the districts spent their funds. More recently, Lopez (2007) suggests that the traditional educational production function used in these empirical studies is not an appropriate design to understand the relationship between resources and achievement. Hence, the literature does not provide a definitive answer as to whether money matters. This paper uses the result of a state funding equalization plan in Dallas County, Texas to show that academic outputs did improve after implementing school finance reforms. Elementary school pass rates on the Texas Assessment of Academic Skills (TAAS) improved as per pupil funding increased.

Title: A Brief Biography of Robert S. Browne

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Robert Browne and the Caucus of Black Economics
Intro:
Black economists around the country were contacted; the intent to raise issues of concerns with the AEA Executive Committee was explained and the economists were invited to attend the meeting of the Executive Committee in December, 1969. Those contacted spread the word to others. All told more than 20 black economists attended the meeting, which became a celebration of sorts, because so many friendships were renewed. Many black economists had “dropped out” because of the limited opportunities provided by the profession. One of these was Dunbar McLaurin, the first black to receive a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Illinois, in 1943. During the World War II years McLaurin was a successful businessman and was eager to move into black economic development. McLaurin gave visible meaning and seriousness to our gathering by leaving another formal dinner meeting, he arrived in style—formal evening dress. It was at this meeting that we came to know Bob Browne. He projected leadership abilities and a keen sense of organization and implementation; the group chose him to act as secretary of the Steering Committee and later Secretary and Chairman of the Caucus’ Policy Committee. As the paper in this volume by John Handy points out, an immediate consequence of the meeting was Bob Browne’s decision to begin a new journal, The Review of Black Political Economy. The Review was an unanticipated asset, a critical outlet for the work of economists—black and white—whose work was related to the condition of blacks in the United State and the Diaspora. The Review has been, for a quarter of a century, the official journal of the successor of the Caucus of Black Economists, the National Economic Association. The presence of W. Arthur Lewis at the meeting of the AEA Executive Committee, sitting with the black economists, contributed greatly to our credibility. Lewis had left a sick bed and came up from Princeton to be there.Footnote 4 The meeting was a contentious one; several members of the Executive Committee, a group of distinguished economists known for their “progressive” views were not prepared for the charges of exclusion they heard, it is no exaggeration to say they were in a state of shock. At one point Kenneth Boulding, a towering figure in progressive circles and former faculty member at Fisk University, stood up and declared “if you continue to push on an open door it will shut on you”. Boulding’s remark did not deter the black economists who had come well prepared to state their case. By the end of the meeting several key members of the Executive Committee stood in support of the black economists. Among them were James Tobin of Yale and Kenneth Arrow of Stanford, both of whom would later become AEA presidents and Noble Laureates; they urged the AEA to work with the black economists to ameliorate the concerns raised at the meeting. One of the first positive steps taken by the AEA was the creation of a committee on the Supply of Black Economists, to deal with the “pipeline” problem. Andrew Brimmer was the first chair of the committee. It conceived the idea of a program to prepare and encourage blacks to enter the economics profession. When Alexis succeeded Brimmer as chair in 1971 he initiated, with the support of the Ford Foundation and an appropriation by the AEA, The Summer Program in Economics for Minorities, a program which continues to operate and which scores of young black and Latino economists have attended.Footnote 5
 The Caucus realized that for participation at the annual meeting to be sustainable not only the supply side had to be tended to but the research output of black economists had to be augmented. Many of the black economists taught at historically black colleges and universities where heavy teaching loads made research difficult, if not impossible. It was also recognized that the research skills of black economists needed augmentation. To accomplish this, the Caucus leveraged its in-kind overhead and administrative ties with UCLA and secured funding from the Ford Foundation for the Black Economic Development Project.Footnote 6 The purpose of the Project was to support summer research, workshops and travel that contributed the development of blacks in the economics profession. C.Z. Wilson directed the project from 1970–1972. Thaddeus Spratlen succeeded him, directing the project from 1972 until its end in 1974. The first workshop of the Project was at the ASSA meetings in Detroit in December, 1970. The workshop was a showcase for the discussion of topics for which black economists had been longing. Bob Browne chaired a Symposium on Economic Institutions and the Black Community: Richard America, James Hefner, Karl Gregory and Sid Evans were panelists. The international dimension was covered in a paper by Rawle Farley, “Poverty and Enterprise in America and Overseas”. In sessions chaired by Alexis and Wilson papers on, “The Political Economy of American Racism: Nonblack Decision Making and Black Economic Status;” “Problems of Economic Growth in the Black Community: Some Alternative Hypotheses;” “Ghetto Economic Development—Content and Character of the Literature;” and “Bonus Schemes and Racism,” were presented, these were published as Papers of the Caucus of Black Economists in the Summer, 1971 issue of The Review of Black Political Economy
Footnote 7 Undergraduate student papers were presented in a student symposium, Economics With or Without Color, chaired by Thad Spratlen. Undergraduate participation was a major focus of the Caucus from its inception; they were the future supply of black economists. In addition to the Summer Program and the Black Economic Development Project, Wilson, as a member of President Richard Nixon’s Advisory Council for Minority Business persuaded John Jenkins, Director of the Office of Minority Business Enterprises (OMBE), to contract with the Caucus to support research clusters at three black institutions: Virginia State University, Southern University, Atlanta University and at UCLA and the University of Washington. The Caucus used members from university and research organizations to evaluate and develop research directions for community development corporations. These efforts were consistent with Caucus goals of expanding opportunities for black economists at every level. The Caucus was an integral part of a larger movement involving civil rights, and university outreach to ameliorate inner city problems and create visible positions within the economics profession for blacks at all levels. An opportunity to have an influence at the graduate level developed when the Caucus was approached by Howard University in 1972 to consult on its pending Ph.D. in Economics. Howard economics had been the home department of two of the most prominent black economists of the twentieth century—Abram Lincoln Harris and Eric Williams. A group from the Caucus which included Bob Browne, Karl Gregory, Donald Harris, Duran Bell, Marcus Alexis, C.Z. Wilson and Thaddeus Spratlen served as the Caucus-Howard Advisory Council. The purpose of the Council was to assist Howard in the development of a Ph.D. program in economics and to assist in recruiting faculty to implement the Ph.D. curriculum. The invitation to the Caucus had come from Andrew Billingsley, Howard’s Vice President for Academic Affairs. But internal politics at Howard and the slow pace of progress ended the formal cooperation in 1973, individual Caucus members continued to work with Howard University. In 1974 The Ford Foundation asked Marcus Alexis and C.Z. Wilson to evaluate Bob Browne’s institution, the Black Economic Research Center (BERC) and The Review of Black Political Economy and to recommend a future for both. Both were reviewed positively in terms of their impact, but it was obvious that they could not survive on their own. In the late 1970s the idea was floated to permanently locate the Black Economic Research Center (BERC) at Howard. A satisfactory arrangement could not be made and BERC ultimately remained a stand-alone center in New York. In the end The Review of Black Political Economy became the official organ of the Caucus of Black Economists, a lasting tribute to the legacy of Bob Browne as a pioneering black economist, a visionary and intellectual entrepreneur.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Emergency Land Fund: Robert S. Browne, the Idea and the Man
Intro: In 2006, Tavis Smiley published Covenant With Black America (Smiley 2006). It was a NY Times best sellers for several weeks. It included a chapter on black rural America and addressed in part the loss of black owned land. We are reminded that General William T. Sherman issued Field order 15, January 16, 1865, which in many ways was the first covenant with black America. Field order 15 set aside thousands of acres of land for ex-slaves divided into 40 acre plots, along with an army mule. Field order 15 was in response to the ex-slaves desire to achieve true freedom and economic sustainability and their insistence that land was a key to accomplishing these goals. Unfortunately, that covenant was broken by the government that refused to recognize Blacks as citizens and valued them only as laborers and consumers; yet neither the broken covenant, a hostile government, nor the KKK could sway freed slaves from their quest to own land. That land base not only provided its owners and their families with some degree of economic independence, it also had a social and political impact that extended throughout the civil rights movement and beyond. Black Landowners were the ones most likely to vote, run for office, become community organizers and leaders of the movement in the black belt rural South. Landownership by Blacks has historically served as a psychological and transformative mechanism, conveying pride and power, a role it continues to play today. For blacks, as for others, land ownership has been a cultural glue providing a sense of place, self, family and community. The significance of land and its role in the evolution of black America cannot be over emphasized. Robert Browne recognized the significance of black land ownership; if he were alive today he would be leading the charge to preserve black ownership.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Emergence of the Black Economic Research Center and The Review of Black Political Economy: 1969–1972
Intro:
The nascent period of the Black Economic Research Center (BERC) and its principle publishing organ, The Review of Black Political Economy can be clearly demarcated as the years 1969–1972. This period came on the heels of the assassinations of Martin Luther King, Robert Kennedy, and El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Among many of the black intelligentsia, this period continued the long standing controversy between integrationist, civil rights strategies and programs promoting Black Nationalism. Also during the late 1960s and 1970s, there was tension stemming from the collapse of meaningful school integration and busing across every urban area in the country. In Brooklyn and in Harlem, where BERC was located, there had been a nationally publicized series of intense confrontations between black community activists and the American Federation of Teachers over community control of schools. Institutions and conventional practices were being challenged by black and white social activists and self-styled revolutionaries almost on a daily basis. Challenges to traditional forms of music, art, literature and literary criticism seemed to be the norm and not the exception. And if such a thing were possible, these issues began to recede as the forefront issues of the time with the all-pervading impact of the war in Vietnam. This was the era in which the Black Economic Research Center and The Review of Black Political Economy were conceived and launched.Footnote 1
 Robert Browne served for 6 years in Southeast Asia, but it was most notably during 1958–1961 while serving as trade advisor and Foreign Service officer in Cambodia and Vietnam that, I believe, Robert Browne’s public foray into black activism and radical economic thought began to crystallize (see Browne 1996, pp. 52–53) While he knew and worked with many of the leading white leftist intellectuals and progressive religious groups of the time, his overall deep distrust of war-time government policy and white America’s inability to fairly treat and work in the interests of people of color, both in Asia and America, led him to advocate reparations and, for a short time, some of the programs associated with the black separatist movement. Bob would frequently make the connection: Whether entitled reparations or disguised by another name, resources on a scale paralleling those dispersed in Viet Nam will have to be transferred to the black community if we expect to correct existing inequities. A significant sum will be required merely to counter the enormous raids on the public treasury being perpetrated by white America’s establishment in its own behalf. I refer here to oil depletion allowances, agriculture subsidies, public utility privileges, cost overruns and other financial shenanigans conspired in by big government and its favored defense contractors, political supporters, etc.—to say nothing of rectifying our exclusion from the 19th century welfare programs like the Homestead Act and the celebrated give aways to the railroads and other establishment institutions of white America. (Browne 1970a) His disturbing firsthand observations of the persecution of Buddhists monks and the heavy-handed, misguided policy that the USA was pursuing in that region riveted his deep concerns on the need to both help establish an anti-war movement and address the social and economic inequities facing black Americans. On returning to the USA in 1961, he emerged as one of the first major intellectuals to meet and warn various American groups about the dangerous path the USA was taking toward war in Vietnam. In 1967, during a fact-finding tour in Vietnam, the Buddhist community appealed to Bob Browne to enlist the support of Martin Luther King to take a stand against the Vietnam War. In that same year, Dr. King expressed his opposition to the war and delivered a powerful analysis of the link between the civil rights movement and the peace movement. A reading of Robert Browne’s personal correspondence with leading religious and peace groups during this period confirms the prominence that Robert Browne held in the establishment of the peace movement in the USA.Footnote 2
 Most disturbing to Bob was the disproportionate deployment of African Americans drafted to fight other people of color in Southeast Asia. His continued interest in Vietnam was underscored by the fact that he was one of the first Americans asked to visit Ho Chi Minh City in 1978, just 3 years after the US withdrawal in 1975. To a large measure, this issue helped shape much of his later positions and writings. Though Bob would often refer to the emergence of the new black activism and the black student movement as a motivating force, I feel, nonetheless, that it was primarily from the perspective of the peace movement, and his troubling Asian experience, that Robert Browne began earnestly advocating black economic development through compensatory justice and wealth generation via sustained black institution building: The two decades of the 1960s and 1970s constituted a period of domestically-based activity for me, but my work during that period was greatly enriched by the years I had spent abroad. There can be no doubt that the particular focus which I brought to the issue of black economic development was strongly influenced by my experience in working closely with the government of Cambodia....Footnote 3
 While working with Bob Browne during the first days of Black Economic Research Center, it was clear to me that the primary, original impetus to establish BERC came out of these complex events and controversial dynamics.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Robert Browne and Full Employment
Intro: Full employment policy was a major interest of Congressman Augustus Hawkins, Democrat, 13th Congressional District of California. In the early 1970s Mr Hawkins was a senior member of the House Education and Labor Committee (HELC). He began his political career in Los Angeles during the 1930s and served in the California General Assembly for a quarter century before being elected to the US Congress. Mr. Hawkins’ views on economic affairs were greatly influenced by the economic policies adopted by the Roosevelt New Deal administration. The guiding principle of that era was that the federal government had an obligation to intervene in the market to promote and protect the public interest when the private sector demonstrated the inability or unwillingness to do so. In response to the high unemployment generated by the Great Depression, the federal government introduced a series of job creation initiatives, including the Works Progress Administration(WPA), Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), and the National Youth Administration(NYA) in which the government acted as the employer of last resort. The principle that government had an obligation to intervene in the labor market to influence favorable economic outcomes also was reflected in the National Labor Relations Act, which protected the right of workers to organize and join unions of their choosing, and to participate in collective bargaining to set the terms of wages and working conditions. Federal government intervention in the market also was demonstrated in New Deal policies on agriculture, trade, banking, and labor standards. Congressman Hawkins was dissatisfied with the failure of the economy to achieve full employment during the 1950s and 1960s, a period when unemployment hovered above 6.0%. He concluded that the Employment Act of 1946, was inadequate to address the problem. The Employment Act of 1946 declared that the federal government had the responsibility to “use all practicable means—to create and maintain conditions under which there will be useful employment for those able, willing, and seeking work, and to promote maximum employment, production, and purchasing power” (House, Senate Conference Report 1945) To Mr. Hawkins, the term “maximum employment” was not the same as full employment. In his view, the failure to clearly state the policy goal as “full employment” allowed the government to tolerate unemployment rates well above any reasonable measure of full employment for extended periods of time. He believed a policy that would commit the nation to achieve full employment was necessary to drive down unemployment and keep it at a low level.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Robert S. Browne: Contribution to African Development

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Robert S. Browne. Development from an African Perspective: Early Success and Challenges at the Africa Development Bank
Intro: The ADB is one of several regional development banks, patterned loosely after the global model of the World Bank. The ADB was the third such regional institution to appear, following the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) and the Asian Development Bank. To understand the history of the ADB it is useful to take a moment to describe the model towards which it aspired. The World Bank is an international financial institution whose membership includes most of the countries of the world. In the highly simplified description which follows, we can view the Bank’s membership as falling into two categories: borrowing countries and non-borrowers, sometimes referred to as donors. The Bank raises its capital from the sale of its shares to its members, not on an on-going basis but at periodic ‘capital replenishments’ agreed to by the member governments of the donor countries. These shares are purchased almost entirely by the developed countries, and are in fact more accurately described as being ‘subscribed’ than being purchased. That is because the subscribing countries actually pay in cash for only a token portion of their subscription (say 10%), providing a sovereign IOU for the balance. These IOUs then serve as collateral to enable the Bank to go into the capital market and borrow the money it needs. Obviously, with such strong collateral, the Bank can borrow at very attractive rates of interest. Another pertinent feature of the Bank is that it is split into two entities, the Bank, properly speaking, which makes market rate loans to borrowing countries, and its sister institution, the International Development Association (IDA), which extends loans at a near-zero interest rate to the poorer borrowers as well as makes loans for the more socially oriented type projects such as in education and health, where returns are not directly quantifiable. IDA’s capital fund is independent of the Bank’s capital and consists of a pool of money replenished through periodic fund raising campaigns among the non-borrowing countries. The bulk of the African countries acquired their independence at the beginning of the sixties, and in 1964 they agreed to organize a development bank for the Continent. Unlike the IADB, which had been created at the instigation of the United States of America (USA), and the Asian Development Bank, which was more or less sponsored by Japan, the ADB had no wealthy sponsor. In fact, given the still lingering bitter colonial taste in African mouths following independence, there appears to have been little disposition among the Africans even to consider accepting extra-African assistance in the creation of this institution. Early on, however, it became evident that the ADB, as then structured, would be highly limited in what it could hope to achieve, because it was essentially a vehicle which shifted scarce resources from poor countries to even poorer ones—a case of the poor lending to the even poorer. A few of the member countries were apparently untiring in pointing this out to their colleagues and eventually a compromise was reached whereby non-regional countries were invited to join with the ADB to create a sister institution, a soft-loan window, to be called the African Development Fund (ADF), modeled after IDA. Like IDA, the ADF would not have any staff of its own but would simply piggy-back on the Bank’s staff and facilities, for a mutually negotiated fee. The ADF would have its own board, consisting of 12 members, half chosen from the new non-regional members and the other half from among the board members of the Bank. The ADF was inaugurated in 1974, during the Nixon administration. For whatever reason, the USA did not join the ADF at its inception, but five years later President Carter sought and received Congressional approval for the USA to join and shortly thereafter I was recruited to go to Abidjan, in 1980, as the first US Executive Director. The term Executive Director really means ‘member of the board of directors’. It is a working board which serves on site and is on constant call. By the time I joined the ADF board there were already rumblings of dissatisfaction with the outcome of the compromise which had been made over non-regional membership. Not surprisingly, the ADF’s resources had very quickly outstripped those of the ADB, and while the ADF was clearly the subordinate institution, having absolutely no voice in the administration or the policies of the Bank, with its role limited solely to participation in the decisions regarding the loans being sought from ADF funds, the growing disproportion between the amount of capital flowing into the two institutions was becoming a source of ever greater sensitivity. The ADF was extending far more loans than the ADB could hope to do and the tail was clearly wagging the dog, to the latter’s embarrassment. The principal opposition to the proposals to open the Bank to non-regional members came from three influential countries—Libya, Algeria, and Nigeria—not so coincidently, countries whose economies were notably stronger than most of their neighbors owing to their position as oil exporters. Finally, in 1982, Nigeria was prevailed upon to change its position and the ADB promptly opened its membership to all interested donor countries, although under certain restrictions designed to “preserve the African character of the Bank”. This last phrase had become the leit motif of this debate, for clearly the Africans feared, perhaps with reason, that allowing the rich countries to put their noses under the tent might well lead to their loss of effective control of their institution. I left the ADF shortly before the non-regional countries actually began to take up their newly expanded participation in the Abidjan-based institution, so I have no experience to recount of life as an actual director of the Bank itself. I will be eager to hear what Willene’s experience has been, although I am acutely aware that the position she holds severely restricts her freedom to discuss what her private observations and experiences at the Bank may be. In terms of preserving the African character of the Bank, I recall that, when the terms of the non-regional membership were being discussed back in 1982, a formula was devised to insure that the non-regional member’s vote could never overpower that of the regional members. I do not know if this objective has proved in practice to be a workable one, given the vast disparity in resources at the disposal of the two groups. I have had Africans to express to me some resentment at the excessive influence which the non-regional countries now play in the Bank’s policies and operations, but I have no particular information on this subject. I would, however, expect to find a wide dispersion of opinion on such an issue, because the Africans are themselves quite divided as to where they direct their criticism regarding virtually all of Africa’s encounters with the external world. Some will hold Africans as principally responsible for the Continent’s dreary global predicament, whereas others are more inclined to place the blame on the tragic colonial legacy and on the post colonial intrigues and cold war manipulations saddled on Africa by the major powers. Because the USA was so eager to see the Bank opened to non-regional membership, my principal instructions upon being despatched to Abidjan had been to refrain from being obnoxious, which was a superfluous instruction in my case, as will, of course, be attested by all who know me. As the non-regional members had no role to play in overseeing the Bank’s budget, its administration or even its policies except as related to the ADF loans, it was quite easy for me to remain aloof from matters which might be tinged with controversy. My first line of contact was with the ADF’s African Executive Directors, for I had to interact with them in regards to the loans being sought from the Fund. These individuals were persons who seemed to have been awarded this rather plum posting as a reward for some past political service in their home country. They displayed no special training for, nor great intellectual interest in the details of their work. I then gradually found myself interacting more frequently with the technicians who were involved with preparing the loan requests and who were generally either country specialists or sector specialists. They were all Africans because, at that time, the Bank did not recruit non-African staff. Most of them were young and seemed adequately qualified for their work in the technical sense, although few of them could yet boast the years of experience carried by many World Bank, AID and other non-African development workers. On the other hand, there is some merit in the ADB’s argument that African communities are more accessible by African staff than by expatriates and inasmuch as the design of successful projects often depends as much on an understanding of local community particularities, rivalries, and other intangibles, as on technical considerations, the ADB was better positioned than the World Bank to address issues of African development. The terms of the opening of the Bank to non-African membership obliged the Bank to begin hiring non-African staff. During my tenure there had been perhaps a dozen non-Africans working on contract for the Bank, out of a staff of perhaps some 600 persons. Officially, the Bank operated on a bilingual basis although French may have had a slight edge, or at least so it seemed to me. This would not be surprising inasmuch as the Bank is located in a French speaking country. Administrative staff was more likely to be bilingual than was technical staff, but a substantial number of the technicians, if not fully bilingual, could generally understand the other language even if they were not comfortable speaking it. In summary, when I finished my tour I felt the Bank to be in competent hands, although I was not really privy to its inner workings. Its funding was adequate at the time, although the ADF, which required more frequent replenishment, was subjected to serious squeezing by the Reagan administration, which displayed little interest in Africa. The ADB was having no difficulty borrowing money in the private capital markets at moderate rates of interest, although this is less an indicator of the skill of the Bank’s internal management and solvency than it is of the market’s perception of the soundness of the donor country IOUs which collateralize the Bank’s borrowings. The only ominous, unarticulated, potential problem which may have clouded the Bank’s excellent profile was how it would handle a member who might, for one reason or another, become seriously delinquent in servicing its loans. There were no delinquent borrowers during my period, nor had there been. That is no longer the case, but of course the other international financial institutions, such as the World Bank and the IMF as well as bilateral lenders, are acquiring plenty of in-depth experience with the thorny issue of international debt so it is not a problem particularly targeted toward the African institution.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Minorities’ Fields of Expertise in Economics and Employment Demand in These Fields
Intro: Research funding agencies such as the Ford Foundation and the National Science Foundation; and professional organizations such as the American Society of Hispanic Economists (ASHE), Committee on the Status of Minority Groups in the Economics Profession (CSMGEP) and the National Economic Association (NEA) include as part of their mission the development of minority scholars in economics. This push to increase minority participation in the economics profession is in part a response to the relatively small percentage of minorities receiving their advanced degrees in this discipline compared to social science as a whole.Footnote 1 Analysis presented by the previous NEA president, however, shows an even smaller share of minorities who are employed in economics departments at academic institutions compared to the share of minority students receiving their Ph.D. in economics.Footnote 2 This current presentation continues the examination of the employment of ethnic minorities in the economics profession by examining the demand side of this issue. Special attention is given to examining the possibility of a mismatch between the fields of research specialization where minority economists are significant contributors and the fields of research which are of significant interest to employers in economics departments at academic institutions.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Credit Access, the Costs of Credit and Credit Market Discrimination
Intro: Household debt can be, if used correctly, the grease for economic mobility. By borrowing, many more families can afford to buy a home, car, or a college education than would otherwise be the case. And debt allows families to smooth out income fluctuations due to short-term spells of unemployment, a medical emergency, among others. Traditionally, not all families had the same access to credit. The chance of getting a loan and the costs of debt often varied by demographic characteristics. Minorities and low-income families in particular had fewer chances of getting a loan and paid higher costs for debt than their counterparts. These differences have often been the result of credit market discrimination. Specifically, lenders may have denied loans to some borrowers solely on the base of race, ethnicity and other personal traits, or they may have steered these borrowers towards higher-cost loan products than were available for other borrowers. Differences in credit access and costs of credit were expected to decline over time as US financial markets became more deregulated, starting in the late 1970s, but taking shape especially in the 1990s. In particular, market deregulation was meant to result in more competition and ultimately less financial market discrimination. Prior research has shown some decline in the financial market discrimination. From the late 1980s to the early 1990s, differences in the chance of getting a loan approved seemed to decrease. More recent research, though, found that differences in loan denial rates and the costs of credit persisted over time, although it is unclear if this persistence was due to taste-based financial market discrimination. Moreover, much of the research ignored the possibility of structural discrimination in financial market decisions. This paper considers recent household level data on consumer debt to determine if credit market discrimination has declined, disappeared or persisted as financial markets have become more deregulated in the U.S. In particular, this paper analyzes the evidence on the chance of financial constraints as well as on the cost of credit for the period from 1989 to 2004. Consequently, this paper builds on the previous research in a number of important aspects. First, the empirical analysis extends beyond the late 1990s to test the impact of the latest round of financial deregulation on discrimination. Second, the research considers the evidence pertaining to taste-based and structural discrimination in credit markets. Third, this research includes the costs of credit and not just loan denials. In the analysis of potential cost differences, the research pays particular attention to the role sources and types of loans can play for the cost of credit. Fourth, the data analysis compares the experience of Latinos and African–Americans with each other to see if their gaps with whites and with each other have changed in any meaningful way over time.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: African Americans and U.S. Politics: The Gradual Progress of Black Women in Political Representation
Intro: Since the 1960s, African Americans have made substantial progress in their overall participation in the politics of the United States. The percent of African Americans who registered to vote and who have voted in national, state, and local elections, increased steadily and significantly. Since the 1960s, African Americans have also increased their total numbers and proportions of those who run for political office, from local school boards to the United States Congress and the Presidency, with the most significant gain in recent history being the election of an African-American Barack Obama as the 44th president of the United States. In addition, African Americans have increased their participation in political organizations and have found ways to influence the U.S. and international media so that issues important to the Black community are highlighted. Existing scholarship has documented that during the past three decades, the general public in the United States has also shown a continuous acceptance of the increased role of African Americans in the country’s politics, and many non-Black Americans go on to vote for, or financially support, African American candidates (Swain 1995; Clemons and Jones 1997; Clayton 1998; Bositis 2000, 2002, 2003, 2005, 2009; Franklin 2000; Katz 2000; Mastin 2000; Gay 2001; Davis and Brown 2002; Kim 2003; Amer 2004; Green 2004; Orey et al. 2007). African American leaders are also using their rising influence in American politics to advocate on important issues on behalf of Blacks in the U.S., as well as people of African descent across the world (Robinson 1999; Adekeye 2004; Kaba 2004; Tillery 2006). Data on the increasing efficacy of African Americans in the American political system reveal significant gender patterns that are emerging, and there has been very little scholarship that has examined the political success of African American women relative to their male counterparts. Statistics on African Americans’ participation in U.S. politics show that Black women tend to be increasingly more active participants than their male counterparts. In fact, some scholars have examined what is claimed to be the overrepresentation of Black female legislators in Congress. (Bedolla et al. 2005) The most telling statistic is that, while there has been no substantial increase in overall African-American political participation since the late 1960s, the percentage of female African American participation has increased. This trend is occurring across various aspects of political participation. African American women are registering and voting more than their male counterparts in local, Congressional, and presidential elections, and in recent years, they have been more successful than their male counterparts in their quest for elected office. According to Bedolla, Tate, and Wong, “despite the dismal prospects for women and Black candidates, and given the large advantage accorded to incumbents and the negative effect of racially biased voting patterns, minority women candidates may still have special advantages over their white female and minority male counterparts” (Bedolla et al. 2005, 167). The difference in the political participation rates between Black women and Black men has led to the two central questions of this paper: First, what are explanations for the increasing difference in political participation between Black men and Black women? Second, are African American women becoming positioned to take over significant political leadership in the United States? This paper will examine some of the factors that have contributed to the widening gap in political participation between Black women and Black men, and will consider this trend relative to larger trends in gender and voting. The paper will focus on the gradual shift in political and leadership representation from Black men to Black women by taking a closer look at the rates of participation of African Americans in U.S. politics within the past four decades. Supporting data are attached as table appendices.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Be All That You Can Be?: Racial Identity Production in the U.S. Military
Intro:
This analysis applies concepts from Stratification Economics to examine racial identity production in the U.S. military. Stratification Economics is an emergent economics subfield that uses the concept of social stratification as a point of departure for examining structural and intentional processes that concurrently generate hierarchy and economic inequality among ascriptively distinguished groups (Darity 2005, Stewart 2008). Stratification economists argue, for example, that inter-group conflict in both economic and non-economic settings is an endogenous characteristic of the social space rather than an exogenous contaminant of market allocation processes and individual decision-making. This investigation employs the model of racial identity production developed by Stewart (1976, 1997). Racial identity is treated as a Becker-type commodity produced by combining market goods and services, and time, using a technology based on pre-existing cultural knowledge. Racial identity is generated jointly with other commodities and has the potential to impose negative externalities on other groups. One implication of this model is that individuals with similar identity production functions have an incentive to engage in collective behavior to reduce negative externalities generated by others’ identity production on own production. Efforts by members of one group to offset the effects of others’ negative identity production externalities create potential for intergroup conflict. The magnitude of such negative externalities is hypothesized to vary across a vector of factors including: the degree of overlap in groups’ composite racial, sexual, religious, and class profiles; the relative weights assigned to racial identity in individuals’ utility functions; the degree of physical proximity and frequency and duration of contacts between members of groups with different identity production functions; and differences in stocks of political and economic resources available to affect identity production possibilities. Relationships between racial identity production and wealth accumulation outcomes have been explored by Darity et al. (2006). These authors conclude that (a) reductions in inter-group income and wealth differentials will not automatically lead to the erosion of traditional patterns of collective identification, and (b) incentives for engaging in cooperative inter-group behavior can reduce the potentially negative dimensions of inter-racial contact and create alternatives to traditional racial identification. The focus of the present investigation on racial identity production dynamics in the U.S. military is potentially instructive for several reasons. First, standardized pay scales, evaluation, and promotion criteria reduce the effects of some traditional pecuniary sources of racial identity production animus operative in the civilian sector. As a consequence, comparison of perceptions of the intensity of racial identity production in the military and in the civilian sector can provide useful insights regarding the relative role of income and wealth differentials compared to other dimensions of racial identity production interactions in generating inter-racial conflict. Second, the U.S. military aggressively attempts to reduce potential negative effects of racial identity production on its mission by fostering an alternative focus of identification. The former Army slogan, “Be All That You Can Be,” and the current one, “An Army of One,” signal this strategy. Both slogans emphasize individual opportunity, but are closely linked to a socialization strategy that emphasizes preparedness, team cohesion, and responsiveness. The effectiveness of a demographically diverse military force depends critically upon the ability of members to trust one another and respect the chain of command. The successful integration of the military, Moskos (1971, pp. 284–5) contends, “was facilitated by the pervasiveness in the military of a bureaucratic ethos, with its concomitant formality and high social distance, that mitigated tensions arising from individual or personal feelings.” The military’s current policy vis a vis equal opportunity is codified in the Department of Defense (DoD) Human Goals, which state, in part, that the DoD aspires, “To make military and civilian service in the Department of Defense a model of equal opportunity for all . . .” and “To create an environment that values diversity and fosters mutual respect and cooperation among all persons . . .” (Department of Defense 1998). Dansby and Landis (1996) have identified five key elements in the military’s approach to the management of equal opportunity (EO) and diversity issues:
 a focus on behavioral change and compliance with stated policy; an emphasis on EO and intercultural understanding as military readiness issues; an understanding that equal opportunity is a commander's responsibility and that the trained equal opportunity advisors can advise and assist the commander in carrying out this responsibility; a belief that education and training can bring about the desired behavioral changes; and reliance on affirmative action plans as a method for ensuring equity and diversity. (pp. 206–207) A third reason for examining racial identity production in the military is the possibility that some findings may yield useful insights for understanding some aspects of civilian workplace dynamics. Moskos (1988; p. 15) argues that “the armed forces of the United States has moved away from an organizational format that is predominantly institutional to one that is more occupational.” As a result of this transformation “in recent decades, the members of the armed forces have felt increasing conflict between internal pressures toward institutional integration and societal trends that push toward identification with like occupational groups in the larger society” (Moskos and Wood 1988; p. 4). In this regard it is useful to note that all military departments (branches) use a system of classifying jobs and categorizing career fields. The Army and Marines assign a Military Occupational Specialty (MOS) code to each member, the Air Force uses Air Force Specialty Codes, and the Navy employs a naval ratings system and Navy Enlisted Classifications. In all services demographic distributions across occupational classifications are monitored to identify systemic patterns of racial and gender over- and under-representation. Despite intensive efforts to manage racial (and gender) diversity, the military continues to face a variety of diversity management challenges. As an example, increasing numbers of gang members are entering the military, many with previous involvement in inter-gang racial conflict. Efforts by gang members to continue these confrontations while in the military require focused interventions (Robson 2006). Confronted by a significant decline in the enlistment of Blacks, one of the Army’s responses has been expanded efforts to attract Latino recruits (Alvarez 2006). The second section reviews selected theoretical and empirical psychological research that informs the present investigation and summarizes historical and contemporary efforts to manage race relations in the military. The models and data are described in the third section. The empirical results are then presented, followed by a discussion of the implications of the study for military human resource policy and further research.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Racial Inequality and Segregation Measures: Some Evidence from the 2000 Census

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Short Term External Debt and Economic Growth—Granger Causality: Evidence from Latin America and the Caribbean
Intro:
This paper is an enquiry about the relative role of economic growth in the size of short-term external debt (STED)—debt with less than one year maturity. Economic growth is seen as the outcrop of monetary and fiscal policies, stronger institutions, and financial development aimed at facilitating stable economic growth that is aligned to continuous increase in absorptive capacity. Against this backdrop, I am interested in whether or not economic growth performance can help to explain growth in STED. To know this is important since the less developed countries (LDCs) have been and are exposed to terms of international trade financing of which STED formed an increasingly greater proportion of the debt portfolio over the recent decades (Dadush et al. 2000). I interpreted the increase as responses to policy issues that are related to the complex nature of absorptive capacity in LDCs. For my initial consideration, capacity absorption is the ability of an economy 
to generate the resources essential to meet increase (decrease) demand for consumption goods which occurs autonomously with increase (decrease) in economic growth. In short: does growth in STED reflect the nature of economic growth in the economies of LDCs? The importance of STED to LDCs is measured by its intertwining into their budgetary considerations. The inclusion helps policy makers to balance the budget and while government uses it as device to balance budget risk neutral agents benefit (Jeanne 2000, 2004). Interestingly, STED provides incentives to borrowers (governments) because of the moral hazard presented by the international financial institutions in their role as lenders of last resort (Jeanne 2004). The Bank for International Settlement (BIS 2000 Report) considers STED as “perhaps the most important and sometimes more volatile component of developing countries’ external obligations”. For example STED—bank loans, short-term securities, and trade creditFootnote 1—represented 60% of outstanding international bank claims as well as 50% of all new loans in the 1990s (Dadush et al. 2000). In fact international trade policies were shaped by the short-term lending to finance projects that were to come on stream beyond the maturity date of the loans (Chang and Velasco 1999) and to determine priority of access to foreign exchange in time of crises for less credit worthy borrowers (INTGDF 2002). Failure to account for the presence of STED omits the role of short-term forces (consumer, producer, financial institutions, government, and international institutions) in empirical modeling of international trade and development. It is well documented that economic growth performance is seen as a road map used to determine the direction and composition of international trade financingFootnote 2 (Todaro 1996). Several authors observed a negative correlation between economic growth and increasing foreign debt including Cunningham (1993), Easterly (2001), Oks and Van Wijnbergen (1995) and Sachs (1989). On the contrary, Dadush et al. (2000) observed that increased economic growth preceded growth of STED in emerging markets—Brazil, Mexico, Thailand, and Russia. INTGDF (2000) reported that cyclical rapid growth in the 1990s contributed to rapid growth in short-term financing. Gooptu et al. (1992) found that countries with greater growth prospects attracted more short-term credit. On the other hand, slow growth dampened 
inflows of private investment and increased short-term debt (UNCTAD 2002) because debt payment suppressed the demand for goods which in turn suppressed the demand for LDCs goods and hence dampened its growth (Cohen 1993). Do these mean that economic growth (size)—a contemporaneous presence, and shocks (deviations from long-run equilibrium growth path) cause STED to grow? Do changes in GDP cause changes in the accumulation of STED or are both determined endogenously? Though the STED phenomenon has been identified as very important, it has been neglected largely in the literature of the debt-growth nexus. The STED-GDP causality study is motivated by the fact that STED has been a prominent element of the portfolio of LDCs (Dadush et al. 2000) as well as featured as the cause of financial failure in large emerging markets (Rodrik and Velasco 1999
). The literature is lacking in empirical work on possible causality between the STED and GDP. Except for Amoateng and Amoako-Adu (1996) who found bidirectional causality between economic growth, export, and debt servicing, I am not aware of any theory about the interaction of STED and economic growth. Similarly, I am unacquainted with any major empirical studies establishing a relationship between economic growth and STED, except Butts (2006), Eichengreen and Mody (1999), and Rodrik and Velasco (1999). Butts (2006) found a positive relationship between STED and economic growth in the case of Guyana. Eichengreen and Mody (1999) argued that economic growth and high STED can co-exist once the perception of creditors about sustainability does not 
shift. Rodrik and Velasco (1999) pointed out that STED could increase investment and growth indirectly, and increase with openness of the economy; while Gooptu et al. (1992) suggested that the volume of short-term lending is affected by specific country factors. Against this backdrop, the purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between economic growth and STED in 27 selected Latin American and Caribbean countries over the period 1970–2003. With increasing economic growth in 2003 Latin America, in especially Argentina which had experienced negative growth of nearly 18.6% since 1998 (UNCTAD 2004) and the Caribbean, I postulate that economic growth Granger-caused growth in STED in several countries in Latin America and Caribbean. The empirical investigation to test the propositions of Granger-causality was done using both the Granger (1969), and Engle-Granger (1987) single equation VAR and the Johansen and Juselius (1990) maximum likelihood estimation approaches. This simple study of GDP and STED is used for comparison across countries where differences in size and 
composition of macroeconomic policy, make impact on environmental shocks which are singular to each country selected from Latin America and the Caribbean. The rest of the paper is as follows. In section two model specification, data, and methodology are considered. Section three gives estimation and results. Section four gives the conclusions.
