Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Is Race a Determinant of Student Performance in Economics?
Intro:
In the first model, the dependent variable GDGRADE (good grade) is constructed by assigning each observation a one for a grade of B or better and zero otherwise. For GENDER, female is set equal to one and male equal to zero. At first, dummy variables were created for the racial groups ASIAN, FOREIGN, BLACK, and LATINO, designating Asian American, African American, Hispanic, and International students respectively. Hypotheses were tested for BLACK equal to LATINO and ASIAN equal to FOREIGN. There was no significant difference between African American and Hispanic students, and these groups were combined to form the MINORITY variable. A corresponding variable for non-minority students could not be used because there were significant differences between observations in ASIAN and FOREIGN categories. White students are the base in each set of regressions. The complete set of variables used in the model is listed in Table 3. Although cumulative GPA in the semester prior to taking the courses would be the recommended proxy for academic maturity (Grove et al. 2006), it was not possible to obtain these data. High school rank and SAT scores were available and are also commonly used to indicate academic aptitude. In addition, the variable UTSTART indicates the number of semesters each student had completed at UT prior to the semester studied. It would be expected that the more experienced students would also tend to be more successful and have higher grades on average.
 Some observations had missing values for SAT scores, high school rank, and high school size. Transfer students to UT are not required to submit SAT results, though many do. Some transfer students, as well as those who completed their secondary education outside of the United States, do not have high school rank or size in their records. It was not possible to determine from the data set whether students had missing background information because they were transfer students or because they had completed high school abroad. One important variable serves as a measure of relative high school quality. Public schools in Texas at the time were evaluated by the Texas Education Agency (TEA), which required administration of the Texas Assessment of Academic Skills (TAAS) to all sophomores in high school. The percentage of students in each high school, not in special education, who passed this exam was published by the TEA and used to evaluate high schools. These percentage passing rates were matched to the high school attended by each student to generate the TAAS variable. Again, some observations had missing values since TAAS scores are available only for students who attended public high schools in Texas. A modified zero-order regression method is used in order to utilize the remaining information available from those observations with missing values (Maddala 1977, pp. 201–203). An imputed value of zero was given to each missing value and dummy variables created where a one was assigned whenever the values in SATV, SATQ, HSSIZE, HSRANK or TAAS were equal to zero, and zero otherwise. Two variables for prior coursework are included in the data set, ECO and CALC. MACRO and MICRO did not have prerequisites at UT, at the time, and there was no recommended sequence. Most students, though, took MACRO before MICRO. The ECO variable is a dummy for successful completion of a previous course in economics, set equal to one if the student earned a grade of at least C in the course, taken prior to the targeted semester, and zero otherwise. Students who successfully completed of a previous introductory course would be expected to do well in the subsequent course both because they would have gained experience with the analytical skills required in economics and because they would more likely be good students. The dummy variable (CALC) indicates successful completion of a first-semester calculus course and was set equal to one if students earned a grade of C or better, zero otherwise. Calculus was required of business majors, but not a prerequisite for either MACRO or MICRO. It was assumed that students who successfully completed at least one course in calculus prior to taking the introductory economics course would have an advantage in understanding the quantitative and graphical components in this material. In this first model, it is hypothesized that the inclusion of a broad set of explanatory variables would eliminate race as a statistically significant factor in student performance. The expectation is that race per se does not determine a student’s success, but rather is a proxy for student characteristics that will either be controlled more explicitly in the model or are unobservable. Thus, variables for race and gender (ASIAN, FOREIGN, MINORITY and GENDER) should not yield statistically significant coefficients and grade differentials should be eliminated. The variable HSSIZE is the number graduating in the same high school class as the student; there is no prior expectation for the coefficient sign. It could be that students from smaller high schools may receive more individual attention and be more prepared academically. On the other hand, students matriculating from larger high schools may have access to more resources, such as honors programs with classes in calculus and other advanced topics. The variable CLSIZE is the class size for each unique section and, as in prior studies by Kennedy and Siegfried (1997), is not expected to be a statistically significant determinant of performance. An indicator variable, FALL, controls for the semester in which the student took the course, fall or spring as enrollment patterns may have varied between the two semesters. Enrollment time frames were longer in the fall and also included the surge of entering freshmen. Students enrolled in spring semesters might be more experienced in both the registration process and in deciding which classes to take. Grades might be slightly biased upwards during spring semesters. The average grade for each unique course section (MGRADE) was calculated and used to control for instructor and other effects particular to that section. This technique is used by Raimondo et al. (1990), and by Brasfield et al. (1992). The average grade is unique to each section and would be the equivalent of using indicator variables for each instructor and each section. Minority students and their non-minority counterparts come to the university with differing levels of academic maturity, measured or proxied by test scores and high school rank at graduation. Mean scores for these variables, as well as the mean course grades and the percent of female students in each category, are given in Table 4. The levels of statistical significance indicated were determined by difference of means tests comparing minority to non-minority scores. Average grades earned in both MACRO and MICRO as well as quantitative and verbal SAT scores are significantly lower for minority students then for non-minority students. Performance on the TAAS is significantly lower for MICRO only.
 Probit analysis results are list in Table 5. With few exceptions, the coefficient estimates for MACRO and MICRO are similar. In this model, gender is not a statistically significant factor in earning good grades in these classes. The sizes of the student’s high school graduating class (HSSIZE), as well as the number of prior semesters at Texas (UTSTART) are also not statistically significant.
 Success in both MACRO and MICRO is directly and significantly related to the students AGE, SAT scores, the student’s percentile rank at high school graduation rank (HSRANK) and relative high school quality, as measured by the TAAS variable. Probit estimates on UT and course-specific characteristics show mixed results. In both MACRO and MICRO the control for instructor effects (MGRADE) was statistically significant, but the unique section class size (CLSIZE) is only statistically significant for MICRO. Students do better in the larger the section of MICRO, even holding instructor effects constant. Taking MACRO in the fall versus the spring semester (FALL) gives a higher probability of success, but does not seem to affect performance in MICRO. Successful completion of at least one semester of calculus (CALC) is positive and statistically significant in both MACRO and MICRO. Course sequencing (ECO) is only statistically significant for MICRO. That is, grades improve when students take MACRO before MICRO, but not when MICRO is first. Of main interest are the coefficient estimates for race. In spite of the numerous explanatory variables, race is a statistically significant factor in determining student performance in MACRO and MICRO. Asian American students have higher probabilities of earning good grades than do White students in MACRO, but their performance in MICRO is not significantly different. Stronger results are found for International students, as the coefficient estimates are relatively larger and statistically significant for both MACRO and MICRO. These estimates most likely highlight substantial selection effects for International students, who may come from countries where acquisition of quantitative skills in secondary education is more rigorous than in this country, or may be members of elite groups in their countries: those with the highest motivation to excel academically as well as those with relatively advantaged socioeconomic backgrounds. Minority students, on the other hand, have significantly lower probabilities of earning good grades in MACRO and MICRO than do any of the other students. Results were similar when interaction effects between the race variables and high school rank, TAAS, and SAT scores were tested. In summary, probit analysis indicates that minority students on average have a significantly lower probability of earning good grades in economics than non-minority students. The performance differential is due in part to the fact that minority students in the data set, on average, have a different set of academic background characteristics, such as lower SAT and TAAS scores. Some portion of the difference in grades earned however is not explained by the independent variables in the data.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Families in the Gautreaux Housing Mobility Program: Perceptions and Responses to the U.S. Political Economy
Intro: In August 1966, 53 Black neighborhood organizations called the West Side Federation filed a class action lawsuit against the Chicago Housing Authority (CHA) and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). The West Side Federation argued that CHA’s pattern of building most of their new public housing in the Black ghetto was systematic and illegal segregation and that HUD financed and endorsed CHA’s discriminatory behavior (Polikoff 2006; Rubinowitz and Rosenbaum 2000). Dorothy Gautreaux, a Black community activist, agreed to be the named plaintiff on the lawsuit which represented more than 40,000 Black families living in Chicago public housing or on the waiting list. Ten years later, the United States Supreme Court agreed that CHA and HUD discriminated against Blacks and ordered one of the largest desegregation programs in U.S. history, The Gautreaux Assisted Housing Program. The Gautreaux program represents an example of the U.S. government responding to African American citizens’ demands for public policy that would create dramatic shifts in their political and economic landscape and have the long-term goal of eradicating inequality. I argue that the 1966 Civil Rights Movement context of the Gautreaux lawsuit represents one of several major shifts in the U.S. political economy that dramatically altered the opportunity structure and life chances of African Americans: emancipation, Great Migrations, Civil Rights and Black Power Movements, and post-industrial job displacements. However, this interaction between social structures and individuals’ lives raises several important questions: How do racialized groups, African Americans in particular, perceive structures in the U.S. political economy that shape life course outcomes within and across generations? What are major events that appear in African American families narratives? How does their understanding of these events influence their decisions and outcomes associated with residential location and human capital (education and employment)? These questions are important because the ability of Gautreaux families to “rent out” their human capital in the market place continues to be affected by market failures in the broader political economy. In a report titled Residential Segregation and Housing Discrimination in the Untied States Michael de Leeuw et al. (2007:2) outline how the U.S. “has not satisfactorily complied with its obligations under CERD [Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination].” The authors discuss the historical role of government policies and practices in promoting racial discrimination and segregated housing and they identify current programs, practices, and policies that they feel continue to violate CERD equality obligations. For instance, public housing continues to be racially segregated and primarily located in areas of concentrated poverty, which affects women more than men. Unpacking the interaction between the political and economic structures in the lives of African American families and their responses to these structures is important for scholars interested in understanding the dialectics of constraints and opportunity and the role of policy in eradicating inequality. The goal of this study is to fill some of the knowledge gap by analyzing rich detailed narratives from a random subsample of Gautreaux participants (N = 25). This study examines how the Gautreaux participants perceive the economic and political structures in their lives and the lives of their parents (N = 50) and children (N = 72) and how these perceptions and experiences shape human capital outcomes (education and employment). An important feature of this study is that the parents of the Gautreaux participants have never been discussed in the literature on the Gautreaux program. The three generations of Gautreaux families have direct experiences with three out of the four major events that I argue dramatically shaped the lives of African Americans, which makes them uniquely interesting in an analysis of perceptions of, responses to, and outcomes associated with different periods of the U.S. political economy. In addition, the exogenous shock of the Gautreaux program and its associated moves to predominantly White or more integrated and affluent neighborhoods provides unusual insights into what happens when the government deploys resources to foster equal access (to housing in this case) for African American families. My findings show that the Gautreaux participants’ identified three major changes in political and economic structures as influencing the life course development of their families: the Great Migration(s), the Civil Rights Movement, and post-Civil Rights era (the 1976 Gautreaux program, affirmative action laws, the 1973 Comprehensive Employment and Training Act programs, etc.). Participants stated that while social structures may be racially discriminatory, they have a dialectical nature which appears as increased opportunities in the midst of persistent structural constraints. These dialectical perceptions determined their acts of resistance or agency (migration, Gautreaux move, school protests in suburbs, etc.). I argue that these acts of resistance were bundled across generations and influenced social mobility/quality of life in the form of educational and occupational accomplishments.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Development Theory of Transportation Infrastructure Examined in the Context of Central and West Africa

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Financing Community Development in the US: A Comparison of “War on Poverty” and 1990s-Era Policy Approaches
Intro:
At the end of April 1992, Los Angeles erupted in violence after the televised brutal beating of Rodney King by Los Angeles police officers. The episode paralleled the 1965 Watts riots. It seemed momentarily that if that one long historical cycle—urban violence, policy intervention, benign neglect, festering social inequalities—had been completed, another had begun. But history never performs the same drama twice. The 1965 riots were centered in Watts and bounded by a police/military blockade around a predominantly African American area known thenceforth as South Central Los Angeles.Footnote 1 The 1992 events also began in South Central, but soon stretched to Koreatown, Culver City, even trendy Melrose Avenue. And in 1992, many Latinos, having recently moved in large numbers to South Central, were involved. The targets of violence were often stores owned by Koreans, who had become the principal “middleman minority” operating stores in inner-core Los Angeles. It was widely noted that the 1992 uprising constituted the first multi-cultural riot in contemporary U.S. history.Footnote 2
 The 1992 civil unrest in Los Angeles helped launch a new round of federal policies, aimed at spurring asset-building and business activity in lower-income and non-white communities. This marked the first sustained federal urban-policy effort since the 1960s. Here too, differences between 1965 and 1992 policy responses are striking. This paper analyzes these post-1992 federal policies, notably the Community Development Financial Institution (CDFI) program and the New Markets initiative, which aim at building assets and strengthening businesses in lower-income and non-white communities. This analysis first considers the role of finance in community development in general terms; then, it contrasts 1990s development-financing policies with those undertaken decades earlier in the context of the federal “War on Poverty.” We proceed as follows. “Conceptualizing banking/financial and asset-building practices: a framework” investigates the basic elements of asset-building processes in urban areas, especially in lower-income urban areas. This discussion points out that financing structures are at the heart of asset-building processes; and these structures pose challenges for any development effort, whether in upper-income suburban or lower-income inner-core areas. “A short history of urban asset-building initiatives before 1990” then summarizes federal urban programs aimed at asset-building and business development, from the 1960s through the Nixon era. “The transformation of banking and financial practices” then examines another crucial context of the newer federal urban initiatives—the transformation of banking and financial-industry practices. Then “Contemporary asset-building in urban areas: from CDFIs to New Market tax credits” returns us to Los Angeles in 1992. It describes the federal urban asset-building policies of the Clinton and Bush Administrations.Footnote 3 “Evaluating the post-1990 federal financing policies” then analyzes these newer federal asset-building urban policies—CDFI and New Markets—in light of past federal policies and of the changing structure of urban financial markets. “The new urban policy and evolving financial markets: some conclusions” draws out some policy implications.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Politics of Skin Color in Brazil
Intro: Racial classification and identification are not always consistent. An Afro-Brazilian may self-classify in various color or racial categories depending on their social situation. In addition, an Afro-Brazilian may self-identify in one color category but be identified as another color by someone else. I argue that despite strong anti-black sentiment in Latin America generally (Pena et al. 2004) and Brazil more specifically, Afro-Brazilians gain utility from choosing a black identity and the effects of black consciousness are expressed in candidate preference and support for racial policies. While I believe there are emotional attachments to identity, I stress that Brazilians can change their color choices and preferences according to social situations. Bailey and Telles (2006) find that poorer Afro-Brazilians tend to choose the brown category more than Afro-Brazilians with higher education. Thus both poor and high income Afro-Brazilians can whiten their color identification but this is more popular among poorer and older Afro-Brazilians. Racial classification is influenced by region, education, and age. Using 1996 national survey data, Telles finds that low educated blacks are more likely to be consistently classified than highly educated people who classify as black. The strongest effect is gender. Highly educated women who self- identify as black are less likely to be identified as black. He finds that self-identified black women in São Paulo are only similarly classified by interviewers twenty-eight percent of the time and in Bahia only twenty-two percent of the time (2004:99). It is considered demeaning to call a highly educated black woman preta so interviewers tend to classify them in other color categories. For this reason, even the black color category (preto), is not a clear-cut category with no room for manipulating ones color or having ones color manipulated. I argue that choosing moreno, an ambiguous color category is a form of whitening and Telles finds that low-educated Brazilians are two and a half times more likely than those with a high level of education to choose moreno. He finds that respondents with high levels of education are nearly three times as likely than those with low levels of education to choose the negro category (2004, 98–99). As Telles notes, in this case money darkens rather than whitens. The impact of education on self-classification as black is extremely important, given the fact that blackness continues to be stigmatized in Brazilian society. Highly educated Afro-Brazilians and younger Afro-Brazilians now embrace this identity and much of this can be attributed to the efforts of the black movement. In an informal conversation with me, a middle-class Afro-Brazilian man said he made a conscious effort to practice enegreçiamento so that he would challenge stereotypes of black people by showing white Brazilians that Afro-Brazilian families can be made up of a professional couple who are both black and embrace Afro-Brazilian culture and African history. Afro-Brazilians are utility maximizing individuals who choose identities according to preferences and to perceived gains. Afro-Brazilians who choose the black categories of preto and negro do so for strategic reasons. Afro-Brazilians who choose non-black identities likely do so because they do not see the immediate benefits of claiming a black identity. They are not simply passive believers in racial hegemony who are “less-racially conscious.” In local low-income communities where blackness has negative connotations (Sheriff 2001), there are low incentives to claim a black identity thereby resulting in high incentives to whiten ones color identity. While I argue that at the outset, identities are strategically chosen I argue that those who choose black identities may become emotionally attached to these identities and gain psychic benefits when choosing this identity. Sales Augusto Santos, an Afro-Brazilian Sociologist concurs that Afro-Brazilians with higher incomes continue to face discrimination despite the myth that money whitens and it is the experience of racism that leads them to claim a black identity.Footnote 1 I believe that color choices are rational not random choices. Further, although I believe lower-income Afro-Brazilians may not recognize the benefits of choosing black identities, I believe that some do choose black identities and external factors such as the Hip Hop movement, non-governmental organizations dedicated to addressing discrimination, and daily experiences of racism such as police brutality make it very difficult to deny blackness.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Biological V. Social Definitions of Race: Implications for Modern Biomedical Research
Intro: What do we mean when we say race? The vast majority people do not comprehend the origin or present day meaning of this word (Graves 2005). Generally, the lay person is referring to both a biological and social content when they use this term. When university students are asked to name how many races exist within the human species their answers range between one—infinity (Graves 2006). When asked what characteristics distinguish human races, they reply that physical and cultural characteristics must be used to identify human races (Graves 2006). Unfortunately, these misconceptions are just as true for those who conduct biomedical research. For example, a recent search of Entrez Pubmed utilizing the term race returned 135,953 articles from the human biomedical literature. More specifically, searches on Caucasian, Mongoloid, and Negroid race returned 37,044, 20,656, and 51,039 citations respectively. While one can still debate the utility of the term race in the human biomedical literature, almost no one defends the idea that the 19th century racial categories Caucasian, Mongoloid, or Negroid are of much use in 21st century research. Yet these terms still remain. This paper argues that this confusion results in part from the general ignorance of evolutionary mechanisms impacting biological variety in species and their results on the human species, specifically. Without an evolutionary perspective, notions of human races and their reputed characteristics persist in society at large, as well as in biomedical researchers. This false paradigm has important implications for the way biomedical research studies are structured, data collected, evaluated, and the public policy proscriptions which result from this process. Indeed more than ever, 150 years without Darwin are enough, especially in the fields of medicine and public health.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Beyond Disparate Impact: Risk-based Pricing and Disparity in Consumer Credit History Scores
Intro:
The development of credit scoring is closely connected to the increased prevalence of risk-based pricing in mortgage and consumer credit markets. The aggregation of consumer credit data by the credit bureaus during the 1980s allowed creditors to more precisely observe consumers’ past payment histories. By 2000, almost every mortgage origination referred to the borrower’s credit history score. Today the influence of credit scores continues to grow, as scores are increasingly being used to evaluate applications for insurance, rental housing, employment, and other activities outside of lending and credit markets.Footnote 1 This expanded use of credit scores may create an efficiency gain to consumers, if the credit record provides valuable information to users. However, the expanded use of credit scores also raises the stakes involved in ensuring that both the calculation and use of credit scores do not disadvantage underserved groups.Footnote 2
 Existing studies document two concerns:
 The three major credit bureaus—Experian, Equifax, and TransUnion—all currently seek to collect comprehensive information on the credit histories of all individuals in the United States, collecting information from creditors, utility companies, legal records, and collection agency files. The credit bureaus lack legal rights to any information, instead soliciting voluntary reporting from these sources (Avery et al. 2003).Footnote 3 The resulting data create substantial records for most borrowers, but do not reflect complete records of individuals’ credit histories. The Information Policy Institute estimates that 35 to 54 million Americans do not have sufficient information to generate a score (PERC 2006). In particular, households that rely on small lenders and alternative financial service providers may not have the payments made on these accounts reflected in their credit records. The data used to construct individuals’ credit records commonly contain mistakes and factual errors (Avery et al. 2004). The Fair Credit Reporting Act provides all individuals a right to review their credit record at no cost and mandates mechanisms for appeal and correction. However, no analysis has been performed of the ability of individuals to easily and successfully correct mistakes. Equally important, no analysis has been performed of which individuals review their records and pursue corrections. To the extent that underserved individuals lack knowledge of this right and/or lack access to the internet (see Lyons et al. 2007; Gates et al. 2002), fewer individuals will be likely to pursue corrections. This article presents a more fundamental issue related to the interaction of credit scores with the operation of consumer credit markets. Specifically, it outlines the potential for credit scoring to contribute to disparities in the segmentation of low- and high-cost credit markets, describing the consequences of defining credit scores with respect to a universal measure of default—serious delinquency on any open credit line. Definition of the outcome and payment history measures in this way fails to distinguish between default on a fixed-rate prime mortgage and default on a subprime ARM with a teaser rate and/or a balloon payment, credit products that carry very different incentives to prepay and default. The analysis shows that disparities in credit scores emerge when: (1) disparities exist in the processes through which borrowers are assigned to credit products and (2) alternative product characteristics carry varying risks of default. In the wake of mounting subprime foreclosures, this mechanism contains the potential to exacerbate the concentrated impacts of the subprime crisis in low-income and minority communities. In particular, disparities in credit score outcomes may emerge as a result of the concentrated lending activities of brokers and subprime lenders, even in the absence of discrimination. Unfortunately, the proprietary nature of credit scoring has largely prevented scrutiny from regulators and academics.Footnote 4 The primary exception is that the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act of 2003 (FACTA) directly instructed the Federal Reserve Board to test for disparate impact in the calculation of credit scores. The resulting report offers a seminal analysis of the credit scoring process. However, because the credit bureaus do not currently record the terms of an observed loan, the Federal Reserve analysis also relies on universal measures of payment history and default. The first sections of this article present and discuss the calculation of generic credit history scores, focusing on the consequences of using universal measures. A stylized example is then developed to illustrate the mechanism through which credit scores may capture disparity in the surrounding credit markets, passing it into future periods and into other credit markets. While the use of simulated data in this model is partly motivated by the lack of public data on credit scores, this approach is also useful in that it circumvents the issues with omitted variables and unobserved risk that accompany analyses of default and credit risk. The resulting model of credit scoring shows that credit scores reflect the assignment of borrowers to credit products, in addition to borrowers’ underlying risk of default.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Racial/Ethnic Differences in Income Inequality Across US Regions
Intro: Social scientists have devoted much time and resources to understanding the causes and implications of high levels of income inequality within and between countries. Researchers have vigorously explored the impact of gender or educational differences among populations on the root causes of income inequality and on society as a whole. Another interesting way of examining income inequality is to explore the underlying racial/ethnic group dynamics that might have significant influence on the distribution of income. In this paper, we examine regional variations in the distribution of income by race and ethnicity. We examine the factors that might explain income inequality and whether they are the same across racial and ethnic groups. Finally, we examine the impact of within group inequality on overall inequality. The results are two-fold. First, they suggest that income and the square of income both are significant factors influencing income inequality. With the sign of the square of income being negative, the results are consistent with those of others supporting the Kuznets hypothesis. Moreover, increases in unemployment were found to increase inequality, while the percentage of males leads to a decrease for all the groups, however these effects were largest for blacks. There are also regional differences in equality. Inequality is higher in the South than any other region. Second, we present the results of what the overall distribution of income and corresponding inequality measures would have been if the given racial/ethnic group were omitted. The exclusion of whites from all regions but the South increased inequality. Blacks being omitted led to an increase in inequality in the Northeast and South but the levels were virtually zero. Over the last half-century there has been a tremendous amount of interest in the proper measure of inequality ranging from the, now-standard, Gini coefficient to the Relative Mean Deviation measure to the Theil Index. Recent work by Campano and Salvatore (2006) provides an excellent overview of the latest developments in the measurement instruments used in income distribution research. Most work in this area only uses the Gini coefficient as the measure of income inequality. We include the Gini which allows us to incorporate the concept of movements towards or away from the average. This work also uses two types of income: personal income and household income. Given the increasing reliance on several income earners to contribute to total family income, the results derived from household income inclusion are quite telling. This analysis is a first attempt at examining the counterfactual argument of racial/ethnic group importance to overall income inequality by omitting given groups individually and examining the resulting level of inequality.Footnote 1 In addition, this work seeks to explain what factors affect income inequality among given groups and what factors help explain the impact of our counterfactuals. In the next section we present a review of the literature on both inequality and measurements in use along with a discussion of the findings of the impact of these measures on racial/ethnic groups. The third section discusses the data sources used and rationale for the inclusion of our explanatory variables. The fourth section has the model and results. This section also includes a discussion of the counterfactual investigation of racial/ethnic group removal. Concluding remarks are in the final section.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Race, Medicine, and the Science Behind BiDil: How ACE-Inhibition Took the Fall for the First Ethnic Drug

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Increasing Diversity in Telecommunications Ownership and Increasing Efficiency in Spectrum Auctions by Breaking the Link Between Capital Market Discrimination and FCC Spectrum Auction Outcomes
Intro: In Section 309(j)(4)(D) of the Communications Act,Footnote 1 the FCC is required to ensure that businesses owned by members of minority groups are given the opportunity to participate in the provision of spectrum-based services, and, for such purposes, the FCC is required to consider the use of tax certificates, bidding credits and other procedures. The FCC does not, however, provide programs that are specifically targeted to improve ownership opportunities for minorities and women. This is because the FCC eliminated all race-based programs in awarding spectrum licenses after the Supreme Court issued its decision in Adarand Construction, Inc. v. Pena.Footnote 2 In Adarand the Court held that race-based government programs were subject to strict scrutiny. That is race-based programs must serve a compelling governmental interest, such as remedying past discrimination, and must be narrowly tailored to serve that interest. Section 257 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 directs the Commission to identify and eliminate market entry barriers.Footnote 3 In 2000, the Commission released a set of Market Entry Barrier Studies,Footnote 4 and the studies show that race affects opportunities for ownership in telecommunications. Against this legal backdrop, a simple theoretical model is developed to clearly reveal and detail the process or mechanics of racial discrimination in a FCC spectrum auction. Given capital market discrimination and all other factors being equal, we show that a minority firm has no chance or zero probability of winning in an auction for spectrum. In addition, we show that, if equal bidding credits are given to all firms, if there is capital market discrimination, and if all other things are equal, the minority firm has a zero probability of winning. We prove that a policy of auctioning spectrum, when there is capital market discrimination, is an inferior policy among policies that can be used to allocate spectrum. We finally show that a policy of auctioning spectrum, when there is capital market discrimination, results in an inefficient auction. These theoretical results suggest that the FCC is discriminating against minorities and distorting the efficient allocation of spectrum through its auctioning of spectrum under conditions of discrimination in capital markets. The results also suggest that the opportunities for diverse spectrum licensing/ownership can be increased and that spectrum auction efficiency can be improved through the re-introduction of race-based programs that remedy capital market discrimination. The FCC attempted to address an aspect of capital market discrimination by using installment payments to finance winning bids in some spectrum auctions.Footnote 5 Installment payments were abandoned, however, because of failures to pay. Both the economic literature and the telecommunications press suggest that FCC Installment Payments were an absolute failure and that the Commission should not offer any form of credit in the auctioning of licenses. For its part, the FCC has ceased to offer credit and has no proposal to evaluate its lending failures or to initiate a new installment payment system. We suggest that the FCC consider some form of credit arrangement or mechanism in conjunction with other financial institutions. As a first step to resuming some form of governmental financing of licenses to minority/women firms, the failings of the FCC as a lender must be understood. To assess the problems of FCC installment payments, we critically examine the C-Block installment payment plans. After this analysis, we offer several proposals that the FCC may consider in order to address capital market discrimination that is embedded in the auction process. The paper contains six sections. “Literature review” is a review of the literature on the relationship between capital market discrimination and auction outcomes. In “A simple model of an FCC auction and capital market discrimination”, a simple theoretical model of an FCC auction that is based on existing law/rules is developed. We analyze the theoretical relationship between outcomes of an auction and capital market discrimination. “The question of different bidding credits” contains the analysis of the hypothetical case of different auction bidding credits for minority and majority firms. “FCC installment payments” contains a description and critique of the FCC’s Installment Payment System for the C-block Spectrum Auction. In “Installment payments: new proposals” new proposals are presented in order to mitigate the harmful effect of capital market discrimination on auction outcomes and efficiency. We conclude our analysis in “Conclusion”.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The 2007 General Elections in Nigeria: An Account of the Politics of Personal Rule in an African Country by a former Presidential Aide
Intro: On May 29, 1999 Olusegun Obasanjo, a retired army general and former military dictator assumed office as an elected civilian President of Nigeria after 15 years of successive brutal military rule. His deputy was Atiku Abubakar, a former civil servant and wealthy businessman. They contested the election on the platform of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). In 2003 they were reelected in what were widely seen as rigged elections. Another set of general elections were held in April 2007. Obasanjo, having served the constitutionally allowed two terms, was not eligible to contest. So, although the ruling party maintained its hold on power, a new man, Umaru Yar’Adua, is the President. It is those April 2007 elections that I discuss here. I was a participant in the events narrated here, having been a senior Presidential aide serving in the office of the then Vice President, for part of the period covered in this essay. While that made me an interested observer, it also provided me with a unique insight as a scholar into the challenges of democratic development and consolidation in Nigeria, and perhaps Africa.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Origins and Rationale for the African American Economic Summit

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: A Direct Route to Full Employment

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: A Changing South: The 2008 Elections Illuminate Demographic and Economic Trends

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: U.S. Healthcare Reform, 2009-2010: Implications for African Americans
Intro: Since 1980, healthcare expenditures in the United States have increased markedly as a percent of gross domestic product (GDP)—increasing from less than 10% in 1980 to a projected 17% in 2009 and 19% by 2019 (Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services 2010). Costs of this magnitude constitute a challenge to the economy overall but, in particular, for the federal government and its budget deficit. Almost half of healthcare spending is by federal, state and local governments through programs such as Medicare,Footnote 4 MedicaidFootnote 5 and CHIP (Children’s Health Insurance Program)Footnote 6 (Council of Economic Advisers 2009). The fraction of healthcare expenditures borne by governments is expected to grow in the near future as early waves of the Baby BoomFootnote 7 become eligible for and sign up for Medicare and as many also become eligible for and enroll in Medicaid (Council of Economic Advisers 2009). Mushrooming healthcare expenditures cause stresses not only at the macro level but also at the micro level—for employers and individuals. The cost to employers, especially those with 100 or fewer employees, to provide health insurance continues to rise, as does the share of this cost borne by employees. As a result, some employers cease offering health insurance coverage, and some employees do not enroll in the health insurance coverage that is available through their employers. The proportion of non-elderly individuals with employer-sponsored health insurance coverage has steadily declined in recent years—from 64.2% in 2000 to 59.3% in 2007 and 58.5% in 2008 (Families USA 2009; Gould 2009). In addition, between 1996 and 2008, the average annual premium for family coverage grew from $6,462 to $12,298, a 90% increase in real terms (Council of Economic Advisers 2009; Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation 2009a). Retaining health insurance coverage is a growing problem in this country. This is true regardless of the measure used or its data source. In 2007, nearly 46 million Americans did not have health insurance (Council of Economic Advisers 2009). More recent data that reflect the impact of the national recession show a continuation of this trend. In 2008, a total of 46.3 million U.S. residents (15.4% of the population) lacked health insurance (Center on Budget and Policy Priorities 2009). Without changes to our healthcare system, this number is projected to grow to 72 million by 2040 (Council of Economic Advisers 2009). The percentage of full-time working adults ages 18–64 who lacked health insurance coverage was 17.2% in 2008, a modest increase over the 2007 share. In 2008, although people of color (African Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Asian Americans, Hispanic Americans, and Americans who are Native Hawaiians or Other Pacific Islanders) were 35% of the U.S. population, they were 54% of the uninsured in our nation (Families USA 2009). In particular, between January 2009 and September 2009, black non-Hispanics (17.3%) and Hispanics (31.1%) were more likely to be uninsured than white non-Hispanics (11%) (Martinez and Cohen 2010). Regardless of insurance status, African Americans experience disparities in the quality of care received and in health outcomes. The 2008 National Healthcare Disparities Report found that for 19 of the 38 core measures of quality analyzed, African Americans received significantly poorer quality of care than whites (AHRQ 2008). Health outcome disparities also were evident during this same time period, in the form of lower life expectancy, higher incidence of diabetes, and higher incidence of HIV/AIDS among African Americans than among whites (US DHHS 2009). Persistent racial/ethnic disparities in access to insurance, receipt of quality care and health outcomes are reflected in the nation’s overall healthcare spending as well. A recent study (LaVeist et al. 2009) found that if health disparities between whites and African Americans, Hispanic Americans and Asian Americans (as a group) had not existed during the 2003–2006 period, the U.S. would have incurred $1.24 trillion less in costs associated with direct medical care, productivity loss due to disability and illness, and premature death. When direct medical care expenditures alone were examined, 31% of this spending for these three subpopulations of color between 2003 and 2006 would not have occurred if racial/ethnic disparities between these groups did not exist.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Race-Conscious Policy Analysis and the Healthcare Reform Debate

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Can ‘Baby Bonds’ Eliminate the Racial Wealth Gap in Putative Post-Racial America?
Intro: The post-racial ideology represents a shift from some acknowledgement of a social responsibility for the condition of black America to a position where blacks need to “get over it” and “take personal responsibility.” Its rhetoric argues that discrimination and other social barriers are largely things of the past, that blacks now need to stop playing the “victim role” and recognize their own fault in the persistence of racial inequality. Moreover, blacks are enjoined to stop making particularistic claims on America and solely pursue programs of social change designed to reach all Americans. All of these sentiments were expressed plainly by Barack Obama in his “More Perfect Union” speech in Philadelphia during the campaign: For the African-American community, that path means embracing the burdens of our past without becoming victims of our past. It means continuing to insist on a full measure of justice in every aspect of American life. But it also means binding our particular grievances—for better health care, and better schools, and better jobs—to the larger aspirations of all Americans—the white woman struggling to break the glass ceiling, the white man who’s been laid off, the immigrant trying to feed his family. And it means taking full responsibility for our own lives—by demanding more from our fathers, and spending more time with our children, and reading to them, and teaching them that while they may face challenges and discrimination in their own lives, they must never succumb to despair or cynicism; they must always believe that they can write their own destiny. It should be noted that the post-racial perspective typically does acknowledge that racial discrimination still exist. However, it tends to trivialize and downplay its significance. For example, during his address at the 100th Anniversary of the NAACP this past summer, Obama states that: I understand that there may be a temptation among some to think that discrimination is no longer a problem in 2009. And I believe that overall, there probably has never been less discrimination in America than there is today... But make no mistake: The pain of discrimination is still felt in America. By African American women paid less for doing the same work as colleagues of a different color and a different gender. By Latinos made to feel unwelcome in their own country. By Muslim Americans viewed with the suspicion simply because they kneel down to praise God. By our gay brothers and sisters, still taunted, still attacked, still denied rights. Both implicitly and explicitly, Obama is arguing that there is nothing unique about the discriminatory barriers faced by black Americans today, and further, whatever discriminatory barriers that they may face, are at their lowest point ever. However, Obama does seem to uniquely target his personal responsibility rhetoric to blacks. What is lacking from his discrimination narrative is the empirical evidence which indicates that since the mid to late 1970s black-white wage inequality, along with the measured component of that inequality attributable to discrimination, has remained roughly flat. Indeed, the election of Barack Obama has given the discourse of post-racialism added fuel. For example, after the 2008 presidential election, actor Will Smith proclaimed “...(a)ll of our excuses have been removed. There’s no White man trying to keep you down, because if he were trying to keep you down he would have [also tried to keep] Obama down” (John-Hall 2009). The example of the ascendency of blacks to elite positions is the typical evidence put forth by post-racialists. Common examples before Obama included the hiring of black CEOs at fortune 500 corporations like AOL Time Warner and American Express, the appointment of blacks at the highest level of the cabinet, such as Secretary of State and National Security Advisor, as well as successful black candidate in many major local and state-wide elections. Post-racialists attempt to bolster their case by arguing that these examples of black exceptionalism result from individual or familial acts of perseverance and hard work. In fact, during his recent address at the 100th Anniversary celebration of the NAACP, Barack Obama offers himself and the hard work and parenting behavior of his mother as an example: … I was raised by a single mom. I didn’t come from a lot of wealth. I got into my share of trouble as a child. My life could have easily taken a turn for the worse. When I drive through Harlem or I drive through the South Side of Chicago and I see young men on the corners, I say, there but for the grace of God go I. They’re no less gifted than me. They’re no less talented than me. But I had some breaks. That mother of mine, she gave me love; she pushed me, she cared about my education; she took no lip; she taught me right from wrong. Because of her, I had a chance to make the most of my abilities… What Obama omits in his narrative is the fact that his single mother had a Ph.D., and the fact that he received an elite education both abroad in Indonesia and domestically while on scholarship at one of the best private schools in Hawaii. Instead, his narrative emphasizes the love, motivation and discipline that his mother instilled, which presumably was lacking in the household of his black inner city comparisons. One of the biggest proponents of the post-racial narrative is the highly acclaimed author, Charles Johnson. In the top story of the Summer 2008 edition of the American Scholar, entitled “The End of the Black American Narrative,” Johnson (2008) qualifies himself as a social theorist by describing how fictional writers concerned with social issues use their craft to put forth narratives addressing actual social experiences. His own social theory on race begins with a tale of exploitation and victimization in his award winning novel, Middle Passage. But, as a result of the successes of the civil rights movement, including the Civil Rights Acts, the Voting Rights Acts, and the growth of the middle class, he argues that that narrative has changed—we are now in a post-racial American and that the narrative of black victimization is over. He asserts that it “…is no longer the case that the essence of black American life is racial victimization and disenfranchisement, a curse and condemnation, a destiny based on color in which the meaning of one’s life is thinghood, created even before one is born.” But how does the new and improved Charles Johnson narrative explain the racial wealth gap, and the fact that this so called black middle class dramatically shrinks when wealth is used as the indicator of class position?

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Racial Identity Production Dynamics and Persisting Wealth Differentials: Integrating Neo-Institutionalist Perspectives into Stratification Economics
Intro: This analysis offers commentary on issues raised in the investigation undertaken by Hamilton and Darity (2009) via the integration of aspects of Institutional Economics into the Stratification economics framework developed by Darity, Mason, and Stewart (2002 [DMS1], 2006 [DMS2]). The study addresses the implications of a post-racialist orientation for racial wealth disparities and uses the Institutionalist focus on transactions to generate explanations for the persistence of the black-white racial wealth gap and predict likely outcomes associated with post-racial trajectories. The second section provides a brief overview of the scope of Stratification Economics and makes the case for the usefulness of integrating aspects of Institutionalist Economics in to Stratification economics. The third section applies insights from the synthesized framework to examine wealth inequalities in a post-racial regime. A brief note on policy implications concludes the essay.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Subprime Crisis and African Americans
Intro: There is a long history of unfair housing and lending practices in the United States; and generally, African Americans have been disproportionately negatively impacted by these activities. In order to understand the current economic crisis and its impacts on African Americans, one must first explore the historical spectrum of discriminatory actions leveled against blacks in housing and mortgage lending. Henry Cisneros, former HUD Secretary, states “the serious problems of housing discrimination and segregation…have now helped to lead us to our current financial crisis (Kutty 2009, p. 3).” Failure to revisit the past may lead to similar dire consequences in the future.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Subprime Crisis and African Americans—Response

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Response to “The Subprime Crisis and African Americans” by Sandra Phillips

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Economic and Educational State of Black Americans in the 21st Century: Should We be Optimistic or Concerned?
Intro: Over the past few decades the United States (U.S.) population has undergone major demographic changes. Whereas black Americans’ share of the U.S. population was 11.8% in 1990 and is projected to be 12.2% in 2010, the Latino/a population’s share is expected to increase from the 9% observed in 1990 to 16% in 2010. Although the black population is projected to increase steadily over the next half century, it will likely not comprise more that 12% of the U.S. population by 2050. This is primarily due to the rapid growth of the Latino/a population, which will nearly triple by 2050 and comprise roughly a third of the total U.S. population. In contrast, the non-Hispanic white population will remain virtually unchanged over the next 40 years (U.S. Census 2008). These changes make it tempting to shift the economic policy focus toward Latino/as, the largest and fastest growing minority group within the U.S. However, black Americans continue to experience large disadvantages and face factors that will make it challenging for them to become upwardly mobile and achieve socioeconomic parity. Furthermore, both blacks and Latino/as face many of the same socioeconomic and educational obstacles that must be eradicated if the United States is to fulfill its commitment to achieving race-neutrality so that the American “creed of opportunity” is inclusive of all groups. This report presents an overview of the economic and educational status of black Americans. In addition to summarizing blacks’ current economic condition, long-term trends are also presented. The purpose of this report is to highlight information that will accentuate the magnitude of the black socioeconomic disadvantage. My goal is to generate discussion about policies in which people have an awareness of the scale and time it will take to address racial inequality. Therefore, this report is more descriptive than prescriptive. To help facilitate thinking about potential policy directions, economic patterns are shown across various presidential administrations.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Comments on “Black Americans in the 21st Century: Should We Be Optimistic or Concerned?”

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Creating a Testable, Estimable Model to Inform Our Response to the Test-Score Gap Crisis

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Black-White Inequality in Reading and Math Across K-12 Schooling: A Synthetic Cohort Perspective
Intro: Reducing the racial/ethnic achievement gap is perhaps the most important method for bringing about equality within the United States (Jencks and Phillips 1998; Ferguson 2001). For example, convergence in the black-white gap in basic premarket skills can be a factor that contributes to a reduction in black-white inequalities in educational attainment and earnings (Farkas and Vicknair 1996; Johnson and Neal 1998; O’Neil 1990). Furthermore, the recent rejection of affirmative action initiatives designed to offset achievement disparities in K-12—such as Proposition 209 in California and Hopwood v. Texas (78 F.3d 932 Fifth Circuit 1995) in Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi—has serious negative consequences for minority students’ acceptance and enrollment rates in premier institutions of higher education (Brown and Hirschman 2006; Harris and Tienda 2010). The use of test scores in college admissions decisions still disadvantages minority students, and contributes to racial/ethnic disparities on future life-chance outcomes (Carnervale 1999; Ogbu 1994), as many elite colleges and professional schools continue to rely on test scores as in their admissions process (Vars and Bowen 1998). Scholars generally agree that black-white differences in achievement are present at every stage of schooling within K-12 education (Fyer and Levitt 2004; Hallinan 2001). There is less agreement, however, on the nature and extent of these differences. A main reason for this is that the achievement gap has been measured differently across studies. Some have used national average tests based on the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) and SAT scores (Campbell et al. 2000), whereas others have used either regional or specialized tests created by private entities (Orr 2003; Stevenson et al. 1990; Roscigno 2000). The NAEP has been particularly important for measuring change in achievement over time for national cohorts of fourth, eighth, and twelfth graders. These data have shown that significant differences exist among racial and ethnic groups. Assessments indicate that black students tend to perform below the national level while whites perform above the national level. The black-white gap declined across subject area and grade level from 1973–1999, with the largest gains by black students occurring in the late 1980s. Since then gaps have widened among 4th, 8th, and 12th graders. Thus, although black students have made achievement gains in the last several decades, they continue to exhibit lower reading and mathematics skills compared to their white counterparts. A number of longitudinal studies have assessed black-white differences at various stages of schooling. These reports have illustrated that blacks score much lower than whites in reading and mathematics at school entry, and these differences become larger at each grade level (Rathbun et al. 2004; Fyer and Levitt 2004). A few studies have emphasized that the white advantage in reading over blacks increases during summer (Entwisle and Alexander 1993; Entwisle and Alexander 1992), with some estimates suggesting that this increase is as large as .15 points per month during kindergarten and .19 points per month during first grade (scores based on a 92-point reading test) (Downey et al. 2004). However, it remains unclear how the black-white achievement gap and the achievement distribution changes throughout the K-12 schooling period.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: What the Achievement Gap Conversation is Missing

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: “Cautiously Optimistic” Comments on “Black Americans in the 21st Century: Should we be Optimistic or Concerned?”

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Crime, Incarceration, and Employment in Light of the Great Recession

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Moments of Disparate Peaks: Race-Gender Wage Gaps Among Mature Persons, 1965–2007
Intro:
The individuals observed in this study were born during 1890–1951, between “the Nadir” and the rise of the post-World War II movement for African American equality. Historians refer to the years from 1877 to 1917 (the start of American participation in World War I) as “the Nadir,” that is, the low-point of the African American post-Civil War struggle for racial equality. During 1882–83 the Supreme Court declared unconstitutional the Civil Rights Act of 1875, stating that it interfered with the property rights of individual (white) citizens. In the infamous Plessy v. Ferguson case of 1896 the Supreme Court enshrined “separate but equal” as the law of the land. The Court declared that it was acceptable for public and private entities to provide racially separate but equal facilities and, thereby, the Court provided legal cover for decades of political, legal, and economic exclusion and disparity within both markets and extra-market social processes. Historically, private and state-sponsored violence against African Americans has been a complementary force with market competition in allocating economic opportunity across racial groups. Tolnay and Beck (1992) estimate that at least one African American man, woman, or child was lynched every week during 1882–1930. Most of these lynching were in Southern states. On January 13, 2000, the New York Times reported that 4,742 African Americans were lynched between 1882 and 1968, a rate of about 1 lynching every 6.6 days (Smith 2000). But, most of these lynching occurred prior to 1955. Woodward (1951: 351–352) estimates 127 blacks were lynched every year between 1889 and 1899, a rate of nearly 2 1/2 African Americans per week. Lynchings of African Americans were not mere chance events related to idiosyncratic acts by bigots. Rather, lynchings were an essential element of private sector initiated but state-accepted acts of terrorism. In 1892, Ida B. Wells Barnett wrote that lynching was “an excuse to get rid of Negroes who were acquiring wealth and property and thus keep the race terrorized (quoted in Jacqueline Jones 1998:333).” Lynchings were designed to stifle African American political and economic competition with whites, most especially the political and economic competition arising from independent black males (Olzak 1990). In the midst of the Nadir and therefore despite economic incentives to the contrary, African Americans closed the literacy gap with whites, experienced exceptional entrepreneurial development, and inaugurated an impressive period of institution buildingFootnote 1 For example, illiteracy rates among African Americans declined from 81% in 1870 to 34% by 1910 (Collins and Margo 2003).Footnote 2
 The period from World War I to 1965 was characterized by migration out of the South, urbanization within the South and other regions, and, ultimately, the so-called Civil Rights Movement. The African American tradition of self-help found significant expression in the rise of the black women’s social clubs and the increasing prominence of Historically Black Colleges and Universities.Footnote 3
 The Civil Rights Movement of 1954–1965 and the Black Power Movement of 1965–1973 were eras of great progress for African Americans, even as they were also years when new challenges arose. Migration, urbanization, and sharp declines in the racial gap in the quantity and quality of education lead to a substantial reduction in the black-white wage gap during 1940–1980 (Smith and Welch 1989). By the early 1970s, African Americans 25–36 years of age had achieved nearly equal years of education with their white cohorts (Bernstein 1995). The dismantling of Jim Crow and the federal government’s second reconstruction of Southern society also made an exceptional contribution to reducing the racial wage gap (Donohoe and Heckman 1992). It should also be noted that 1945–1973 was a period of declining unemployment, stable prices, and rising real wages for all workers; hence, this sustained macroeconomic boom, combined with racially progressive public policies and self-help by African Americans, created an economic environment which fostered greater racial wage equality. An analysis of a sample of 1960 help wanted advertisements from selected major newspapers shows a remarkable pattern.Footnote 4 Prior to the Civil Rights Act of 1964, private for-profit competitive employers openly engaged in racial, gender, marital status, and age discrimination within their labor market practices. They had no fear of being penalized by either the competitive forces of the market or governmental agencies. Executive Order 11246 (September 24, 1965) required federal contractors to develop a written affirmative action plan. The plan did not force contractors to hire, train, or promote anyone. Rather, the plan requirements were designed to help the contractor take the necessary steps to remove impediments (if any) to the hiring, training, and promotion of women and racial and ethnic minorities by the contractor. Affirmative action included aggressive steps in outreach, recruitment, training, and other activities that would help women and racial and ethnic minorities compete on a level playing field. Over time, the concept of affirmative action spread from federal contractors to other private companies, state agencies, and universities. Yet, by 1978 this modest effort to breakdown disparity was under full assault (Katznelson 2005). That year, the Supreme Court declared that the University of California—Davis Medical School’s affirmative action plan had discriminated against Alan Bakke, a white male applicant. Thereafter, a series of court challenges have considerably reduced the nature, scope, and effectiveness of affirmative action. The stagnation in racial equality during the mid-1970s and 1980s is also correlated with changes in federal anti-disparity policy (Anderson 1996; Leonard 1996; Rodgers and Spriggs 1996). According to Leonard (1990:105), “affirmative action under the contract compliance program virtually ceased to exist in all but name after 1980s.” He provides strong evidence that the federal government gutted the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Program, the enforcement vehicle for affirmative action within the federal government. Leonard writes that by the mid-1980s affirmative action “no longer aided blacks.” Five major recessions have occurred since the demise of Jim Crow: 1974–1975, 1981–1982, 1990–1991, 2000–2001, and the Great Recession of December 2007–2009. These recessions have varied by length and by intensity, but each has had an impact on racial disparity. The National Bureau of Economic Research reports that there was a 16-month inflationary recession from November 1973 to March 1975.Footnote 5 There was a 6-month recession from January 1980 to July 1980, with a one-year recovery from July 1980 to July 1981. The next major recession occurred over the 16 months of July 1981–November 1982. The one-year “recovery” of 1980–81—the shortest recovery of the post World War II era—was only a brief respite in a long period of stagnation from December 31, 1979 to December 31, 1982. A third major recession occurred from July 1990 to March 1991. A 10-year expansion followed this recession. The penultimate recession lasted just 8 months, starting in March 2001 and reaching its trough in November 2001. The Great Recession started December 2007 and does not yet have an official ending date, making it the nation’s most severe recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Prior to 1991, the average recession lasted just 11 months while the average boom lasted 43 months. Excluding the 1973–1975, 1981–1982, 2007–2009 recessions, the average recession lasted just 9 months. Hence, the recessions of 1974–1975, 1980–1982, and 2007–2009 represent periods of exceptional adjustments in the American economy. The Federal Reserve System (FED) reacted to the stagflation of 1974–1975 and the following years of inflation by making a fundamental change in macroeconomic policy, viz., it became much more concerned with fighting inflation than fighting unemployment. Carpenter and Rodgers (2005) show that the African American employment-population ratio is more sensitive to restrictive monetary policy than the white employment-population. This is so because interest rate increases by the FED increase African American unemployment (especially among teenage African Americans) more so than white unemployment. In particular, they find that African Americans are not necessarily disproportionately employed in interest rate sensitive industries, but that African Americans have a relatively more difficult time finding employment during recessions. Importantly, they also find that contractionary monetary policy does not decrease labor force participation rates; hence, the fall in employment-population is due entirely to the rise in unemployment.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Inter-group Disparities in the Distributional Analysis of Human Development: Concepts, Measurement, and Illustrative Applications

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: An Empirical Analysis of the Demand for Imports in Three CARICOM Member Countries: An Application of the Bounds Test for Cointegration
Intro: In studying the behavior of the demand for imports in Guyana (GY), Jamaica (JA), and Trinidad and Tobago (TT),Footnote 1 Gafar (1995) utilized a traditional import demand model.Footnote 2 In that model, the dependent variable was the volume of imports and the explanatory variables were the level of real income and the price for imported goods relative to the price for domestic goods. When that model was estimated by ordinary least squares (OLS), the estimated income elasticity for each of the three countries was found to be positive and statistically significant with values ranging from 1.29 to 2.29. The estimated price elasticity for each country was also negative and statistically significant with values ranging from −0.26 to −0.34. Given that no test was conducted to determine if the data used in estimating the import demand equation were stationary, the warning expressed by Granger and Newbold (1974) about spurious regressions must not be overlooked. Since, if the data for testing the model are nonstationary, the results on the statistical significance of the various regressions that are reported in the Gafar study may be misleading. In order to ascertain if the data have this statistical property, many empirical studies now routinely conduct unit root and cointegration tests on the numbers used to evaluate the empirical model. Indeed, for recent studies on the import demand function, these new econometric methods are seen to have been applied by Matsubayashi and Hamori (2003), Razafimahefa and Hamori (2005), and Harb (2005), among others. Apart from the stationarity issue, a re-assessment of the determinants of aggregate imports for GY, JA, and TT is also warranted on the grounds that a number of recently conducted studies on import demand have replaced the single real income variable in the import demand equation with the different components that underlie the total expenditure on final goods and services in the macro economy (see Giovannetti 1989; Abbott and Seddighi 1996; Mohammed and Tang 2000; Min et al. 2002; Tang 2003; Narayan and Narayan 2005; Oteng-Abayie and Frimpong 2008). This shift from the real income variable to the components of total expenditure is justified if the import contents for the different components of total expenditure are not the same. Indeed, as Abbott and Seddighi have pointed-out, there could be aggregation bias if the single aggregate expenditure variable is used in the import demand function when the various components of total expenditure exert a different impact on imports. Based on the traditional and the disaggregated expenditure models of import demand, there is a twofold purpose to this paper. The first is to provide new estimates of the income and price elasticities of import demand by means of the bounds test for cointegration. The second is to provide estimates of the consumption, investment, and export elasticities of import demand also based on the bounds test for cointegration. As explained by Pesaran et al. (2001), the bounds test is concerned with determining if the regressors in the model are purely I (0), I (1), or mutually integrated. A major advantage of this test is that once the computed Wald or F-statistic falls outside of the critical value bounds it is not necessary ‘to know the integration/ cointegration status of the underlying regressors. However, if the Wald or F-statistic falls inside these bounds, inference is inconclusive and knowledge of the order of the integration of the underlying variables is required before conclusive inferences can be made’ (Pesaran et al., p. 290). The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the bounds test as presented by Pesaran et al. is described. In Section 3, the empirical findings of the study are reported using the unrestricted error correction model and the bounds test for the traditional and disaggregated expenditure models of import demand. In Section 4, the concluding comments and policy implications are given.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Empowerment Zone in Boston, Massachusetts 2000–2009: Lessons Learned for Neighborhood Revitalization
Intro:
In 1994 President Bill Clinton signed the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 establishing what are known as empowerment zones.Footnote 1 The original legislation called for six empowerment zones in urban areas and another three in rural areas throughout the country. The purpose of empowerment zones was to encourage economic development strategies aimed at revitalizing distressed neighborhoods. Such strategies across the country would include four goals: to generate economic opportunities for residents living in the empowerment zones; to create sustainable community development; to build broad participation among community-based partners; and to generate a strategic vision for change in the community.Footnote 2
 Reviewing the history and impacts of empowerment zones remain important given current policy strategies and proposals for revitalizing urban areas. The unfolding Promise Neighborhoods initiative in the US Department of Education and the national administration’s Choice Neighborhoods initiative in the US Department of Housing and Urban Development are being presented as neighborhood-based strategies for improving living conditions in distressed urban areas.Footnote 3 Examination of empowerment zones as a strategy for neighborhood revitalization may have implications for how these new programs are modeled and implemented in urban areas. Within this context it is important to assess the impact of individual empowerment zone programs because as concluded by Rich and Stoker, “the empowerment zone initiatives was not a national program that was implemented in several different sites; it was a set of local programs that were sponsored by the same federal grants and made use of the same market-oriented tools.” Further, “our evidence shows that some of the local programs were effective (Rich and Stoker 2007).” In a follow-up article they write: “Our evaluation findings suggest that what happens locally is a vital concern for federal urban policy and also informative for local communities with responsibility for crafting and executing revitalization strategies (Rich and Stoker 2010).” Boston was selected as an Empowerment Zone (EZ) site in 1999 by HUD under the Tax Payer’s Relief Act of 1997. The 10 year empowerment zone designation (1999–2009) included authorization for provision of tax-exempt bonds and various kinds of tax credits up to $130 million.Footnote 4 This initiative included authorization of $10 million per year to advance objectives associated with economic opportunity and job creation; enhancing the health and well-being of residents; providing education and job readiness; and, community capacity building. Based on congressional legislation Boston’s empowerment zone (EZ) came to an end in December 2009.Footnote 5 Appendix A provides a time chart of major events and developments in the history of Boston’s EZ. Was this economic development initiative a success in Boston? And, how should success or failure be determined for this kind of strategy? What are the implications for civic leaders regarding neighborhood revitalization and the idea of community empowerment?

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Economic Determinants of the Number of Minority Farmers in the Southeast Region of the United States, 1969-1997
Intro:
One of the most interesting and important issues that many economists and other social scientists have raised is the continually decreasing number of minority farmers in the United States, as illustrated in Fig. 1. According to Brown and Larson (1977), the number of Black-operated farms reached a peak of 925,710 in 1920. By 1969, the number of Black-operated farms had dropped 90.6% to 87,393, compared with a drop of 64% for all farms in the South and 57.7% for all farms in the nation.
