As Keynes famously quipped, you could bury bank notes in bottles at the bottom of abandoned mines, fill the mines with trash, and then invite capitalists to dig them up (Keynes 1936, 129). All that mattered was that the stimulus be large enough to raise aggregate demand to the full employment level. The New Deal strategy is fully compatible with a Keynesian commitment to boosting aggregate demand. Nevertheless, it is important to understand that the strategy’s commitment to securing the economic and social human rights that recessions threaten is independent of that macroeconomic goal and provides a justification for the strategy irrespective of its macroeconomic effect. That said, Keynesian economists have good reason to embrace the New Deal strategy based solely on its advantages as a means of delivering a fiscal stimulus to an economy in recession. These advantages can be grouped under two headings. The first consists of enhancements to the anti-cyclical effect of the fiscal stimulus. The second consists of enhancements to the short-term job-creation effect of the fiscal stimulus. Using the New Deal strategy to deliver a fiscal stimulus will enhance its anti-cyclical effect in two ways. First, by providing immediate reemployment to laid-off workers, the New Deal strategy would provide a faster and more effective means of short-circuiting the negative spiral that does the most harm during a recession—the tendency for job losses to cause further job losses. No other means of delivering a fiscal stimulus to an economy can promise to reemploy unemployed workers as quickly and with as little disruption to their normal consumption expenditures as the New Deal strategy. Second, because most of the fiscal boost provided to the private sector by the New Deal strategy would result from a resumption of ordinary consumption spending by reemployed workers, it would tend to fill precisely the same gap in business income that the spread of unemployment during a recession causes. Businesses that suffered losses due to the depressing effect of unemployment on consumer demand would not have to wait for the benefits of a fiscal stimulus delivered somewhere else in the economy to trickle through to them. They would feel the effects of the stimulus almost immediately, and their healthier balance sheets would make it possible for them to participate both more quickly and more aggressively in a resumption of economic growth. Stimulus spending distributed in other ways is unlikely to be as well-positioned microeconomically to foster a resumption of economic growth; and even if the stimulus has been delivered to industries with a high growth potential, their expansion is not going to be capable of lifting the entire economy until the damage done to consumer-oriented businesses by the recession is repaired. There is only one caveat to this assessment of the enhanced anti-cyclical effect of a fiscal stimulus delivered via the New Deal strategy. The caveat is that the multiplier effect of stimulus spending delivered in this way would be somewhat smaller than that of some other forms of stimulus spending (Harvey 2011). The practical importance of that caveat pales to insignificance, however, in light of the other major advantage of the New Deal strategy as a means of delivering a fiscal stimulus—its short-term job creation effect. Simply stated, the New Deal strategy outperforms all other anti-recession measures as a means of creating jobs, including stimulus measures with a higher income multiplier than the New Deal strategy. The reason for this is that the front-loaded round of direct job-creation that kicks off the multiplier effect of the New Deal strategy adds far more to the overall job-creation effect of the strategy than is lost as result of its possibly diminished multiplier effect compared to some other types of stimulus spending (Ibid.). Table 1 illustrates this difference. Table 1 estimates both the direct and indirect job creation effects of a $100 billion fiscal stimulus delivered to the U.S. economy during the so-called Great Recession of 2008–09 using three different spending strategies. The first is a continuation of the so-called Bush-era tax cuts that were included in the compromise tax cut agreement negotiated between the Obama Administration and Republican leaders of Congress following the 2010 mid-term elections. The second strategy consists of an increase in Unemployment Insurance (UI) and Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP) benefit payments, two types of stimulus spending with among the highest income multipliers (Blinder and Zandi 2010). The job-creation effect of these three stimulus strategies are measured in several ways, since different measures of job creation are not necessarily proportionate to one another. What the table shows is that the estimated job creation effect of the New Deal’s direct job-creation strategy far exceeds that of the other two strategies. Indeed, the model on which these estimates are based suggests that if the New Deal strategy had been deployed in February 2009, the nation’s unemployment rate could have been reduced to its pre-recession level and kept there for as long as it took for the economy to recover for far less than the federal government actually has spent on fiscal stimulus measures. From this perspective, the problem with the federal government’s response to the Great Recession has not been that it spent too little, but that its spending has been very poorly allocated. The New Deal strategy constitutes not only a far more progressive response to recessions on social welfare and human rights grounds. It also constitutes a far more effective response on purely economic grounds.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Employment and Earnings: A Case Study of Urban Detroit
Intro:
Employment decentralization and racial housing segregation have been characteristic of U.S. industrial cities for decades. These problems continue to plague Detroit and a few other cities, but they seem to have eased for the nation’s cities overall. Stoll and Covington (2010) found a decline nationwide in job sprawl and in racial housing segregation between 1990 and 2000.Footnote 1 In contrast to Stoll and Covington’s findings at the national level, Detroit Michigan’s population faces increases in both job sprawl and residential segregation. Detroit was experiencing “rapid decentralization” in 2006 according to a Brookings Institution study (Kneebone 2009:12). The study listed Detroit first among 98 U.S. metropolitan areas in job sprawl in 2006, with 77.4% of jobs located more than 10 miles outside the city center (2009:8). Only 7.0% were located within 3 miles of the city’s core. According to the Census Bureau, between 1990 and 2009 the share of the population of Detroit City that is black rose from 75.6% to 77.2% as the population of the city fell from 1,027,974 to 916,133.Footnote 2
 Detroit’s unemployment rate, 22.6% in September 2010, was nearly twice that of the rest of Michigan (12.3%), according to Michigan.gov, the official state website, and the U.S Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS 2010).Footnote 3 BLS data shows that total non-farm industry employment in the Detroit metropolitan area fell 2.1% (compared to 0.2% growth in the U.S) between September 2009 and 2010. This continued a trend that started in 2005. Employment declined primarily in trade, transportation and utilities (3.1%), government (2.8%) and financial activities (4.7%). There were small increases in professional and business services (2.1%), education and health services (2%), manufacturing (0.1%) and leisure and hospitality (0.7%).Footnote 4 The next two sections, respectively provide an overview of worker and job characteristics for central city Detroit and regression analyses of wages for the Detroit metropolitan area. Census 2000 data is employed in both sections because it is the most recent data available, at the level of detail necessary.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Historical Amnesia: The Humphrey-Hawkins Act, Full Employment and Employment as a Right*
Intro: Though Wall Street was rescued by the federal government from a crisis that it helped to create, economist William Darity (2010) has noted that “it is stunning how cautious the response has been to the nation’s greatest economic crisis since the Great Depression of the 1930s.” The crisis is a disaster for tens of millions of American workers and their families. In January 2011, official unemployment averaged 9.0%--representing 13.9 million persons. However, persons working part time who would like full-time employment, as well as persons who want jobs but have not looked for work in the past 4 weeks, are not included by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the official figures. Including them, as the National Jobs for All Coalition (NJFAC) does monthly on its website (NJFAC), brings the figure to 18.0%–28.7 million people. While all groups have seen sharp rises in unemployment, there are wide disparities. For white workers the jobless rate was 8.0%--but for African Americans it was a depression level of 15.7% and for black 16–to–19 year olds it was an astronomical 45.4%. In addition, in 2009 (the latest year available) 16.3 million people were working year-round full time, yet earned less than the inadequate official poverty level for a family of four (NJFAC). Professor Darity (2010) laments “the failure to undertake or even to consider more daring and imaginative policies [than the stimulus of 2009] to produce a healthy and equitable economy.” And he proposes a “powerful transformative policy,” “a federal job guarantee that would insure that all persons willing to work would be able to obtain work” (see also, e.g., Harvey 1989 and 2000; Wray 1998). Darity (2010) also shows its economic feasibility, at a minimum annual salary of $20,000 (a mean of $40,000) plus $10,000 in benefits, to provide jobs for all of those currently jobless. He spells out the extensive advantages that would accrue both to the unemployed, to workers and to society, including addressing the nation’s vast unmet physical and human infrastructure needs, security for workers, improved health, elimination of working poverty and a chance for former prisoners to become useful members of society. Professor Darity’s idea and variants of it have deep roots (Nixon 1973) and some of these roots are part of 20th century US history. In this article I briefly explore some New Deal job creation efforts and President Franklin Roosevelt’s Economic Bill of Rights. The main focus is on two major attempts to secure full employment and the right to a job through legislation. In the 1940s, the ill-fated Full Employment Bill of 1945, failed to pass; the Employment Act of 1946, passed, but did not have full employment as its goal. The second major attempt, in the 1970s, led to passage of the weak Humphrey-Hawkins Full Employment Act of 1978, which has been virtually ignored. In the article, I draw partly from my experience as a participant observer. In the 1970s, I was an academic economist and active participant in the struggle to attain strong full employment legislation in the United States. During that period, I wrote, consulted with many groups (mostly faith-based) provided testimony to Congress, and spoke extensively throughout the country on unemployment and the need for a federal government commitment to full employment. I am a co-founder and currently serve on the executive committee of the National Jobs for All Coalition (NJFAC), an organization that educates and advocates for a government policy of living-wage jobs for all who want to work.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Behavioral Pragmatism: President Obama’s Approach to Unemployment
Intro: The familiar cycle of partisan ups and downs, flipping congressional power between Democrats and Republicans, was widely expected to transform Washington politics during the 2010 mid-term elections. More than with previous mid-terms reversals such an outcome was expected to transform the ideological tone of policy debates as much as their partisan character. The results, with the loss of Democratic power in the House of Representatives, met the most pessimistic liberal expectations. Within weeks of the new Congress’ inauguration, however, liberal fears of a regressive agenda were matched by widespread anxiety over legislative stalemates and inertia. Yet, in the months that followed the real meaning of that inertia for domestic policy began to sink into the consciousness of the optimistic liberal voters. The White House would be seen as conceding to major conservative demands for federal restraint in terms of social welfare and employment policy while conceding to federal largess in terms of upper income tax policy. The prospective for Obama’s employment policy, whatever the congressional context, increasingly seemed to be understandably restrained in openness to federal intervention and yet pragmatically unconstrained in its willingness to go with the flow of the strongest private sector pressures. As a consequence, the balance between public and private sector prerogatives appeared to swayed between an unreflective moderation and a latent inclination toward extending federal authority. During the first years of his administration as President Obama as carried his campaign theme of “Yes, We can” into the policy-making arena, the biggest controversy formed around the general question of what could or could not be done, first, for failing banks and their financial networks and, second, for a dysfunctional healthcare system. Subsidiary questions of administrative competence, systemic capacity and national resources took center stage. In particular, conservatives questioned the competence of federal intervention in financial markets and its capacity for healthcare reform. Liberals questioned the availability of national resources expected to sink into private insurance corporations in substitute for a public initiative. Yet, both sets of critics may have missed the mark, the real point of fundamental conflict that underscored, though only imperceptibly, the controversy over these major federal initiatives. Analysts would do well to focus more the “we” and misunderstandings about whom it includes and rather than on what can or cannot be done. The legislative struggles of the Obama administration have shed more light on what it can or cannot get done than on the political and ideological composition of those influencing the decisions. It can be argued that the locus of compromise in the White House has moved from the ideological center of policy debate to the ideologically represented center of those who are influential in policy debates; the representatives, administrators, lobbyists and a few others who defined the limited circle of policy influence. The fairly rambling administrative search for an effective jobs program serves to illustrate the ambiguity and inconsistency in perspectives on the issue. When it comes to economic questions, in general, and employment policy, in particular, the national consensus about the composition of federal decision-makers is less solid than Americans are otherwise accustomed to believing. Who regulates, how and by what means, seems to emerge more from operational adaptation than from policy consensus. In particular, the further policy making moves into complex areas of employment, the more boundaries of public-private interdependence are obscured. However wide the ideological distance between positive and negative prognosticators of employment growth, the pragmatic center is where the White House preferences are likely to fall. This pragmatic center, it is important to recognize, may be far from the ideological center between public-private program alternatives. Instead, it is closer to the pressure center of partisan and interest-group forces that normally participate in fiscal policy-making. It is useful to take a closer look at the history of pragmatic center in order to understand current options.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Communists and the Fight for Jobs and Revolution
Intro: Winning the battle against unemployment would mean that there would be living wage jobs for all. Despite decades of struggle at both the legislative and street level, such an outcome has never been achieved in the capitalist world, suggesting that it is incompatible with capitalism. Even the most advanced social-democratic countries never achieved these goals (see, for example, Eurostat 2010), and to the extent that any progress was made, the Great Recession of 2007, maturing into a Great Stagnation, is further eroding those safety nets. If achieving jobs for all is a Sisyphean endeavor within capitalism, what additional measures of success could be used to assess progress in this struggle? The strongest efforts to overcome involuntary unemployment have historically been made by the political left, especially communist parties seeking to advance the interests and class consciousness of the working class. Their aggressive response to unemployment and its racist character flows from the communist goal of ending capitalist exploitation through a workers’ revolution and the establishment of socialism/communism. In this political framework, the battle against unemployment becomes both an end in itself and, dialectically, part of the process of developing class consciousness among the masses, leading the working class to become a “class-for-itself”, shedding bourgeois individualism, reformism, and racism, and wielding its collective power to create a new mode of production and a new egalitarian, collective society. One additional measure of success in the battle for jobs, then, would be progress made in raising anti-racist class consciousness as the struggle proceeds. Conscious class unity in the U.S. context requires addressing the historic differential exploitation of African American workers and the increasing differential exploitation of Latino workers. Anti-racism and multi-racial unity are core aspects of class consciousness. Communists in the U.S. have historically stressed the need for black leadership and multi-racial unity in the fight for working class interests, especially in the battle against unemployment (Harris, 2009, Naison, 1983; Kelley, 1990; Foster, 1954). The success of the bourgeoisie in preventing the formation of such consciousness through racism in economic, political and cultural spheres has held back the struggle against all forms of exploitation, a fact lamented by many writers (e.g., Spero & Harris 1931). Success in the jobs struggle then can be measured in two ways: the extent to which palliative measures are wrung from the system through class struggle (e.g., countercyclical public works programs, unemployment insurance, relief payments) and the extent to which anti-racist, internationalist class consciousness grows among the working class, creating a powerful force for advancing the long-term interests of the global proletariat. In this paper, a review of the theory and early history of the fight against unemployment, especially in the U.S., is followed by an assessment of the relative success of two specific examples of communist-led job struggles according to the criteria noted above. The examples are the St. Petersburg Unemployed Council of 1906 and the Unemployed Councils of the early years of the Great Depression. Suggestions for the current struggle against unemployment are drawn from those experiences.

Title: Confronting the Jobs Crisis

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Development and Immigration: Experiences of Non-US Born Black Women
Intro: Gender relations in the US and globally are portrayed in the media as increasingly egalitarian. Indeed, anxiety over men’s economic status is on the rise. This is reflected in the suggestion that the global crisis that began in the 2008 led to a “mancession,” due to a more rapid rise in male than female unemployment early in the crisis in developed economies. The pronouncement that the end of gender inequality is upon us, however, is premature. Race/ethnicity and household structure are key factors influencing gender outcomes, contributing to a troubling degree of inequality among women. Racial wage and employment inequality among women persists unabated in the US and in other racially heterogeneous societies (such as South Africa and Brazil). Further, despite evidence of narrowing of wage gaps in developed economies and educational gaps in developing economies, we see continued and worsening economic conditions among single mothers. Women’s disproportionate responsibility for children can inhibit their ability to get and keep stable jobs. This is because employers see them as “flexible” workers more than, for example, white men. Single parents face diminished social protection as governments cut spending. Further, declining job prospects for men reduces child support payment to custodial parents, usually women.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Reflections on an Intellectual Partner: My Life with Linda Datcher Loury

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Subprime Mortgage Calamity and the African American Woman
Intro: Numerous media and scholarly reports have focused on the subprime mortgage crisis and the resultant global financial meltdown. Most of the literature notes unequivocally that discrimination in the mortgage market has been, and remains, race-based and that it has had a disproportionate negative effect on the African American population (Brown 2010; Goldstein and Urevick-Ackelsberg 2008; Leigh and Huff 2007; Phillips 2010; Rugh and Massey 2010). For instance, the Consumers Union analyzed Texas refinance loans and determined that those affected by subprime lending were overwhelmingly minority (80%) with race being the strongest indicator of who received a high-cost mortgage. After accounting for credit and neighborhood characteristics, Black borrowers were 3.9 times as likely to end up with a subprime refinance as non-Blacks (Consumers Union 2002b). Federal Reserve studies reveal that Blacks and Hispanics are more likely, and Asians, less likely, to receive a higher-priced loan even after controlling for borrower and loan characteristics (Avery et al. 2006). Income was found not to be a contributing factor in the disparity between Whites and Blacks with regard to subprime loans. In fact, in a report titled “Income is No Shield against Racial Differences in Lending” published in 2008, the higher the income level, the more likely an African American would get a subprime loan. The study revealed that middle- to upper-income (MUI) African Americans were more likely to receive high-cost loans than low- to moderate-income (LMI) African-Americans when compared to similarly situated Whites. Comparable results occurred in 2006 and 2009 studies. What may be interesting for this group is that, while LMI African-American borrowers were over three times as likely to receive a high-cost loan compared to LMI White borrowers in Durham; Greenville; and Wilmington, NC; MUI African-American borrowers in Greenville and Durham were over four times more likely to get high-cost loans than MUI White borrowers (National Community Reinvestment Coalition; The Opportunity Agenda; Poverty and Race Research Action Council 2006; National Community Reinvestment Coalition 2008; National Council of Negro Women and National Community Reinvestment Coalition 2009) Figs. 1 and 2. The Five Metro Areas where LMI African-Americans are Most Likely to Receive More High-Cost Loans Than LMI Whites. High-Cost Disparity Ratio is % African American High-Cost Loans /% White High Cost Loans. NCRC, 2008 The Five Metro Areas Where MUI African-Americans are Most Likely to Receive More High-Cost Loans Than MUI Whites. High-Cost Disparity Ratio is % African American High-Cost Loans /% White High Cost Loans. NCRC, 2008 Many people have explored what caused this crisis. Some have argued that it was caused by men who overwhelming dominate the financial landscape, which raises the question: what would have happened in the global marketplace if the financial institutions were run by women? (Langley 2009). This paper reports on the consequences of the subprime mortgage calamity and its impact on the African-American community and women—and more specifically how the crisis has impacted Black women in America.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Intersection and Accumulation of Racial and Gender Inequality: Black Women’s Wealth Trajectories
Intro: Despite our prosperity as a nation, empirical evidence shows an unparalleled degree of wealth inequality in the United States (Wolff 1995). Wealth is an especially important indicator of economic well-being, because, unlike income or educational attainment, this measure of economic status captures the consequences of the accumulation of assets across and within generations. Wealth can be used to pay for college, put a down payment on a home, or start a business—keys to upward socioeconomic mobility. Moreover, it cushions the economic impact of unexpected costs associated with job loss, medical expenses and divorce. Wealth also has consequences for future generations because it can be passed on in the form of inter vivos transfers and inheritances. Existing research shows that there are large race and gender disparities in wealth, with blacks possessing less wealth than whites (Oliver and Shapiro 1995) and women having less wealth than men (Chang 2010a). Nevertheless, studies on wealth have tended to treat race and gender as separate dimensions, ignoring the ways that race and gender may intersect to shape the accrual of economic resources. An intersectional approach to understanding how race and gender produce wealth trajectories would consider the unique position of individuals who must navigate both race and gender statuses simultaneously. The central aim of this study is to investigate how much wealth black women possess in middle and late life. An intersectional lens may be especially important for understanding outcomes for black women, who occupy two lower statuses (i.e., “black” and “woman”) in American society (see e.g., Shields 2008). In terms of wealth accumulation, black women encounter barriers to opportunities due to both racism and sexism, which may even emanate “from members of their own social groups—they may experience sexism from within the black community and racism from other women…” (Settles 2006, p. 590). Furthermore, taking into account the aging process, the number and proportion of black older adults is projected to increase over the next two decades (He et al. 2005). Although it is well-documented that black women have longer life expectancies than their male counterparts (Kochanek et al. 2005), less is known about how the numerous race and gender barriers to building wealth faced by black women affect them in this stage of the life course. That is, little is known about black women’s wealth trajectories in later life. An intersectionality perspective would suggest that racial and gender disadvantages are likely to exacerbate each other and compound over time, and consequently that black women are likely to experience substantial economic insecurity, accumulating little wealth over the life course. Wealth holdings are especially important among older black women given their economic insecurity over the life course (Brown and Warner 2008; Christie-Mizell et al. 2007), limited employment opportunities, and the increasing likelihood of health limitations as they age (Warner and Brown 2011). The life cycle hypothesis (LCH)—the dominant economic paradigm for understanding savings and consumption behavior—posits that rational actors should accumulate wealth until they retire, whereupon they begin decumulating wealth, such that average wealth levels will increase until around retirement age, after which they decline (Modigliani and Brumberg 1954; Modigliani 1986). Implicit in LCH is the untenable assumption that individuals are able to achieve economic success without the constraints of artificial barriers such as institutional racism and sexism. However, well-documented discrimination on the basis of both race and gender faced by black women (Darity and Mason 1998) makes the LCH unlikely to be adequate for explaining their wealth trajectories. Therefore, this study utilizes an intersectionality approach and panel data from the Health and Retirement Study to investigate black women’s wealth trajectories (net worth and net financial assets) between ages 51 and 73. Black women are hypothesized to have extremely modest wealth holdings throughout middle and late life. Below are brief reviews of the literature on racial and gender inequality in wealth and explanations for the wealth gaps, followed by a discussion of how race and gender disadvantages are hypothesized to shape black women’s wealth trajectories. Next, the data and methods utilized are discussed, followed by a description of analysis results. Finally, the conclusion section contextualizes the findings and discusses future directions for research as well as policy prescriptions.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Informal Child Support Contributions in Black Female-Headed Families

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: On (Not) Closing the Gaps: The Evolution of National and Regional Unemployment Rates by Race and Ethnicity
Intro: The U.S. economy is characterized by persistent differentials in unemployment rates by race and Hispanic origin. Almost four decades ago, Leigh and Rawlins (1973) noted that “the ratio of the unemployment rate of black workers to that of whites has remained strikingly stable near 2 to 1 during the postwar period.” Since then the ratio remained well above 2.0 before finally declining in 2008 to 1.94 and further to 1.83 in 2010. The black/white disparity persists despite the near-doubling in completion rates of high school and college for blacks relative to whites since the early 1960s, and the passage since that time of a considerable amount of legislation aimed at ending discrimination in the workplace. Smaller but still substantial gaps exist historically between the rates of unemployment for Hispanics and whites, though as we show below, the latter gap has narrowed considerably. Are these gaps converging at all in the long run? Are they the same in different regions of the country, where the proportions of minority populations differ? This paper will address these questions by conducting time series tests on unemployment rates for whites, blacks, and Hispanics and on the ratios of black/white and Hispanic/white rates nationally and across the four regions of the U.S.: Northeast, Midwest, South, and West. The experiences of these groups are very different over time and across space. Over the past 40 years, for example, white unemployment on an annual basis has only briefly exceeded 10%, during 1982–1983, and then only in the Midwest. By contrast, black unemployment in the Midwest has been more than 10% for all but 6 years in the same period. In another example, Hispanic unemployment rates have often matched and even exceeded rates for blacks in the Northeast and West, but have remained well below black rates in the Midwest and South. Such disparities in outcomes call into question the concept of the unemployment rate, whether nationally or for a specific group or region. Simple calculations like those above are enough to show that historical averages are different across groups and regions, but determining the degree of persistence of these differences requires a deeper analysis. At the extreme, rates for one or more groups may be non-stationary, or integrated of order one, implying differences may well diverge. Even when series are stationary, different subgroups may converge to different levels, so that gaps may persist over the long run. The basic hypotheses to be tested are three: That unemployment rates converge to stationary means: rates may fluctuate, but eventually converge to levels that are, for given demographic groups and given regions, constant over time. Even in periods of strong economic growth, some percentage of the population, amounting to millions of workers, are unemployed; that these percentages differ across demographic groups is well-documented and the subject of a large literature, as briefly summarized in Previous research section. If confirmed, this hypothesis implies that ratios between demographic groups and across regions are likewise constant over time. That unemployment rates converge to means that are subject to occasional shifts, or “structural breaks.” Conditions in labor markets are subject to change: for example, better information, fewer rigidities, and more flexible regulations could lead to declines in frictional unemployment. On the reverse side, greatly enhanced worker protections and increasingly generous unemployment benefits likely contributed to significant increases in many European unemployment rates since the oil crises of the early 1970s. Shifting means describe moving targets for adjustments to transitory shocks and could imply a narrowing of the gaps if, for example, educational differences between groups were to narrow. That unemployment rates diverge; that is to say, that rates are the sums of random shocks, so that any new shock has a permanent effect. Blanchard and Summers (1986), noting relatively high rates of European unemployment and stable, not falling inflation rates, attributed persistent unemployment to groups of “insiders” and “outsiders”: the former the remaining employed, who wish to preserve their relatively privileged status; the latter the unemployed, who lack the power or influence to get their jobs back. An alternative version of this story is that being detached from the labor market for a length of time makes the unemployed undesirable to employers, as skills erode or become obsolete in a dynamic environment. The term “hysteresis,” denoting a system with memory, exhibiting path-dependence, describes unemployment that arises from being unemployed. Gaps between groups will be stable provided only that the series are cointegrated; that is, that their difference is stationary. In the language of time series analysis, Hypothesis 1 is characterized by stationarity; Hypothesis 2 by stationarity with structural breaks; and Hypothesis 3 by non-stationarity. The techniques to be employed are straightforward applications of the Kwiatkowski, Phillips, Schmidt, and Shin (1992, hereinafter KPSS) test with the null hypothesis of stationarity, generalized to accommodate structural breaks (Hypotheses 1 & 2); and confirmatory analysis using augmented Dickey-Fuller (ADF) tests, with the null of non-stationarity, again accommodating the possibility of structural breaks (Hypothesis 3). These tests will provide, in addition to confirmation of stationarity, evidence of the evolution of the gaps between demographic groups and regions. The stylized facts so described provide a record to policy makers of the progress (or lack of it) in ensuring that no group suffers disproportionately in response to economic distress. The plan of the paper is as follows. Previous research section provides a brief review of previous literature. Description of the data and methodology section describes the data and lays out the empirical approach; Results of stationarity tests on unemployment rates section conducts stationarity tests on unemployment levels; Results of stationarity tests on employment ratios section conducts stationarity tests on unemployment ratios; Discussion section provides some additional discussion, and Conclusion section concludes.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Role of Race and Birth Place in Welfare Usage among Comparable Women: Evidence from the U.S.
Intro:
With the steadfast calls by congress-dominated Republicans to downsize major federally-funded programs, there are concerns that some welfare programs might be at risk of being cut. Given many more welfare recipients are women versus men, an analysis focused on women’s preference or inclination for welfare usage is useful. In the early 90s there were several studies that suggested abuse of the welfare system. In reaction to these findings and public perception that individuals, specifically immigrants and minorities, were abusing the U.S. welfare system, Congress decided to tighten the grips by passing the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act (PRWORA) in 1996. The legislation ended welfare as an entitlement program, restricted the eligibility of immigrants to various programs, and provided stricter conditions for eligibility for Americans. Post welfare reform, the share of the population on welfare shrunk considerably as many past welfare recipients were forced to seek jobs (Greenwell et al. 1998). However, recent studies suggest significant negative effects of welfare reform on the poor, especially poor women (Carnochan et al. 2005). They note that the vast majority of these individuals are still living below the poverty line and thus at risk of going back into the system. Though there is evidence in the literature that immigrants and minority racial groups use welfare more than citizens and Whites respectively (Borjas 1994, 1999; Borjas and Hilton 1996; Blau 1984; Hansen and Lofstrom 2003), the relevant question to ask is if immigrants or minorities have an inclination for welfare in comparison to comparable Whites. This is because a higher use of welfare by one group over the other may just reflect the differences in income or employability across these groups. A priori there is no reason to expect differential inclination for welfare across race. This is important because welfare eligibility is determined on the basis of needs; hence usage should be driven by similar criteria. However, given past research that suggests a public perception of preference for welfare for most minorities and immigrants, and the fact that some attribute poverty and welfare dependency of welfare recipients to their own lack of drive and attitude towards employment (Gilens 1999; Davis and Hagen 1996; Hunt 1996; Smith and Stone 1989; Greenwell et al. 1998), it becomes useful to investigate if an inclination for welfare exists for women from certain birthplaces or race/ethnicity. Although the existing literature on welfare programs has widely discussed the impact of the reform on poverty, marriage and other socioeconomic indicators,Footnote 1 it has, however, failed to discuss if there is racial preference in its usage—despite widespread public perception (Kellstedt 2003). Only a few papers have focused on preference for welfare usage across groups in the U.S. For example, Oyelere and Oyolola (2011) investigate differences in welfare by birthplace and citizenship status. We follow along these lines in our analysis of women’s welfare usage. Our two main questions of interest are: (a) Is there any racial/ethnic differences in welfare usage among comparable women? (b) Does experience/exposure as captured by birthplace affect welfare usage among comparable women? By comparable women, we are referring to women who should have similar levels of welfare usage given their characteristics. The characteristics we are referring to here are the factors that traditionally explain welfare usage. Our initial results suggest that race matters for welfare usage. However, this result is not robust and through further investigation we show that though some specific subgroups of women seem more inclined to use welfare in comparison to comparable White women, there is no evidence of differences in inclination for welfare use based on race. We also find that for most comparable women, birthplace does not matter for welfare usage. The only exception being women from U.S. territories. We find that these women are more likely to use welfare than comparable White women born in the U.S.Footnote 2
 This paper contributes to the literature by highlighting that among comparable women, there is no inclination for welfare usage based on race. Second, among comparable U.S. born and immigrant women, there is no difference in welfare use. This finding is important given evidence that the urge to pass welfare reform in 1996 was driven in part by a sense that immigrants and minorities had a preference for welfare use or were the face of welfare. (see Kellstedt 2003 and Martin Gilens 2003). Although the issue of race was rarely explicit, in the pre reform debates, Soss and Schram (2006) noted that arguments tended to carry a racial underpinning because so many Americans identified welfare recipients as poor black women or immigrants. The remainder of the paper is as follows. In “Data” we highlight the data and provide some descriptive statistics. In “Empirical strategy” we outline our empirical strategy and in “Results” we present our results. We conclude in the last section.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Impact of Macroeconomic Fluctuations on the Likelihood of African American Female Homeownership
Intro: In addition to being an integral part of the American dream (Leigh and Huff 2007a,b), research has consistently demonstrated that homeownership is an acceptable indicator of social integration and economic well being. Homeownership, being a primary component of household wealth, confers benefits to the homeowner not just in terms of the value of home equity itself, but also the tax benefits and inflation protection associated with acquiring a property (Kain and Quigley 1975). Along with the private economic benefits, there is recent evidence that homeownership may have a positive effect on the owner’s behavior and on the children of homeowner (DiPasquale and Glaeser 1999). Additionally, a homeowner’s neighborhood choice has been found to create positive neighborhood externalities (Estrada 2005). The prevalence of homeownership however, is not universal. Across different demographic groups and even within different regions, homeownership rates vary widely. Many of these demographic inconsistencies are longstanding, resulting in significant differences in access to the social benefits of homeownership from community to community (Sykes 2005). For instance, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (n.d.) reported that despite increases in housing sales there were differences in homeownership rates for households of different ethnicities. Specifically, from the first quarter in 2007 to the first quarter in 2010 the African American homeownership rate dropped from 48% to 45.6% (2.4% decrease), while whites homeownership dropped by 0.8% from 75.3% to 74.5% (Jourdain-Earl 2011). In essence, African Americans are three times more likely than whites to lose their homes. While there are a number of demographic and socioeconomic factors that have been identified as determinants of homeownership, research demonstrates that race differences in homeownership rates persist even after accounting for life-cycle, resource, preferences, and regional differences across groups (Myers and Chung 1996 and Alba and Logan 1992). For example, Leigh and Huff (2007a, b) reported that the homeownership gap between the lowest income blacks and lowest income whites is the greatest gap between black and white homeowners at any income level and this gap has increased from 22% to 25.8% between 1970 and 2001. Because neighborhood quality, including schools, may have disproportionate effects on children, racial gaps in homeownership and home values may tend to perpetuate themselves and to reinforce gaps in other social outcomes such as income, employment, and criminal behavior. Past studies used the various twentieth century Integrated Public Use Microdata (IPUMS) to study the long-run evolution of racial differences in homeownership and housing values among male household heads. However, the proportion of black households headed by females has increased over time relative to the proportion of whites. Consequently research should be expanded to include female households to avoid giving a misleading portrait of racial change over time. In addition to the paucity of studies that examine the effect homeownership inequality among women. William Darity (2005) challenges economists to develop and / or adopt a theoretical framework to understand the persistence of ethnic and racial inequalities of well-being, income, and wealth. To this end, this study seeks to examine the impact that cyclical fluctuations in the economy have on the likelihood of homeownership for black and white women.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Sugar and Spice and Everything Nice? Teacher Perceptions of Black Girls in the Classroom
Intro: In Margaret Simms and Julianne Malveaux’s influential volume Slipping through the Cracks, Margaret Wilkerson (1986), Lynn Burbridge (1986) and Harriett Harper (1986) sounded the alarm with regard to continuing disparities in black women’s educational attainment and on-the-job training. Twenty-five years later, there is still cause for concern. Diette (this issue) demonstrates that black female students still are less likely to take advanced math courses than their white counterparts and Campbell (this issue) sheds light on the mechanisms behind the differences in advanced course taking by exploring the relationship between the characteristics and behaviors of black female students and the probability of their being recommended for advanced courses. This paper complements the work of Diette and Campbell by examining the ways in which teacher perceptions of student behavior relate to their likelihood of recommending students for advanced courses. Teachers often make subjective judgments about student behavior, and these behavior perceptions may influence their decisions to recommend those students to advanced or remedial courses or instructional ability groups (Condron 2007; Hughes et al. 2005). There is evidence that being placed in a low-level instructional group can have negative repercussions for student academic performance not only in a student’s current grade, but throughout the remainder of their academic trajectory as students who start in low level groups are less likely to take the advanced courses required for admission in to selective universities (Darity and Jolla 2009; Dauber et al. 1996; Eder 1981; Lleras and Rangel 2009; Oakes 2005). For this reason, it is important to have a better understanding of the degree to which teacher perceptions of student behavior vary across student racial background categories. In this paper I pay specific attention to teacher perceptions of black female students by using a nationally representative sample of eighth grade students and their teachers to compare the perceptions that teachers hold for black females with the perceptions that teachers hold for female students from other racial backgrounds in the areas of attentiveness and disruptiveness. I control for a host of other variables that might influence teacher perceptions such as student socioeconomic status, student test scores, classroom racial composition, and school racial and socioeconomic composition. I extend the analysis by estimating the relationship between teacher subjective perceptions and the likelihood of that teacher recommending a student for honors classes. I find that black female students are perceived as less attentive and more disruptive than their white, Hispanic, and Asian counterparts. The differences in perceptions of attentiveness but not disruptiveness are mitigated after controlling for academic performance and socioeconomic status. Further, perceptions of attentiveness are significantly related to the probability that a teacher recommends a student for honors courses. This can have important implications for the academic trajectory of black girls.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Whiter the Better? Racial Composition and Access to School Resources for Black Students
Intro: Rigorous courses are an important resource, distributed within schools, that merit attention as a central determinant of student achievement and future outcomes (Cook and Evans 2000; Rose and Betts 2004). Yet, black students are less likely to be enrolled in advanced courses (ex. Darity et al. 2001; Klopfenstein 2005) and specifically Algebra 1 (Riley 1997). Some researchers and policymakers have put the primary focus for improving opportunities and outcomes for black students on increased access to white students (ex. Orfield and Lee 2005). This view is supported by research that suggests that black students are negatively affected by attending schools with higher concentrations of black students (ex. Hanushek et al. 2009; Grogger 1996). Other research questions whether increases in exposure to white students improve outcomes for black students (ex. Darity 2001; Diette et al. 2011; Kelly 2009). This study examines the relationship between the disparity in access to Algebra 1 in middle school and school characteristics in North Carolina. Of particular concern is investigating the relationship between access and the percentage of white students in a school. Following previous work, the study investigates potential nonlinear effects of racial composition. The results of this study suggest that: (1) black students are underrepresented in Algebra 1 in essentially all middle schools; (2) the largest disparities in enrollment occur in schools that are highly integrated while the disparities are reduced in schools with either large majority white or large majority non-white populations; (3) schools with a larger share of white teachers have larger disparities in enrollment between black students and white students; (4) the disparity in enrollment between black female students and white females students appears to be more responsive to changes in racial composition than the disparity for males. The paper proceeds as follows. Section 2 provides a brief survey of related literature. Section 3 discusses the data and the descriptive statistics. Section 4 explains the empirical strategy and Section 5 reports the results of the study. Section 6 concludes.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Co-Morbidity and Other Complexities Affecting Black Women’s Health
Intro: When what we now know as HIV/AIDS was first diagnosed in the early 80s, it was called 4-H disease, because it was primarily found among Haitians, homosexuals, hemophiliacs and injection drug (heroin) users (Gallo 2006). Over time HIV and AIDS came to be more solidly associated with gay, white men. But a look at the data shows that the rates of HIV infection are rising at alarming and disproportionate rates among black women. According to the Centers for Disease Control, the rate of new infection is almost 15 times as high among black women as that of white women. And African Americans are disproportionately affected by HIV/AIDS at every stage of the disease—from diagnosis to death rate. Some research shows that HIV/AIDS related illness is now the leading cause of death among black women ages 25–34 (U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services 2010). While the notion has been that certain women were at risk—women with multiple partners, women partnered with incarcerated men or men who sleep with men—HIV infection rates are also high among Black women outside these risk groups. For example, Michelle Linster’s research addresses the rise in the HIV rate among black women over the age of 50 (Linster 2011). According to the CDC, HIV/AIDS rates were 12 times as high among African Americans over age 50 compared with whites (Dept. of Health and Human Services 2008). Why are older women at risk? Some experts believe this population of women do not see themselves as “at risk” so they may not be as proactive about being tested, checking their partners’ status or taking measures to protect themselves. Stigma and denial are contributing factors as well, according to the CDC (Dept. of Health and Human Services 2008). Stigma is so acute in the Black community that some people would rather not to know their HIV status than to admit to having it. If there is good news it is that, over the past three decades, treatments have become more effective in prolonging the lives of people living with AIDS (PLWA) (Dept. of Health and Human Services 2008). And there is continued effort to address the infection rates, access to care and HIV-related health disparities—from the federal level to the grassroots.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Beyond Anecdotes: A Quantitative Examination of Black Women in Academe

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Wealth Affirming Policies for Women of Color

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Bi-Polar: College Education and Loans to Small Businesses Headed by Black Females
Intro: This section describes the data of the 1998 and 2003 Surveys of Small Business Finance as it relates to college education and BFHB and NFHB relative loan repayment ability. Both surveys oversampled minority-owned firms but provided weights to be nationally representative. The 1998 survey was collected in 1999 and 2000 and provided information on 1998. The 2003 survey was collected in 2004 and 2005 and provided information for 2003. There were 2,256,175 NFHFs in the 2003 survey, of which 681,496 (30.2 %) applied for a loan; and 1,400,932 NFHFs in the 1998 survey, of which 302,071 (21.6 %) applied for a loan. In the 2003 survey there were 121,062 BFHFs, 42,406 (35 %) of which applied for a loan, and in the 1998 survey there were 79,999 BFHFs, 15,024 (18.8 %) of which applied for a loan. From 1998 to 2003 both NFHFs and BFHFs had a significant increase in their application rate but NFHFs had an significant increase in there average approval rate, from 71.4 % to 87 %, while BFHF’s experienced only a minor increase in their approval rate from 35 % to 38 %. Neither the difference in the approval rates nor the difference in the change in approval rates is evidence of discrimination in credit markets between BFHFs and NFHFs across the two periods. The weakest evidence of discrimination requires that firms of similar creditworthiness have different loan approval rates due to their race. The data shows that on average BFHFs and NFHFs have different characteristics that could drive the two groups diverging approval rates. Both the 1998 and 2003 SSBF data show that on the average BFHFs and NFHFs differ substantially in both willingness-to-pay and ability-to-pay. Table 1 presents weighted-sample means for measures of credit-worthiness and other characteristics of BFHFs and NFHFs in 1998 and 2003. In 1998 BFHFs were on average rated riskier by Dunn and Bradstreet’s credit score, an industry measure of willingness to pay. They were more likely to have demonstrated a firm or owner delinquency, were smaller, younger, had less cash, and were less likely to have a college-educated owner. In 2003 BFHFs were still on average riskier but now the selected sample is larger, older, with more cash on hand, higher profit to liability ratios, and higher educational attainment which suggest a higher ability-to-pay. Another interesting thing to note when comparing the 1998 and 2003 sample is that, in 1998 NFHFs and BFHFs were equally divided between operating in competitive and non-competitive areas as indicated by the firms Herfindahl index while in 2003 BFHFs were more likely to operate in a concentrated market than NFHFs. Since the average characteristics of BFHFs and NFHFs are so different differences in average approval rates do not imply discrimination. The differences in average characteristics do provide insight as to why members of the two groups may be illegally treated with different standards; as no one expects an apple’s crispness from a lemon. The next section delineates the evidence and shows that controlling for the BFHFs relative lack of credit worthiness, high application rates, high presence in concentrated markets, etc., cannot account for their significantly lower approval rates. As such, this paper presents strong evidence of discrimination against BFHFs in the market for small business loans.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Plight of African American Women: Employed and Unemployed
Intro: Women’s participation in the labor force has grown over the past centuries. Today, women constitute almost half of the payroll employment and their parity in pay compared to men has grown to 80 % (U.S. Congress Joint Economic Committee 2010). Changes are taking place for greater parity in pay but at a slow pace. Affirmative Action and Equal Employment Opportunity laws from the 1950s and 1960s have helped mitigate some the unfairness, but, alas, it still remains. These laws appeared to reduce the racial and gender disparities in the beginning but by the 1980s the disparities grew (Darity and Mason 1998), particularly for black women (Newsome and Nii-AmooDoDoo 2002; Pettit and Ewert 2009). Employment patterns as well as wages declined (Newsome and Nii-AmooDoDoo 2002) while no new policy was implemented to improve social or economic status of black women to counteract growing disparities. African American women showed gains of human capital and from what traditional economics explains, they should have shown gains in access to jobs but that was not the case (Newsome and Nii-AmooDoDoo 2002). As the need for family financial security increases women have joined the labor market even while juggling the care of their children. Some of these women are single with children noting that the 2000 Census indicates that about 25 % of households are single parents raising their families, which is an increase, however small, since 1990. Black families have even much higher rates of single parent households (Darity et al. 1998). There’s been over a 40 % increase in the numbers of women working over the last 25 years, but the percentages of full and part-time workers remain pretty constant(U.S. Department of Labor 2009, U.S. Congress Joint Economic Committee 2010). The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (2011) reported that 59 % of working-age women were in the labor force as of 2009, representing an increase of approximately 18 % since 1970. It is expected that there will be a 9 % increase by year 2018. The basic economic cost of unemployment for any group within the borders of the United States is foregone output. Under the rubrics of neoclassical economics, the circular flow expands when businesses can employ workers who then have the money to buy the outputs. It follows to have as many workers as possible employed so the demand for products and services not only continues, but grows. This model, also, gives no insight as to why discrimination in employment opportunities and wage rates continues to exit between black and white workers. If workers are paid by their marginal product then workers with the same skill who do the same work, should be paid the same amount. Workers who compete for a job will keep the wages no higher than the additional output or marginal product of the last worker. Firms on the other hand will compete for workers and thus keep wages no lower than the marginal product. In other words, wages then settle at the level that reflects marginal productivity. The problem, with this approach from a productivity side, is that a wage differential for white and black women still exits. Even the big picture of aggregate demand and aggregate supply give no explanation as to why unemployment for black women, at its lowest rate was still slightly above the highest rate for white women. During times of declining GDP and slower growth, finding ways to make sure that more people are working is important and yet that task remains undone. This investigation sheds light on the racial differences for Blacks and whites and then, in particular, with the female gender it underscore a divide that keeps growing even when the economy bounces back from a business cycle trough. The following data in Figs. 1 and 2 help to illustrate the disparities found in employment/unemployment for African Americans women. We round off our investigation by using Geographical Information Systems (GIS) to underscore the significance of the location of work. Umemployment Rates by Race and Gender, 1980-2010 Female Umemployment Rates by Race, 1980-2010

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Incredible Shrinking Black Woman: Implications of Health Policies

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: For Colored Girls? Factors that Influence Teacher Recommendations into Advanced Courses for Black Girls

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Explaining the 2004 Decrease in Minority Stock Ownership
Intro: The racial gap in wealth between minorities and Whites has been a subject of research for quite some time (Terrell, 1971; Smith, 1975; Blau & Graham, 1990; Wolff, 1998; Menchik and Jianakoplos, 1997; Altonji and Doraszelski 2005, 2001; Altonji et al. 2000). The explanations for this large and persistent gap in wealth typically focus on either, past inequity and the inheritances Whites receive because of it or present differences in saving and investing and their impact on wealth. The period between 2000 and 2004 is a source of discussion for the latter. Blacks and Hispanics had made tremendous strides in investing in the nineties, and early 2000’s to the point that participation rates of minorities and Whites were nearly identical in 2000 once education and income were accounted for (Hanna & Lindamood, 2008; Ariel-Schwab, 2007). However, by 2004 minorities had a much lower likelihood of being equity investors. In contrast, Whites were just as likely to be investors in 2004 as they were in 2000. This difference in minority participation is attributed to the drops in equity prices over that time period. The cause for this divergent behavior is unknown. Hanna & Lindamood (2008) examine the race-based differences in market participation using the Survey of Consumer Finances. They find that their model which includes risk tolerance and a host of demographic characteristics fails to explain the difference in stock ownership likelihood among the races. They suggest that these differences may be due to investor inexperience. This paper examines whether the racial differences in investor behavior in 2004 were due primarily to race or to differences in cognitive ability and investor experience. We use proxies for cognitive ability (IQ) and investor experience and discover that racial effects do not remain significant in predicting the likelihood of owning stock in 2004. We then examine racial effects on the amount of stock ownership in 2000 and 2004 and find that minority status does not impact stock and mutual fund holdings once we account for differences in cognitive ability and investor experience. However, there is a strong significantly positive effect of being White on the balance of stocks and mutual funds in 2000 and 2004. Finally we find that the tendency to divest from the market is a phenomenon independent of race. We conclude with discussion of how policy might improve the likelihood of more productive investment behavior among minorities.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Ethnoracial Differences in Early Union Experiences Among Young Adult Women

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Arrival Cohort, Assimilation, and the Earnings of Caribbean Women in the United States
Intro: Most subgroups of black immigrants from the Caribbean earn less than U.S.-born blacks (black natives) when they first arrive in the United States (Model 2008). However, these immigrants begin to close their initial earnings deficit as their tenure in the United States increases. This pattern of earnings assimilation results in greater unadjusted earnings for some subgroups of Caribbean immigrants, particularly those from the English-speaking Caribbean (Kalmijn 1996; Model 2008). Since Caribbean immigrants and black natives share the same phenotype, some scholars and policy makers argue that differences in work ethic, attitudes toward work, and work culture between Caribbean-born blacks and black natives produce labor market differences between the two groups (Glazer and Moynihan 1979; Sowell 1978). While research shows that unadjusted differences in labor market outcomes between Caribbean immigrants and black natives are partly the result of disparate labor market characteristics (Mason 2010; Model 2008), much of this literature has ignored the experiences of black Caribbean women, particularly those from the non-English-speaking Caribbean, as well as cohort of arrival variation in earnings among subgroups of Caribbean immigrants. Moreover, few papers have empirically tested the mechanisms—culture, employer preferences, or selective migration—that are argued to generate the earnings assimilation patterns observed for both male and female Caribbean immigrants (Model 2008; Sowell 1981; Waters 1999). This paper tests whether selective migration explains earnings differences between U.S.-born and Caribbean-born black women in the United States. Utilizing data on U.S.-born and Caribbean-born women from the 1980–2000 U.S. Censuses and the 2000–2007 American Community Surveys, I show that upon arrival in the United States, most arrival cohorts of Caribbean women have lower earnings than black native women (collectively). In models that attempt to account for the impact of selective migration on earnings by comparing the earnings of black immigrant women to U.S.-born black women who have moved across states since birth (black native movers), I show that the initial earnings gap between black native movers and Caribbean immigrants is significantly greater than the gap between all black natives and Caribbean immigrants. I also show that while arrival cohorts of women from the French-speaking (Haiti) and English-speaking Caribbean are projected to achieve earnings parity and eventually surpass the earnings of black natives (collectively), fewer cohorts from these regions are projected to surpass the earnings of black native movers. Additionally, a longer tenure of U.S. residence is required for these immigrants to surpass the earnings of black native movers. In summary, since the earnings profiles of black immigrants are more similar to the earnings profiles of black native movers than of black native non-movers, these results suggest that selective migration is an important determinant of nativity differences in earnings among black women in the United States. This paper also documents significant variation in earnings by cohort of arrival for each immigrant subgroup. The primary mechanisms that are purported to generate cultural differences among blacks are socialization in a majority black society or differences in slave histories (Sowell 1978; Waters 1999). Since neither the racial composition nor the slave histories of the major sending countries of black immigrants change over time, the documented variation in earnings by cohort of arrival suggests that cultural differences among blacks is not the primary mechanism that drives labor market differences among blacks. Moreover, it is unlikely that employers possess sufficient information to engage in disparate treatment of different arrival cohorts of immigrants. As a result, these empirical findings do not support the claim that employer preferences drive labor market differences between U.S.-born and Caribbean-born black women. While previous studies show this result for immigrants from the English-speaking Caribbean (Model 2008), this study shows that this trend also holds for women from Haiti and the Spanish-speaking Caribbean. The remainder of this paper will proceed as follows: Section II presents the background, Section III describes the data and methodology used in the study, Section IV presents results, and Section V offers conclusions.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Affordable Care Act and Its Potential to Improve the Health of African-American Women

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Black Female Earnings and Income Volatility
Intro: I use data from the 1973–2009 waves (1972–2008 calendar years) of the March Annual Social and Economic Study of the CPS. The unit of observation is an individual between the ages of 16 and 60. Given the rotating design of the CPS, a respondent is in sample for 4 months, out 8 months, and in another 4 months, making it possible to match approximately one-half of the sample from one March interview to the next. There was a major survey redesign both in the mid 1980s and mid 1990s so it is not possible to match across the 1985–1986 waves and the 1995–1996 waves. In addition, the line number, which is intended to uniquely identify a person in the household, was not recorded for the 1976–1978 survey years, and in 1977 there were changes in the format of matching variables. This yields an interrupted time series across 36 years with gaps in calendar years 1974–1975, 1975–1976, 1984–1985, and 1994–1995. See ZHB for a more detailed description of the match process and data generating procedure.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Special Editorial Note

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Invisible Woman: The Status of and Challenges Facing Black Women Preface
Intro:
This publication is a written record of the symposium, “The Invisible Woman: The Status of and Challenges Facing Black Women” that was co-sponsored by Bennett College for Women, The Research Network on Racial and Ethnic Inequality, Duke University and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). The symposium convened a new generation of scholars to expound on the research from the landmark book, Slipping through the Cracks: The Status of Black Women, which was published 25 years ago. Slipping through the Cracks elevated the experiences of Black women, a group of whose needs are often silenced and problems left unsolved. Dr. Julianne Malveaux, President of Bennett College, argues that the intersection of race and gender renders Black women invisible as policies that focus on Blacks and women typically focus on Black men and White women respectively. However, the intersection of race and gender both determine Black women’s economic, social, political and educational status and therefore, Black women warrant their own analysis. Footnote 1
 Over the past 25 years, there have been significant triumphs for Black women, including the prominent rise of the first Black first lady Michelle Obama—wife of the United State’s first Black president, Barack Obama. However, Black women continue to face significant challenges. In addition, Black women are shouldering more responsibilities due to what Dr. Malveaux calls the “third burden”—the consequences from the demonization and marginalization of Black men.Footnote 2 Therefore, any recommendations to improve the Black community must examine the status of Black women, specifically as it relates to single parent families, education and training, employment, health, wealth and development. The remainder of this introduction places readers in the context of Black women’s experiences by providing a brief overview of their status, with respect to the aforementioned areas, 25 years ago in relation to today. By the 1980’s, Black women headed over half of the Black households and out-of-wedlock births were the leading cause. Due to their limited economic and human resources, low-income single Black mothers struggled to cover household expenses (e.g., food, childcare, etc.) and over one-half of these families lived in poverty.Footnote 3 Legislative policies exacerbated the challenges facing these families. The federal government began curtailing financial assistance to needy families and over the past couple decades the government instituted other provisions severely weakening the social safety net. For instance, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) and the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) have not always lead to self-sufficiency nor provided substantial support and relief to single Black families. In fact, despite TANF moving many single mothers into jobs, poverty rates for Black single families remains obstinately high.Footnote 4
 Twenty-five years later, Black single parent families have increased significantly. Black women head over 60 % of Back households due to factors such as the shortage of men, delay in marriage, low marriage rates and the overall rise in cohabitation across the population.Footnote 5 Research will show that early cohabitation rates among Blacks remain low in comparison to White and Hispanic Americans. However, Black women account for the second highest rate of out-of-wedlock births relative to other racial groups.Footnote 6 Using the economic theory of fertility and marriage, we attempt to understand the growth of out-of-wedlock childbearing in the Black community. The theory suggest with men in short supply, low-income women are more likely to bear children outside of wedlock at their own cost, thereby driving down the costs of fatherhood. And the economic costs facing single Black mothers are tremendous. In 2008, the median income for single mother households was $30,129 with Black and Latino single mother households yielding even less at $25,011 and $23,866, respectively.Footnote 7 Limited jobs skills and education exacerbate these economic hardships as these limitations constrain low-income single Black mothers’ earning potential in the future. By the 1980’s, Black women’s education gains began to erode. Black women were graduating from high school at higher rates; however, their dropout rates were higher than white women and men. In addition, Black women’s matriculation rate in higher education institutions decreased. Black women represented less than 5 % of students enrolled in U.S. higher education institutions and even fewer Black women were represented at graduate and professional level schools. It is important to note that in absolute terms more Black women were earning degrees at all levels of higher education - a notable achievement. However, in relative terms, Black women’s degree attainment rate remained lower proportionately than white men and women. Several policy changes contributed to the erosion of Black women’s education gains, including the federal government’s reduction in financial assistance programs. In addition, the federal government distanced itself from education equity, which notably affected Black women and was demonstrated by the decline of Black women’s applications to graduate and professional schools.Footnote 8
 Twenty-five years later, Black women are making significant strides in both secondary and post secondary education; but they continue to face challenges. “No Child Left Behind” has not closed the racial achievement gap and resource disparities, such unequal access to quality classes, continue to exist in schools based on race and socioeconomic status.Footnote 9 We examine research that suggests that while Black girls participate in advanced placement courses more frequently than Black boys, Black girls lack access to these classes relative to Whites. In addition, research suggests that Black girls access to these classes is contingent upon their teacher’s perception of them, which tends to be less favorable relative to non-black students. These implications are significant as Black girls lack of access to college preparatory courses significantly affects their educational outcomes in secondary and post secondary institutions. Almost 30 % of Black women have college degrees and Black women earn over two-thirds of Bachelors, Masters and Doctoral degrees.Footnote 10 In addition, research suggests that Black women’s professional outcomes in academia are improving. In the 1980’s, Black women held fewer academic positions, were more likely relegated to junior ranks and received tenure in lower numbers.Footnote 11 However, 25 years later, research will demonstrate that Black female professors are facing fewer challenges than their predecessors. The employment status of Black women 25 years ago compared to today suggests that progress has been slow with marginal improvement. Historically, Black women have experienced unemployment and underemployment at disproportionately higher levels than their white counterparts have. During the 1980’s, the proportion of Black women in service occupations was substantially higher than that for white women.Footnote 12 In addition to occupational segmentation, Black women have lower lifetime earnings due to the racial wage gap. While Black women are more likely to be employed, they earn significantly less wages.Footnote 13 Presently Black women earn 64 cents for every dollar a white man earns.Footnote 14 While wage disparities exist across industries, we examine the nursing industry, where research suggests that non-union Black nurses are more likely to experience a wage penalty than non-union white nurses. In addition, Black women’s income vitality is examined as research suggests that Black women’s income volatility is rising; but that it is also influenced by education level and marital status. Over the past 25 years, legislation, such as the Equal Pay Act, were enacted to protect women and minorities from labor market discrimination. However, Black women’s benefits from these policies are mixed as Black women continue to experience discrimination in the labor market due to race and gender. To begin to remedy these disparities, President Obama passed the Lily Ledbetter Fair Pay Act to restore victims’ protection against wage discrimination based on age, religion, national origin, race, sex and disability. It is with cautious optimism that we hope this Act will significantly begin to improve the employment outcomes for Black women. From the cradle to the grave, Black women have some of the poorest health outcomes relative to other racial groups.Footnote 15 In the 1980’s, Black women were at a higher risk for both acute and long-term illnesses including obesity, diabetes and cancer.Footnote 16 A quarter of a century later, Black women’s mortality and morbidity rates remain higher than most other racial/ethnic groups. Black women and obesity receive considerable attention due to its prevalence in the Black community. Therefore, we examine the social determinant religiosity and its relationship to for obesity. We further broaden the conversation on Black women’s health by discussing another social determinant, mass imprisonment, and its impact on increasing Black women’s risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., hypertension, diabetes and obesity). In addition, we discuss preventing HIV/AIDS in older Black women as they are contracting the deadly disease at an alarming rate.Footnote 17
 Before the passage of the Affordable Care Act in 2011, decades passed since the passage of any major health care reform to address Black women’s health. Fortunately, the Affordable Care Act represents a major overhaul of the Nation’s healthcare system and it enables millions of Black women to have access to health care coverage.
