In addition, the bill includes provisions such as increasing black women’s access to preventive screenings such as mammograms, colonoscopies and immunizations, which are major steps to addressing the racial health disparities Black women face. We hope this legislation significantly improves the health outcomes of Black women because as Dr. Malveaux states “… maintaining the health of Black women is important to maintaining the health of the community.”Footnote 18
 One of the greatest challenges facing Black women is the racial wealth divide, as Black women posses significantly less wealth than Black men, White men and White and Hispanic women.Footnote 19 Historically, discrimination, government policies and even acts of violence have prohibited Blacks from generating wealth.Footnote 20 Consequentially, prior to the age of 50, the majority of Black women have virtually no wealth at all.Footnote 21 And at middle-age and older-age, research suggests that Black women have low levels of net worth and net financial assets suggesting that they are more likely to face economic insecurity later in life. Therefore, we examine how the intersection of race and gender places Black women in a vulnerable economic position and identify strategies for asset building and wealth generation. Homeownership is the main pathway to wealth; yet, research shows that there are significant differences in the likelihood of homeownership between White women and Black women. Policies deregulating the financial market have contributed to the rise of subprime mortgages and predatory lending and black women, particularly upper income black women, were one of the primary targets.Footnote 22 We examine the consequences of the subprime mortgage crisis on black women and its implications on home equity and wealth for Blacks and future generations of Blacks. In 2011, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act were enacted to address the existing and entrenched structural and institutional barriers to wealth accumulation. It intends to promote financial stability and protect families from future unfair financial practices. We recognize this Act as an important step to assist Black women in accessing fair and equal opportunities to build wealth and equity. Many of the challenges facing Black women are not unique to the United State; but are challenges experienced by many women of the African Diaspora. Therefore, this research provides valuable insight into these women’s economic and social contributions in developing countries. We examine the intersection of race, class and gender in Nigeria, in respect to children’s work in which poor young girls are more likely to work relative to other children. We examine the earnings of black immigrant women and U.S. black women in comparative perspective. In addition, we examine the relationship that race and immigrants’ birthplace has on welfare usage. The research suggests that the intersection of race, gender and class has similar implications on Black women in both industrial and developing countries.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Introduction

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Still Slipping: African-American Women in the Economy and in Society
Intro: African American women still “slip between the cracks” with some data collection and reporting. For example, the most recent report of the Digest of Educational Statistics reports on race or gender but not both (Tables Eight and Nine). Still, we know that the proportion of African Americans with college degree nearly doubled from 10.9 % in 1986 to 20.2 % in 2011 (www.nces.ed.gov/pubsearch/pubsinfo.asp?pubid+2012001). While African American male college enrollment once exceeded African American women’s enrollment, for the past decade, two-thirds of the African Americans in college have been African American women. As African American women increased both their numbers and proportion of college attendees and graduates, occupational options increased. Still, African American women, whether in elite occupations or crowded into typically female service and clerical jobs, experience a pay gap between their earning and those of white women, Black men, and white men. To be sure, African American men are more likely to be unemployed than African American women, but when they are in the labor market, their median income is higher than that of African American women. While African American women’s occupational options have expanded, occupational opportunities have eroded both because of the Great Recession (2008–2012) and because of the rising tide of conservatism in our nation. The focus on balancing the federal budget, which means cutting the federal workforce, and freezing federal salaries (which have been level since 2009), has a disproportionate impact on African American women, more than 22 % of whom work for governments, compared to just under 17 % of white workers (Wright 2011). Why? African American women are more likely to be teachers, nurses or social workers than others, and the public sector is more likely to employ those workers. Additionally and parenthetically, African American women and men have a smaller pay gap through government employment than through private sector employment. State and local governments laid off at least142,000 workers in 2011 (Williams 2011). Again, a disproportionate number of these were African American women. Many would argue that pay freezes and payroll cuts are economic necessity, not racially motivated, but all too often race-neutral public policy has a disproportionate racial impact. Affirmative action policies opened some doors for African American women, yet these policies have been repeated attacked and the reach of affirmative action eroded, since 1986. The rationale is the fiction that our country is now “race-neutral” and that the election of an African American president reflects the diminution of racial attitudes in our nation. The rising tide of conservatism has meant a retreat from affirmative action policies. The majority of the Supreme Court ruled, in 2003 that certain forms of affirmative action are illegal in Gratz v. Bollinger, a case where a mediocre white student argued that she would have been admitted to the University of Michigan but for affirmative action policies. Because of public referenda, race based affirmative action is illegal in California, Michigan, Washington, Nebraska, and Arizona. The Supreme Court will hear the Fisher v. University of Texas case sometime in the fall of 2012. This is yet another case of a mediocre white student arguing that she would have been admitted to UT but for affirmative action. While lower courts have ruled in favor of the University of Texas, and the Supreme Court had no obligation to take this case, those who oppose affirmative action have taken advantage of the fact that the Roberts court has been hostile in race matters. The disporportionality in these policies is reflected in differential unemployment rates by race and gender. The overall unemployment rate dropped from 9.0 % in May 2011 to 8.2 % in May 2012 has been heralded as a sign of economic recovery, albeit one that is weak and unstable. There were similar drops in every race-sex group, with white women’s rate dropping from 7.1 to 6.7 %, and Black women’s rate dropping from 13.4 to 11.4 %. In the 3 months between March and May 2012, however, every race-sex group saw employment rise in every race-sex group except African American women. White women’s employment rose by 200,000, while African American women’s employment dropped by 100,000. Some would consider this miniscule (less than 1 % of total Black women’s employment), but the crowing about recovery while African American women have lost work speaks to a systematic disregard for black women (Bureau of Labor Statistics 2012). The employment situation for African American women is compounded by the pay gap that these women experience. African American women earn 85 cents for every dollar earned by white women, and 63 cents for every dollar earned by white men (www.NationalPartnership.org). While we are regularly reminded of the narrowing pay gap between men and women (with women currently earning 77 cents for every dollar men earn), and President Obama’s Lily Ledbetter Fair Pay Act (2008) addresses some ways to close the gap, the pay gap that African American women experience is rarely addressed. Gaps in both employment and pay explain the limited wealth of African American women. A 2010 study by the Insight Center for Community Economic Development (www.insightcced.org/uploads/CWRG/LiftingAsWeClimb-WoemnWealth-Report-InsightCenter-Sopring2010.pdf) reported that the average net worth of single middle aged (36 to 49) Black women (including those who head households and have children) is just $5, compared to $42,600 for single white women of the same age. This low level of wealth has implications for the children of these low-wealth women, and for African American families in general. African American women are the primary breadwinners in 44 % of African American families with children, and 72 % of all Black children are being raised in households headed by women. These families have no cushion at all, so recession, unemployment and economic turbulence hit these women-headed households harder than other households. While it is important to focus on the economic status of African American women, from Black community perspective it is also critical to consider it in the context of African American family formation and the economic status of African American men. Low wages, limited college participation, and higher unemployment rates affect the economic status of African American women, as well as African American families, and in many families shifts the burden of support from one that is shared to one that falls fully on the shoulders of women. Thus, African American women experience a third burden beyond race and gender, in that the economic status of African American men directly affects the status and options of African American women. Fully 3.1 million African American women are single mothers, and the status of these women affect’s their children’s options and life chances. While a college education is often seen as a bridge to a broader range of career options, affordability is a significant barrier to college for many African American youngsters, especially those who have been raised by single mothers whose low level of wealth precludes saving for college. Thus, while African American women outnumber men who are enrolled in college, hundreds of thousands of African American young people cannot go to college, or stay in college, simply because of the financial status of their parents. This has implications not only for these young people, but also for our nation, especially as President Obama has declared that the United States should lead the world in educational attainment, measured by the percentage of people who have had at least a A.A. degree. According to OECD data, while the United States leads the world in producing 55 to 64 year old bachelor’s degree recipients, with 31.1 % of that population holding degrees. The educational attainment of 25 to 34 year olds perhaps reflects more recent investments in education. Among that population, 32.3 % of US residents in that age group had BA degrees, placing us sixth behind Norway (43.8 %), the Netherlands (37.5 %), Denmark (34.9 %), Korea (34.5 %) and Sweden (32.4 %) (*). We will not lead the world again unless our nation is prepared to specifically invest in the education of African American and Latino young people, as this group represents the expanding demographic in our country. The economic status of African American women, combined with the “drug wars” affects the high levels of incarceration among African American women who are eight times as likely to be incarcerated as white women. Indeed, African American women are currently the fastest growing prison population in our nation. According to Meda Chesney-Lind, a sociology professor at the University of Hawaii, “National policies like zero tolerance are responsible for the school to prison pipeline. And a dual justice system that treats white girls differently from Black girls is disproportionately affecting African American girls”. Indeed, a 6-year-old Black girl was handcuffed in Milledgeville, Georgia for having a temper tantrum. One might wonder if a white girl would have been incarcerated, or if this incident is reflective of our nation’s disregard for Black women and girls. In 2008 in California, the arrest rate for Black girls was 49 for every 1,000, compared to 8.9 per 1,000 for white girls (Jefferson 2011). The differential economic status of African American women affects non-economic aspects of African American women’s lives, including health and health access. According to a recent study by the Kaiser Foundation, African American women are far more likely than white women to have no health coverage (22.4 % compared to 12.8 %), no personal doctor (17.3 % versus 13.2 %), to have had no dental checkups in 2 years (35 % versus 25 %), no doctor visit due to cost (21.9 % versus 14.7 %), and late prenatal care (23.9 % versus 11 %). While there may be other factors, these disparities are at least partly a function of cost (James et al. 2009). The outcome of these differences in access and affordability result in the differential incidence of life-threatening diseases by race. According to Dr. Doris Brown, “The leading cause of death for all women in the United States is heart disease, cancer, AIDS stroke, and diabetes. The death rates for these diseases among African American women continue to rise despite declining rates for whites. African American women have the highest cancer death rates for breast, colorectal and pancreatic cancers.” Dr. Brown also found that the 5-year cancer survival rate for African American women is 57 %, compared to 67 % for white women. While Dr. Brown writes that lifestyle choices affect health status, income and economic status are also a factor (Browne 2008). There is some good news in the health care arena, in that the life expectancy gap is narrowing, among white and Black women from 4.6 years to 3.7 years. The gap is closing because drug abuse is rising among whites. While proportionately more, African Americans abuse drugs than whites, the rate of drug use among African Americans is falling more rapidly (Harper et al. 2003). Perhaps public policy has ignored African American women so systematically because popular culture and the popular media have tended to demonize African American women as dependent welfare mothers, lewd, lascivious and sexually available women, and as unattractive, evil, neck-rolling and emasculating women. Given these stereotypes, Black women may be seen as less worthy of public policy attention. Since 1986, we have seen the vilification of Anita Hill, the law professor whose allegations against then-Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas, were dismissed by some senators with demeaning statements about “erotomania”. From the floor of Congress, during the “welfare reform” debate in 1995–96, African American women on public assistance were derided in harsh and perjorative terms, with only members of the Congressional Black Caucus voicing objections. In 2007, radio talk show host Don Imus described the Rutgers women’s basketball time as “nappy headed hos”. While he was dismissed by CBS and MSNBC, he returned to the air a mere year later, on different networks. During the Obama Presidential campaign, the New Yorker Magazine chose to depict Michelle Obama as an Afro-wearing, gun-toting, fist-bumping Black militant. After President Obama’s election, Mrs. Obama has garnered mostly favorable press, but the “angry Black woman” allegations surface far too often. In 2011, the Psychology Today website posted an article titled “Why Are Black Women Less Physically Attractive Than Other Women”, written by a so-called “evolutionary psychologist” Satoshi Kanazawa. The relative acceptance of these stereotypes indicates that there are no consequences to vilifying African American women. With few African American women in decision making positions in majority media, (and with the penchant of some African American male producers and rap artists to vilify African American women), the cessation of this damaging media is unlikely. These images affect young Black women’s self-esteem, as well as their treatment by others in our society. Our 1986 volume had a section on development issues, with case studies on women in Tanzania and Jamaica, and an essay on women’s activism in South Africa. The purpose of this section was to make a connection, as Stephanie Wilson wrote, “between denied opportunities of Black women in the developing world, and Black women subjected to low-income status in the developed one.” As with African American women, women in the developing world have experienced both progress and regress, but the involvement of the US State Department and many in the private sector to provide entrepreneurial opportunities, including micro-finance opportunities has improved the global economic status of women of African descent. African American women’s involvement in developing African policy has increased since 1986. In the Clinton years, Rosa Whitaker served as White House Advisor on Africa and Singleton McAllister led the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). Robin R. Sanders was appointed Ambassador to Nigeria, the first African American women to serve in such distinction. As Hilary Rodham Clinton leads the State Department, she has included African American women in leadership positions as special advisors and assistant secretaries of State. Still, the bottom-line economics have not changed much. Nearly half of the world lives on less than two dollars and 50 ¢ per day. The economist Jeffrey Sachs says that poverty can be eliminated globally by 2025 through carefully focused development aid, which represents less than 1 % of world GDP, but a lack of commitment, combined with a global recession and an unstable euro, suggests that these contributions are not forthcoming in the short run. Sachs also supports the cancellation of debt to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in the world’s poorest countries, including those on the African continent (Sachs 2005). Any efforts to eradicate world poverty have a disproportionately positive effect on women of African descent in the diaspora. These women are more likely to raise and support children, and to have limited employment opportunities. Black women in the United States, despite many challenges, have a privileged position when compared to women in the developing world. From that perspective it is important that our policy work include advocacy for economic justice for women around the globe, and especially in the diasporic world. With differential economic status affecting everything from health to image to global presence, what must happen to improve the status of African American women? The legislative agenda that Margaret Simms and I developed in 1986 is as relevant now as it was then, with a focus using legislation to create more favorable outcomes for African American women in the economy. The agenda suggested items such as preserving affirmative action, providing or legislating more affordable child care, increasing both financial aid and Title III funding to Historically Black colleges and Universities (HBCU’s), and providing more training opportunities for African American women. Although our legislative solutions did not specifically mention targeting public policy to Black women, we suggested ways to tweak legislation to provide more favorable outcomes for African American women. As we stated in 1986, “While our panels have documented some inequity, it is the challenge of legislators and policymakers to shape our research findings into legislation that corrects measured inequities.” We did not use terms like “social and economic justice” that are more frequently used today, although this goal is implicit in our focus on closing gaps Because our work was first presented at a legislative forum, the focus on legislative outcomes is understandable. Given the current legislative climate, which chooses economic austerity instead of economic investment and expansion, we can no longer depend solely on legislation. Legislation has clear limitations, even when it is well written. Government employees resistant to change may not implement those policies they do not support. This means that when we consider the future of African American women, we must also look to non-legislative efforts to improve the status of African American women. These include: Organizing. The Occupy Movement suggests ways that organized groups can bring attention to issues of economic inequality. To the extent that these organizations focus on issues of economic justice. African American women should have a presence, both to support efforts that might support us, and also to leverage these organizations’ visibility to advance issues that affect African American women. Presence. In civil rights organizations, Black leadership specifically means the leadership of African American men. In women’s organizations, with few exceptions, leadership means white women. Our few national African American women’s organizations are all too often missing from the policy table. African American women’s presence has been hampered by the 2010 death of Dr. Dorothy Irene Height, who led the National Council of Negro Women since 1955 and whose stature did not permit anyone from rendering her as invisible as African American women have been rendered collectively. Those of conscience who advocate for social and economic justice cannot have policy or advocacy conversations without African American women in the room. Advocacy. African American women must develop an effective presence as advocates for economic advancement, both in the public and in the private sector. Many corporations talk the diversity and inclusion talk, but do not walk the walk in terms of their policies to advance the careers of African American women. Indeed, at the upper echelons of corporate America, with few exceptions, African Americans are invisible. Employee support groups can be advocates for inclusion, and corporations have an obligation to include African American women, and other women of color, in their governing bodies so that they may be internal advocates for equal opportunity in the workplace. Similarly, women legislators have often been effective advocates for the advancement of African American women, but they need constituent support to maintain their level of advocacy. Slipping Through The Cracks offered both a legislative and a research agenda more than 25 years ago. While African American women have made some progress since 1986, those agendas remain relevant because gaps have not been closed, social and economic justice has not been attained, and these inequities will have a deleterious effect on the African American community, our nation, and our world.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Introduction to Articles on Black Women and Work

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Non-Traditional Family: An Introduction

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: An Analysis of Black–White Wage Differences in Nursing: Wage Gap or Wage Premium?
Intro: This paper analyzes the labor market for registered nurses (RNs) in the United States (US) to determine if Black nurses experience a wage penalty relative to White nurses. This is important because nursing and teaching represent two relatively well paid professional occupations with large representations of African American females. Some research argues that a nursing shortage exists (Bergmann 2006; Lovell 2006; Seago et al. 2001). However, few studies have examined the prospects for African American nurses to help alleviate the purported shortage. An impediment to these prospects could be real or perceived racial inequalities in the labor market. Some researchers argue that healthcare employers possess monopsony power (Bergmann 2006; Yett 1975). Monopsony power may allow them to indulge in exercising racial preferences; in light of purported shortages, this would represent a market failure. Others argue that unions may offer countervailing power as the result of imposing standard wages based on seniority that could prevent this situation from occurring in occupations such as nursing (Schmitt 2008). Research exists that suggests the presence of a black–white wage gap in nursing. Buhr (2010) found immigrant nurses from Africa and the Caribbean received a 9% wage penalty in Canada. Scott (2008) contends that Black nurses earn less than White nurses in New York. Possible explanations for black–white differences in nurses’ pay include racial differences in: occupation; returns to skills; metropolitan residency; union membership. This study addresses the issue by performing regression analysis on the wages of RNs, which allows for a more focused analysis of the returns Black and White nurses receive for their characteristics.

Title: Things Fall Apart: Health Consequences of Mass Imprisonment for African American Women

Title: The Impact of Housing Stressors on the Mental Health of a Low-Income African-American Population

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Maggie Anderson with Ted Gregory: Our Black Year

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: NEA Presidential Address: Gender Inequality and Human Development in Sub- Saharan Africa
Intro:
Economic growth appears to be related to improvements in human capabilities as measured by several components of the Human Development Index (Human Development Report 2009) that measures those functional capabilities important for economic well-being (Anand and Ravallion 1993; Elu 2000; Ranis and Stewart 2000; Ranis et al. 2000). Since 1990, when the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) introduced the Human Development Index (HDI) the majority of Sub-Saharan African countries have been classified as being low in human development, despite the positive growth rate. The HDI, motivated to measure the capabilities of individuals to enjoy a high quality of life (Sen 1985), is a summary index of the incomes, education and life expectancy of the average individual in a country. As gender inequality in Sub-Saharan Africa appears to be particularly pernicious (Izumi 2007; Rebouche 2006), in this Presidential Address, I link 2009 UNDP HDI data for with data on measures of gender inequality provided by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, to explore the consequences of gender inequality for human development in Sub-Saharan Africa. The HDI is a composite index based on three sub-indexes capturing three different dimensions of Health, Education, and Living standard respectively for individual well-being in a country: a long and healthy life measured by the Life Expectancy Index, knowledge measured by an Education Index, and a decent standard of living measured by the GDP Index. I will consider the extent to which the HDI, as a broader measure of the welfare on individuals in a country, is conditioned on measures of gender inequality. If so, gender inequality can possibly inform the extent to which human development and living standards s in Sub-Saharan Africa are low in general, and relative to other countries.Footnote 1
 My inquiry is important for at least two reasons. First, promoting gender equality in Sub-Saharan Africa is one of the key Millennium Development Goals (2011). My analysis will inform how sensitive human development in Sub-Saharan is to the status of women, and permit some insight into how prioritized gender equality should be. Lastly, my inquiry extends the analysis of Morrisson and Jutting (2005), and will inform the extent to which particular Sub-Saharan African laws, norms, traditions, and codes of conduct toward women in Sub-Saharan Africa are important for human and economic development.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: From Here to Full Employment

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Hurricane Katrina as an Experiment in Housing Mobility and Neighborhood Effects: Were the Relocated Poor Black Evacuees Better-Off?
Intro: Differences in neighborhoods—the physical space where individuals and households reside—appear to play a central role in racial inequality in the United States (Wilson 1987). Black-white differences in neighborhoods appear to matter for black-white differences in health status (Lochner et al. 2003), poverty (Massey and Denton 1993),and are likely to be the mechanism by which black-white inequality is transmitted across generations (Loury 1977). The importance of neighborhoods for socioeconomic outcomes (Jencks and Mayer 1990) can be a result of behavior being subject to social interactions (Manski 1993) whereby individual outcomes and payoffs are linked to the outcomes and payoffs of others (Akerlof 1997), leading to so-called peer effects.Footnote 1 When peer effects are operative, neighborhood begets neighborhood, so that over time neighborhood socioeconomic characteristics persist along with the socioeconomic outcomes of the individuals that reside in the neighborhood. As a random event, Hurricane Katrina induced hundreds of thousands of New Orleans citizens to evacuate and relocate to different neighborhoods, both within the state of Louisiana, and across the United States. As such, Hurricane Katrina engendered an experiment in the effects of housing mobility and changing neighborhoods due to the dislocations it caused. The extent of dislocation was quite dramatic. As of 2000, Census data reported that New Orleans had a population of 484,674 individuals. Post-Katrina, various estimates reported in the media indicated that on December 2005, the city had approximately 100,000 individuals (Grier 2005). Thus, at least in the short-run, over 300,000 individuals in the City of New Orleans were dislocated and either temporarily homeless or relocated into new neighborhoods as a result of Hurricane Katrina. Relocation decisions are typically voluntary, and correlated with unobserved characteristics of households and individuals. The relocations induced by Hurricane Katrina provide an opportunity to examine the causal effects of moving from high poverty to low poverty neighborhoods on socioeconomic outcomes—or neighborhood effects. With survey data from a small sample of Katrina evacuees in the City of New Orleans who registered for absentee voter ballots, this paper considers whether or not there were treatment effects associated with housing mobility that moves individuals to destination neighborhoods with poverty rates lower than in origin neighborhoods. Viewing a household move from origin to destination neighborhood as a treatment, we estimate the effects of moving to a neighborhood with a lower poverty rate with a matching estimator. Our choice of a matching estimator is motivated on several grounds. First, as our sample data are unweighted, possible correlation between unobserved sample weights and the treatment could undermine identification of treatment effects. A matching estimator allows us to condition selection into treatment on observables, obviating the need for weights. Second, neighborhood effects need not be linear (Patterson 2008). A matching estimator does not impose linearity upon parameter estimates, and are therefore likely to yield robust parameter estimates of treatment effects, and where there are thresholds. To date, the effects of moving low income households in high poverty neighborhoods to low poverty neighborhoods appears, in some instances, to improve their welfare. Experimental analysis of neighborhood effects reveal that the beneficial effects range from lower rates of delinquency among females (Kling et al. 2005), to improved health and lower crime victimization rates among children (Katz et al. 2001). Quasi-experimental analysis also show that low-poverty neighborhoods favorably affect the schooling (Boston 2005) and labor market outcomes of youth (Rosenbaum 1992, 1995), and on teenage pregnancy (Harding 2003). Our inquiry contributes to the literature on the effects that neighborhoods have on socioeconomic outcomes, and the implications such effects have for antipoverty policy. That neighborhoods engender social interactions and peer effects suggest that effective antipoverty policy could operate through housing mobility policies that change the neighborhoods individuals with low socioeconomic status reside in. This is the premise of the United States Department of Housing and Development (HUD) Moving To Opportunity Program (MTO).Footnote 2 The MTO program randomly assigns housing vouchers to low income households from high poverty neighborhoods in five cities for use in relocating to neighborhoods where the poverty rate is less than 10 %. Below, we consider neighborhood relocations from and to neighborhoods across a range of poverty rates. As such, our inquiry will broaden the analysis of neighborhood effects, recognizing that if indeed neighborhood poverty, constrains household and individual welfare, then it is useful for antipoverty policy to consider how changes in neighborhood policy affect household and individual welfare across a variety of destination and origin neighborhood poverty characteristics. Our analysis also represents one the few efforts, outside the analysis of the Gautreaux housing mobility program, that neighborhoods effects are estimated based on origin and destination neighborhood poverty characteristics.Footnote 3 Findings from the MTO experiment are based upon low income households moving to neighborhoods where the poverty rate is less than 10 %, and there is no consideration of the exact poverty characteristics of the origin neighborhood. To the extent that there are nonlinear thresholds in the relationship between neighborhood poverty and socioeconomic outcomes (Patterson 2008), ignoring the poverty characteristics of both the origin and destination neighborhood could lead to biased estimates of neighborhood effects. Below, we estimate neighborhood effects based on moves by low-income households where the treatments measure origin and destination neighborhood poverty. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section “Data and methodology” describes the data and methodology. Our econometric strategy for estimating neighborhood identifies neighborhood effects by assuming selection on observables, which justifies the use of propensity score matching estimators. In section “Results”, we report parameter estimates of the treatment effects of moving from and to neighborhoods with differential poverty rates on five measures of individual welfare. The treatment effects of neighborhood change measure the poverty rate of both the origin and destination neighborhood. The last section concludes.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Housing, Race, and Recovery from Hurricane Katrina

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Keeping Your Financial Planner to Yourself: Racial and Cultural Differences in Financial Planner Referrals
Intro:
Since individuals who use professional financial advice tend to display more financial responsible behaviors, having access to a financial expert within a Black household’s social network and sharing this access through word-of-mouth (WOM) referrals may lead to the household having a more positive and persistent financial condition. As such, this review of literature will include studies that focus on social networks and access to experts, word-of-mouth referrals, the value of expert access, and the importance of referrals within Black social networks. Information transfers within social networks may occur in the form of word-of-mouth referrals. Consumers frequently depend on word-of-mouth (WOM) referrals in making purchase decisions (Bansal and Voyer 2000; Brown and Reingen 1987). WOM referrals not only serve as a means of transmitting information regarding the evaluation of a good or service, but they also allow for convenient access to the specialized knowledge of an expert, at a lower cost, and in a more trusting environment. Individuals who have or have access to an expert within their social network may benefit from receiving specialized knowledge at reduced search costs and increased convenience and flexibility (Cornwell and Cornwell 2008). Researchers have found WOM referrals to be the most influential source of information when consumers do not fully understand a product or service and when the product has credence characteristics (Anderson 1998). Hiring a financial expert and financial advice are credence goods since most people are neither confident in their financial knowledge nor their ability to properly evaluate the quality of financial advice or its provider prior to, or even after, receiving the good (Bluethgen et al. 2008). As a consequence, people tend to turn to their social network for referrals and service-provider recommendations since it is assumed that friends and family will not recommend an inferior product or service (Chang 2005). There is substantial literature relating to the use of social networks for employment recommendations.Footnote 1 Job-search literature includes social networks as an indirect source of job information related to availability of jobs of different types and about conditions of employment. Holzer (1987) finds in the job-search domain Blacks and Whites rely on WOM recommendations at similar frequencies as represented by only a small non-significant racial difference in the use of friends and family for job referrals in younger workers (66 % of Whites compared to 67 % of Blacks between the ages of 16 and 23) and 23.9 % of Whites compared to 21.5 % of Blacks among all age categories. Yet, minimal empirical research has examined the use of social networks in referrals for financial experts. In a sample of California mortgage holders, Reed (2010) finds the majority of individuals rely on their social network for information about mortgage products with Blacks and Whites reporting similar frequencies. Pittman (2008) looking at a sample of only Black borrowers finds that over 80 % of the sample received mortgage advice in regards to choosing a lender from friends or family. Barrett (2011) finds that nearly 40 % of 1,000 surveyed investors between the ages of 25 and 70 relied on their social network to select a financial expert. Fischer and Gerhardt (2007) report that financial experts may be particularly valuable to individuals who lack financial literacy and/or are prone to cognitive biases that lead to financial mistakes. Financial experts improve household savings and investment behaviors by reducing anxiety during volatile market conditions, helping clients avoid acting irrationally (Haslem 2010; Winchester et al. 2011), and enhancing portfolio diversification (Bluethgen et al. 2008). Marsden et al. (2011) find that working with a financial expert improves goal setting, calculation of retirement needs, and the accumulation of emergency funds, and Grable and Joo (2001) find financial planners increase the ability of a household to better use complex financial instruments. The current economic condition and behaviors of Black households suggest that they may benefit from the use of a financial expert. The number of studies that find Blacks display less than optimal financial behaviors is staggering. It is suggested that 55 % of White households are adequately prepared for retirement compared to 39 % of Black households (Yuh et al. 1998). Blacks hold less stocks in defined contribution plans and are almost twice as likely to take a hardship withdrawal from their 401(k) accounts than Whites (Mitchell 2012). Oliver and Shapiro (1995) find that 73 % of the value of all wealth held by Blacks is in consumable assets, compared to Whites who invest over half (51 %) of their aggregate wealth in income-producing assets, with Blacks holding nearly two-thirds of their wealth in homes (compared to 43 %) and 10 % in vehicles (compared to 6 %) (DeVaney et al. 2007). Loving et al. (2012) find that Blacks are not only less likely to be homeowners than Whites, but also experience lower levels of home appreciation. Last, Blacks have lower savings rates and use more of their credit line on average than Whites, as well as report higher scores on debt stress indices (Drentea and Lavrakas 2000). To the contrary, Black households with access to a financial expert have been shown to be more likely to own wealth accumulation and asset protection products than Black households without an expert. In addition, those who use a financial expert are significantly more likely to have a detailed plan to meet all of their financial goals and nearly double the confidence in their ability to meet those goals (Prudential 2011).Footnote 2
 Receiving expert financial advice that leads to changes in savings and investment behaviors that result in wealth accumulation in Black households is threefold. First, increases in wealth lead to increases in a household’s ability to withstand income shocks such as unexpected health and/or medical expenses, a temporary loss of employment, and/or other emergencies (Wolff 2002). Second, having more wealth enables Black households to provide intergenerational transfers of wealth. It has been hypothesized that racial differences in financial inheritance contribute to racial wealth inequality (Martin 2011). It is estimated that wealth transfers, both inter vivos and bequest, account for 12 %–51 % of the receiving generation’s net worth (Gale and Scholz 1994; McKernan et al. 2011). Third, added wealth can be used to fund formal education, accumulate additional financial assets, and to finance entrepreneurial ventures (Martin). Therefore, the successful building and accumulation of wealth within Black households may also decrease the persistent wealth gap between Blacks and Whites. Consulting with a financial expert may also reduce the number of Black households that fall victim to predatory lending practices, as evidenced by the number of Black households who face bankruptcy and foreclosure in the wake of the 2007 Recession. Researchers have found that the use of subprime loan products varies significantly by race, with Blacks being significantly more likely than Whites to hold a subprime loan (Reid 2010). These finds support the contention that households lacking financial expertise have a tendency to enter into risky financial contracts (Lusardi and Mitchell 2007). Therefore, gaining access to financial knowledge, in the form of a financial expert, may allow for a better analysis of the technical aspects of various financial products as well as offer guidance that results in less risky financial contracts being undertaken (Agarwal et al. 2009). Consumers must be knowledgeable in the selection process for a financial expert to ensure that the chosen expert is ethical, competent, and appropriate (Alcon 1999). However, Blacks have been shown to have a lack of knowledge regarding selecting a competent financial expert, and have been shown to be wary of financial service providers because of negative historical experiences and/or perceptions (Toussaint-Comeau et al. 2001). Consequently, Chang (2005) finds that Blacks are more likely to seek financial advice and planner recommendations from members of their social network than any other source. Since social network members tend to be economically homogeneous and share similar financial concerns and needs, relying on friends and relatives for referrals improves the quality of the match between user and service provider. Pittman (2008) finds that relying on information from social networks enables borrowers to more thoughtfully evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of particular loan products. In the job-search domain, Datcher (1983) finds that those who found employment through personal contacts were less likely to quit, and Devine and Keifer (1993) find that they had longer tenure on their jobs. Brown and Reingen (1987) contend the likelihood of establishing a successful client-financial expert relationship in increased by using a recommendation provided by a friend or family member.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Using the Blinder-Oaxaca Decomposition Method to Measure Racial Bias in Achievement Tests
Intro: The robust and persistent gap in black-white performance on achievement tests is well documented. For example, results from the 2009 National Assessment of Educational Progress indicate that black eighth graders have math and reading scores that are approximately 90 % of the average white student score. While all students had higher math and reading scores in 2009 compared to 2007, or to the 1990s, there has not been a significant change in the racial gap over time (see U.S. Department of Education 2009). Research dating to the 1960s reports a significant racial test score gap after controlling for detailed individual characteristics, socioeconomic status, and school quality (see Coleman et al. 1966; Kaufman and Kaufman 1983, and Phillips 2000 as examples). Given the persistence of racial differences in test scores, educational attainment and earnings, some claim that reducing racial differences in academic achievement will do more to reduce other racial disparities than any other plausible policy (see Jencks and Phillips 1998 and Harris 2010). In the search for a better understanding of the test score gap, and for relevant policy recommendations, recent research has examined the effects of factors such as teacher and student characteristics, school quality, segregation and socioeconomic factors on test score differences (see Ferguson 2003; Hanushek and Rivkin 2009; Fordham and Ogbu 1986; Nye et al. 2004; Card and Rothstein 2007 and Grissmer et al. 1994 for examples). A recent volume of the Review contributes to this body of research by calling for improved, comprehensive models to appropriately estimate the gap, understanding the roles of racial discrimination and racial identity in achievement motivation and outcomes, and the need to attend to minority students at both ends of the test score distribution (see McMillian et al. 2010; Seaton 2010 and Robinson 2010). In general, the studies examining the achievement test score gap reflect an optimism that narrowing the gap will reduce other racial disparities in economic outcomes. However, other studies suggest that this optimism may be misplaced since reduced disparities in academic achievement are often associated with increased racial disparities in other areas. For example, several studies report increased racial pay and career disparities at higher levels of education, salary and power (see Tomaskovic-Devey et al. 2005; Arias et al. 2004 and Elliott and Smith 2004). These results are consistent with the view that outright discrimination intensifies when members of subaltern groups compete with members of the dominate group for social rewards in a hierarchical setting (see Darity 2001). These studies imply that equality of academic achievement is not sufficient to offset the inequities rooted in pre-market and labor market discrimination. While the relation between the achievement gap and racial disparities in pay and other economic outcomes is controversial, standardized achievement tests play important roles in access to higher education, employment and promotions (see Harris 2010 and Hedges and Nowell (1998). Consequently, it is necessary that achievement be measured without bias. Jencks (1998) describes 5 ways that standardized tests can be biased.Footnote 1 For example, tests suffer from “content bias” when they contain questions that favor one group over another. This study contributes to the literature on test score bias by illustrating how the Blinder-Oaxaca decomposition technique can be used to measure the relative racial bias in achievement tests that arises due to the content of the exams. This Blinder-Oaxaca method, described in more detail below, can be used to measure the portion of a gap between two groups that can be attributed to, or explained by, differences in average characteristics. In an application of this technique to test scores, if two tests are unbiased, or equally biased, the percent of the test score gap that is attributed to differences in characteristics will be the same for the two tests. However, if one test explains more of the racial gap in scores than another test, that test is relatively less biased. The approach used in the present study differs from standard methods of detecting content bias. For example, Cole (1981) and Medley and Quirk (1974) detect bias within a test by altering questions and measuring subsequent performance differences between groups. Other efforts to address bias in achievement tests focus on identifying, modifying, or removing biased test questions. There are different methods of identifying faulty test items. For example, Schratz and Wellens (1981) describe how panels of minority educators can be used to develop tests and remove biased items. On the other hand, others use statistical methods where significant deviations between group scores on particular items and overall group mean scores can be used to find faulty test questions (see Green 1971 and Scheuneman 1979). However, this method of detecting bias in a test is controversial. For example, Hunter and Schmidt (2000) argue that findings of test item bias can be attributed to measurement error, assumption violations, or to small differences between groups that are statistically significant because sample sizes are very large. Given this controversy, the application of the Blinder-Oaxaca decomposition method to the test score gap can be viewed as another statistical technique to confirm the presence of racial bias in achievement tests. The remainder of this paper is organized along the following lines. In the next section the data and the achievement tests used to illustrate the Blinder-Oaxaca decomposition technique are described. A detailed description of the decomposition technique follows. The model and empirical results are presented and the paper concludes with implications for practice and future research.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Racial Position Segregation in Intercollegiate Football: Do Players become more Racially Segregated as they Transition from High School to College?
Intro:
Sport has long been heralded as having paved the way to such significant actions as Brown v. Board of
Education and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Jack Johnson held the world heavyweight title in boxing, Jesse Owens won four Olympic gold medals in track and field, Jackie Robinson broke the Major League Baseball (MLB) color barrier, and Ernie Davis won the Heisman Trophy in college football all before 1964. Thus, one might argue that sport has served as an avenue to equal opportunity for African Americans. At the very least, it would seem that the sports labor market opened up earlier to African Americans than the general labor market. Currently, 67% of players in the National Football League (NFL) are African American (National Football League 2011), and 78% of players in the National Basketball Association (NBA) are African American (National Basketball Association 2011). Furthermore, over half of the top 50 highest paid American athletes are African American (Sports Illustrated 2011). However, U.S. Census data on median earnings among full-time, year round workers reveals that African American males earn slightly less than white females and only about 73.5% as much as white males.Footnote 1 Indeed it seems that the labor market outcomes of African Americans in sports labor markets are more similar to their white counterparts than those in non-sports labor markets. However, the sports labor market may not be free from racial discrimination. For example, Holmes (2011) finds evidence of salary discrimination against African American MLB players, while Berri and Simmons (2009) find evidence of salary discrimination against African American quarterbacks in the NFL. Branham (2008) and Madden (2004) bring to light that African American coaches in the NFL are seemingly on a shorter leash and held to a higher standard than similar white coaches. Also, Kanazawa and Funk (2001) find evidence of customer discrimination against African American NBA players. Thus, it seems that none of the three major American sports is without some form of discrimination. In this study, we examine the issue of racial position segregation or racial “stacking” in intercollegiate football. Racial position segregation refers to the phenomenon of white and African American players being relegated to certain types of positions on a team. Viewing a team as a firm, the issue can be seen as a case of inter-firm segregation. Carrington and Troske (1998) show that the wage gap between white and African American workers is primarily a “within-plant phenomenon”. That is, whites tend to occupy higher paying positions than African Americans within a given firm. Similarly, Bayard et al. (2003) find that much of the gender wage gap can be attributed to women being segregated into lower paying occupations within firms. Just as the wages of African American and female workers suffer from inter-firm segregation in the general labor market, the earnings of African American athletes have been shown to suffer from position segregation in the sports labor market. Yetman and Eitzen (1972) and Eitzen and Yetman (1977) show that those positions dominated by white players in sports generally receive higher salaries and more endorsement opportunities. Thus, racial position segregation is not without economic consequence for African American players. General observation suggests that racial position segregation is not as significant an issue as in the past. One need not look very hard to find examples of African Americans playing positions that were generally considered off-limits by many in the past. As the first African American to play in the Atlantic Coast Conference, Darryl Hill is considered by many to be the “Jackie Robinson of southern college football.” As Hill acknowledges, college football provided an opportunity for upward mobility, yet it did not come without a price. “One of the toughest places I played was Clemson University. You know, 50,000 drunk southern gentlemen are waiting to see this brother come out on the field. Not a black person in the stands anywhere. The black people had to sit outside the stadium on a red, dirt hill called ‘Nigger Hill.’ And that’s where they watched the game. Talk about double-teamed, I was triple-teamed. Every time I look up there and see these black people sitting on this dirt hill, I said, I’m gonna show these folks.” (Darryl Hill in Greenberg and Bernstein 2008) Since Hill’s ground breaking 1963 season, there has been significant improvement in the racial integration of college football (Eitzen and Yetman 1977; Hawkins 2002). Prior to the 1960’s, organized college football was almost completely segregated. Those who played did so mostly at a limited number of African American institutions. As desegregation took hold, African American participation grew. In 1992 and 2002 respectively, it has been reported that nearly half of Division I football players were of African American decent (Lewis 1995; Hawkins 2002). In 2010, pursuant to the 2009–2010 National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Student-Athlete Ethnicity Report, African American players composed the majority of Division I football players at 45.8% (National Collegiate Athletic Association 2010a). This is the first time African American players represented the dominant demographic since the NCAA began monitoring African American participation. Wilbur Hackett can personally attest to the transformation of college football. As a linebacker for the 1967 University of Kentucky football team, Hackett became the first African American to captain a Southeastern Conference (SEC) football team. This was no small accomplishment given that most SEC teams had yet to include African American players on their rosters. Following his playing career, Hackett became a college football official. As an official, he recognized the improvement in the racial make-up of college football teams. “When I look around and I see 11 African American football players on defense and I look over there and there’s a black quarterback, it does my heart good. And, I do feel good about the fact that these young men are getting these opportunities. It makes me feel good because I know where it was and where it is now.” (Wilbur Hackett in Greenberg and Bernstein 2008) Given the immense pressure placed on coaches to win, it seems selecting and assigning players based on racial stereotypes would have no place in the modern college football era. As any coach will agree, talent wins football games. Indeed, a head coach’s continued employment is predicated on his ability to evaluate and integrate talent. By assigning positions on the basis of race, a coach negatively affects his team’s ability to win games. However, even though considerable progress has been made with respect to racial relations in college football, can we properly conclude that organized college football is free of racial position segregation? Our study employs data from Rivals.com to observe a player’s position in high school and college. Estimating a probit model, we examine the impact that a player’s race has on the probability of him changing positions when he moves from high school to the collegiate ranks. If a player’s race is a significant determinant of whether or not he changes positions, then there is evidence supporting players being stacked along racial lines in college football. Also, given that a player does change positions, we are interested in observing what position he switches to and whether that tends to differ between white and African American players. The remainder of this paper progresses as follows. Relevant literature is reviewed in section 2. Section 3 details the data and our empirical methodology. Section 4 provides an analysis of position changes. Our probit results are reported and discussed in section 5, and section 6 contains our concluding remarks.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Ethnic Minorities, Race, and Inequality in China: A New Perspective on Racial Dynamics

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Race: China’s Question and Problem
Intro:
Although it is now a commonly accepted truth that race and racial difference has no cultural, or scientific/biological basis, race has a social truth that has been buttressed by and reflected through history and power. That social truth came from meanings that have been assigned over time to certain physical features of the body—the shape of the head, skin color, hair texture, eye shape, and body type. Perpetuating the meanings and values attributed to these physical features is/was an expression of power. This means that Western definitions of race traveled wherever powerful Western states have. Yet, as Dikotter has pointed out, an awareness of a classificatory hierarchy based on relative skin color existed in China long before the arrival of Euro-American missionaries and colonialists. Stories of contact between the Chinese and Africans from the Tang (618–907) and Song (960–1279) Dynasties are part of the historical narrative. There is the story of Du Huan, an officer in the Tang Dynasty, who wrote about his travels in Africa (possibly Eritrea) in the 8th century. According to other narratives, Canton was already the site of an Islamic trading enclave by the 10th and 11th centuries and interest in the lands in the “southwest”, as Africa was referred to, was growing. With trade as the primary purpose of these exchanges, merchants of the Tang and Southern Sung Dynasties wrote of their initial disappointment with these regions, but by the 13th century, opportunities for trade seemed more favorable. This increasingly favorable impression led to expanded economic interest. Chinese writers of the time began describing African wildlife, the landscape, and the nomadic people of the east African coast. Descriptions focusing on skin-color appeared as early at the 4th century and there seems to have been a time when dark-skinned persons were presented to the Chinese imperial court as slaves, called “Kunlun” (initially meaning “…primeval chaos”…. and then coming to mean something close to “…peoples from a magical western mountain…”). The Chinese Columbus, Zheng He, arrived in the 15th century and trade and Chinese exploration of Africa accelerated.Footnote 3
 The repeated telling of these stories shows how the Chinese incorporated Africans into their cosmology. The Chinese held a belief of the cosmological ordering of the universe that included a structured a hierarchy of civilizations with the Chinese imperial order at the core and placed other civilizations in descending degrees of civilization radiating in concentric circles out from this core. Notions of skin color mapped these radiating circles of civilization. But these ideas about skin color and the recognition of skin color differences were not absolute; attaining civilization defined skin color. At this time, China did not share the absolutist notions of skin color of the European Enlightenment not did they believe that the state was a container for those differences. For example, the Chinese imperial clan was thought of as “white” because white was the center of the civilized world. Chinese laborers were considered uncivilized and, therefore, black.Footnote 4 In this discursive field, those from the Kunlun, the outskirts of the known world, would be described as black. So, skin color and a sense of racial hierarchy mapped onto a spatial hierarchy based on civilizational attainment. Initially, Europeans, coming from a place far from the civilizational core, were considered just as strange as Africans. Yet, the addition of Western notions of racial identity and difference should not be minimized Beginning with the late imperial era, the confluence of Chinese notions of the civilizational basis of fundamental difference and Western racial classification hierarchy shaped the discourse surrounding the creation of the modern state. The questions to ask interrogate the understandings of China’s 19th and 20th century reformers and revolutionaries, like Kang Youwei [康有为] (1858–1927), Liang Qichao [梁启超] (1873–1929), Sun Yatsen [X中山] (1866–1925), and Mao Tsetung [毛泽东] (1893–1976) and Zhou Enlai [周恩来] (1898–1976) about the role of race and racial difference to the global order as they attempted to construct a modern Chinese political order. Did they see a racialized picture of global difference, hierarchy and power? Did race and racial difference play a role in their understanding of the modern state form? Did that racialized understanding influence the form of the modern state in China? The concept of the modern state as a sovereign participant in a global community of Westphalian states was a raced concept. Enlightenment thinkers like Kant, Linnaeus, and Locke believed that there was a direct association between appearance, culture, and political acumen and the capacity for self-rule. Used as the premise for scientific classification, European whites were defined (by European whites) as being the most advanced group and, despite the differences between various groups within the white group, inhabited and controlled the most powerful states. Coinciding with Europe’s transition from feudalism to capitalism, this concept was used to justify their control not just of the territory where they lived but also their expansion to lands far from their capitals. European power, expressed by their expansion beyond their territorial borders, also spread and imposed the meaning of sovereignty and ideas about those who were not worthy of nor ready for self-rule. Their power also served to inculcate the meaning and relevance of the inferiority to those they ruled over. This created a psychological feedback loop whereby the inequalities created by racial classifications increasingly reflected economic inequalities. As Baum has written, “…it [was] not race that [gave] rise to inequality but inequality that [gave] rise to race…”Footnote 5 The American and European states with ethnically and racially diverse populations were, nonetheless, politically, economically, and socially dominated by those who based their claims on their European descent and their proof was white skin color. Western notions of “race” entered the minds of the Chinese elites in two ways. First, elites in Japan attempted to answer the critical question: what was the secret of white Europe? It was in Japan that many exiled Chinese reformers, fleeing from the Empress Dowager’s coup after the 100 Days reforms of 1898, first encountered translations of Western political and social philosophical texts on the use of Spencerian Darwinism to understand the international political order. They also defined the modern state form as the central vehicle for national survival in the global struggle for dominance.Footnote 6 Reading both Darwin’s writings and the commentaries that (mis)used Darwin to analyze contemporary societies and politics, Liang began to write about a global race competition between states in neo-Darwinist terms. For the groups to successfully compete with one another, they had to accentuate their ability to unite together for a common purpose or goal. What created this ability to group? The recognition of a common essence. Kang and Liang, along with other reformers used the term “tongzhong” (同种), meaning similar kind or similar/same seed, to describe this sense of groupness.Footnote 7 Skin color seemed to be a visible manifestation of the ability to group. The second way that Western notions of race entered the Chinese society was through Westerners living and working in China. They circulated ideas about skin color as race, identity as singular and fixed, culture as inheritable that were translated into notions of superior state power. Western missionaries in mission schools, for example, taught that the ability to politically group as a nation was a manifestation of race. According to Dikotter, these missionaries even taught their students how to recognize the characteristic colors of the world’s races, with the Chinese, Japanese, and Filipinos as the “yellow” race, the Europeans as “white”, Africans and the American slave population, as “black”. They taught about the hierarchical order of races, with whites and North American/European states at the top and blacks, held in slavery in the West and colonized in territorial Africa, at the bottom.Footnote 8
 The power of the narrative of white superiority within the racial hierarchy and the superior power of white states was successfully challenged by the victory of the Japanese army against a white, European nation, Russia, in 1904. The Russo-Japanese War demonstrated that a non-white nation could militarily defeat a white one. In just 40 years, from 1868’s Meiji Restoration to the early years of the 20th century, Japan went from being a closed feudal system, part of the Chinese imperial tributary order, to a major global power rivaling the West. This victory provided important inspiration for Asian, African, and Arab nationalists and revolutionaries. African-American scholar, activist and Pan-African internationalist, William Edward Burghardt Du Bois (杜波依斯博士) (1868–1963), wrote aof the Japanese victory The accomplishment of Japan has been to realize the meaning of European aggression on the darker peoples, to discover the secret of the white man’s power, and then without revolutionary violence is [to] change her whole civilization and attitude toward the world, so as to emerge in the twentieth century the equal in education, technique, health, industry and art of any nation on earth. It was a colossal task….it called for team work………………………………….….Footnote 9
 Yet, the affinities that the West defined as being fundamental to racial identity did not lead to mutual recognition and group-ness between China and Japan. In the treaty that ended the conflict, Russia ceded influence over Korea to Japan and turned over its leases in the Liaotung Pennisula and the southern half of the Sakhalin Islands. The Japanese population was angered that it did not get additional territory or monetary reparations. This only fueled Japanese militarism, leading to the outcome that Du Bois had warned about in his essay “What Japan has Done”—a militarized and economically prosperous Japan mirroring the American/European models in their aggression against other Asian states. For Chinese reformers and revolutionaries, Japan was poised to exploit China’s weaknesses, as had the white Western states. If China did not develop its ability to group, they faced extinction as a culture and a civilization. On the other hand, it also re-emphasized the importance of the ability to group within the state. Without this ability, the Chinese socio-political order would always lose in confrontations with white European states and Japan. During this same period, as China and the Chinese appeared less able to unite for a common purpose, a series of internal rebellions—the Taiping Rebellion, a civil war in the south, and the Nian Rebellion in northern Anhui Province, along with the two great Muslim rebellions in Yunnan (1856–1873) and Shaanxi/Gansu (1862–1873)—demonstrated how the Chinese socio-political order was increasingly fractured. These rebellions strengthened local elites at the expense of imperial forces, splintering China at a time when other more unified states were gaining power. Desperate to stave off extinction, both Liang and Sun Yatsen turned to identity as a political concept for the salvation of the civilization. The concept of identity defined a unity of peoples called the “Han” linked by their common descent from the Yellow Emperor. At that time, the Han lived under the Qing imperial order, which was controlled by a non-Han group, the Manchus. To save China, the Han would have to remove from power all of those of irreconcilable difference, those who are not “tongzhong”—externally, this meant the West and, internally this meant the Manchus. In a lecture delivered in 1924, entitled “Chinese Nationalistic Spirit”, revolutionary and father of a representative republican political order in China, Sun Yatsen, said, According to the law of social evolution, the fittest survive, and the weak are killed by the strong….at present Great Britain and the United States are the most powerful nations in the world…If either Great Britain or American should conquer the world, it would become du qiang (独强) or “the Single Power”. Could it be ethnically justified, if the Chinese nation were conquered by Britain and the Chinese people were made British subjects?..... Naturally we would not feel comfortable in our conscience. That means that our spirit of nationalism still exists…Nationalism is the means of existence for a race, just as a scholar depends upon his pen and ink to earn his living…I fear that we may perish in the near future……………….Footnote 10
 For young revolutionaries, a sense of groupness would be facilitated by ending an imperial system where “tongzhong” did not dominate. Control by a non-Han group, the Manchus, who were under the control of foreign, European powers, had to end. To ensure the survival of Han Chinese civilization and Chinese territorial sovereignty, the Han needed to institutionalize a national political constitutional regime. Both Liang and Sun inaugurated their programs through political parties. Liang launched the Baohuanghui or “Protect the Emperor” Party for a constitutional monarchy and Sun formed the Tong Men Hui (Alliance League 同 盟黨) and began promoting the replacement of the imperial system with a republican style government. Sun’s formula for groupness, the San Min (三民主義) doctrine, “The Three Principles of the People”, would provide the necessary salvation for China, “…by promoting the recognition of China as the equal of other nations; by producing political equilibrium and economic justice, it will fit China for perpetual existence in the world.” The three principles were (1) nationalism, (2) democracy, and (3) people’s livelihood. Sun’s formulation exposed the ambiguity of the concepts of “race”, “nation”, and “nationality” in modern Chinese politics. Their racialized group, translated as “zu” (族), a term used to refer to lineage groups including a geographical and biological referent, would exist within the notion of minzu (民族), meaning nation as an ethnicized, community, linked by blood like a large clan (zongzu 宗族). Like Liang, Sun believed that this racial “zu”, the yellow race, included only Han, not Manchu. For both men, the guomin (国民 nation), signifying a political community, would be fused with a minzu (nationality 民族), creating an ethno-national community of biologically descendant Han Chinese, a racial state.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Race/Ethnicity and Education Effects on Employment in High Technology Industries and Occupations in the US, 1992–2002
Intro: Policymakers, entrepreneurs, and others pursue a variety of policies to stimulate the formation and expansion of technology based industries that create innovations, which provide many benefits and play a central role in economic growth. When compared to industries as a whole, technology based industries, in particular the high technology sector employ higher than average numbers of scientists and engineers, who are critical to the success of the ventures. Science and engineering (S&E) jobs require high levels of skills to drive the creation of knowledge that produces innovations; and society places a high value on these jobs, which often are more highly rewarded than many other types of jobs. African Americans, Hispanics, and others continue to lag behind whites and Asians in the level of educational attainment, particularly in S&E studies despite making educational gains since the mid-1970s (NCES 2003). It is possible that racial/ethnic differences in human capital investments in S&E fields of study could result in a representation and reward structure in high technology industries that is divided along racial lines even though no deliberate acts of discrimination exist. On the other hand, it is possible that the demand for highly skilled, technical individuals may result in employment opportunities and wage premiums for minorities with the requisite skills that are as high as or even higher than those enjoyed by whites. Although it is argued that the competitive demand and supply of skills play the major role in determining employment in high skill, high reward jobs, Grodsky and Pager (2001) found that black men suffer greater racial penalties in highly rewarded occupations. Thus it is not clear that the demand for skill will outweigh long-standing prejudices and discrimination against qualified blacks and Hispanics. Further, since the number of minority-owned companies as well as the social networks that contribute to employment are typically weak or absent in African American communities (Wilson 1996), the potential for African Americans, Hispanics and other minority groups to participate in and establish successful high technology businesses may not be as strong as whites. This paper explores the question of whether the effects of education on employment in S&E jobs in high technology industries as well as outside this sector are the same for minorities and the white majority during the period 1992 to 2002. This study uses multinomial regression analyses to systematically examine effects of changes in the level of educational attainment on the employment patterns of minorities and the white majority in order to determine the relative importance of human capital (educational attainment and experience), race and other factors on employment in four groups of jobs demarcated by the intersection of high technology industries and S&E occupations.

Title: What Does a High School Diploma Get You? Employment, Race, and the Transition to Adulthood

Title: Spatial and Racial Patterning of Real Estate Broker Listings in New York City

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Effect of Nativity, Ethnicity and Race on the Earnings of Cape Verdean Americans
Intro: In 2010, black immigrants to the US and their offspring comprised about 12 % of the US black population (Rong and Brown 2002). Because African Americans have suffered economic shortfalls for so long, experts and the public worry about the labor market outcomes of this growing population. Do they earn less than similarly qualified whites? Do they earn less than similarly qualified African Americans? Is their foreign birth a handicap? Is their ethnicity? To be sure, black immigrants are a diverse group. But, to date, scholars have methodologically rigorous answers only in the case of English-speaking West Indians (Geschwender 2003; Kalmijn 1996; Dodoo 1997; Model 1991, 1995, 2008). Research on other black ethnic groups has yet to disentangle the effects of race, ethnicity and nativity (Cotton 1993; Darity et al. 1995; Bradbury 2002). The present paper seeks to remedy this gap by examining the earnings of Cape Verdean Americans, a group with African and European roots who speak a Portuguese-based Creole. In their homeland, most Cape Verdeans identify racially as mestiço (or mixed). But residents of the US honor the ‘one-drop rule’, a custom that labels ‘black’ all persons with any visible African ancestry. Cape Verdeans merit study for several reasons. First, they have a long history in the US; thus, unlike most immigrant groups with some African ancestry, their native born population does not consist disproportionately of young labor force entrants. Second, Cape Verdeans’ skin tone ranges from light to dark, but many are reluctant to identify as ‘black’. Finally, Cape Verdean culture is a unique blend of African and Portuguese elements (Halter 1993, 2009; Lobban 1984; Meintel 1984). This cultural and linguistic heritage may have consequences for labor market success. The data come from the 2000 US Census and eight waves of the American Community Survey. The paper is organized as follows. First some background on Cape Verdeans in their homeland and in the US is offered. This is followed by a summary of relevant theory and research. The data analysis comes next: a description of the sample, a synopsis of the methods, and a report of the results. The paper ends with a discussion of its implications and a plea for further research on black ethnic groups.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Elected Versus Appointed County Commission Executives: Race, Political Favors and Support Facilities

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Community Development Credit Unions: Securing and Protecting Assets in Black Communities
