Immigrants arriving during the 1990s rapidly increased from 1 % of the labor force in 1994 to 6.5 % of the labor force in 2003 and remained at about 6 % through 2012. Except for immigrants arriving during the mid-2000s, all other immigrants represented a declining share of the US labor force. Immigrants in US workforce, by year of arrival: 1994–2012 Table 1 shows the ancestral origin, race, and ethnicity of immigrants. Mexicans were 29 % of all US immigrants during 1994–2000, but increased to 33 % during 2008–2012. Canadians and Europeans are an increasingly smaller share of US immigrants, falling from 2 to 1.5 % and from 14 to 10 %, respectively. Today’s immigrants are increasingly additions to America’s racial and ethnic minority groups. For example, the black immigrant share rose from 8 % in 1994–2000 to 10 % in 2008–2012, while Hispanic immigrant share rose from 46 to 50 % during the same period. Much of the literature on the effects of immigration on labor market outcomes of native workers has focused on males. Accordingly, Figs. 2, 3, and 4 present important labor market outcomes for native African American males: employment-population ratio, mean weekly workhours, and mean weekly wages for 1994–2012. Each outcome provides a sharp contrast with the long term increase in the immigrant share of the US labor force. Employment-population ratio, African American males, 1993–2011 Mean weekly hours, native African American males, 1993–2011 Mean weekly wage, native African American males, 1993–2011 If immigrants and native African Americans are substitutes, the canonical neoclassical model of immigration predicts a negative relationship between native wages and increases in immigration in the short-run, as well as a negative relationship between native participation and employment and increases in immigration in the short-run. However, African American malewages, employment, and participation did not decline in the 1990s as the immigration share of the labor force increased. Instead, the African American male employment-population ratio rose from 64 % to 71 % during 1993–1999, while mean weekly workhours increased by 2 h from 30.6 to 32.6 during the same period—a 6.5 % increase in weekly workhours. Mean wages of African American males rose from about $702 in 1993 to $866 percent in 2002. The labor market outcomes of African American males did decrease during the 2000s, but this was a period of much slower immigration than during the 1990s. Rather than immigration, the recessions of 2001–2002 and 2007–2009 appear to the primary factors pulling down the employment, participation, and wages of African American males. Table 2 summarizes the data presented in Figs. 2, 3, and 4. Each entry is the slope coefficient from a bivariate regression of a labor market outcome on the aggregate immigrant share or alternative arrival cohorts. When we consider all arrivals, a one percentage point increase in the share of immigrants is correlated with 0.75 h reduction in weekly work time, 0.01 % reduction in the labor force participation of African American males, and 2.15 % increase in the wage rate. Our data cover a period of 18 years and contains three business cycles: 1994–2001, 2002–2007, 2008–2012. The transition years, that is, 2001–2002 and 2007–2009, represent the onset of recessions and the beginning of recoveries. Investment spending falls rapidly during recessions and rises rapidly during recoveries; hence, the transition years represent periods of rapid capital adjustment and provide a natural demarcation of the short-run versus the long-run. Per the canonical neoclassical model of immigration, we would expect the coefficients of Table 2 to be zero. The “all arrivals” coefficients for employment and participants are not zero, but they are small. The “all arrivals” coefficient for the wage equation is large and has the wrong side. The short-run effects of immigration are associated with the most recent arrivals, while the long-run effects of immigration are associated with the most distant arrivals. Hence, the coefficients should be negative and decreasing in absolute value as we move from the 1990s arrivals to pre-1965 arrivals (LaLonde and Topel 1991). Focusing on the coefficients of the arrival cohorts, none of the coefficients have the expected pattern. A one percentage point increase in the share of immigrants who arrived before the Immigration Act of 1965, a minimum of 30 years before the labor market outcomes of 1994–2012, is associated with an increase of 3.65 h of weekly work for African American males, an increase of 0.06 percentage points in the fraction employed, but a 8.7 % reduction in weekly wages. Additionally, as we moved forward from pre-1965 to the most recent arrival cohorts the coefficients for workhours and fraction employed do increase in absolute value but the coefficients are not positive and, hence, are also moving in the wrong direction. For 1990s arrivals, the effect on employment is small and not significant, while the coefficient on wages is positive and large. Collectively considered, these correlations are not completely consistent with the canonical neoclassical theory of immigration. But, Table 2 does establish that the labor market effects of older cohorts (longrun effects) are quite different from the labor market effects of recent cohorts (shortrun effects). Of course, Table 2 provides only unadjusted correlations and hence cannot be used to provide a definitive analysis of the substitutability of African American and immigrant workers.Footnote 2 Competitive substitution in the labor market is in some measure related to whether or not groups have similar regional distributions and similar skills (education and age). Fifty-six percent (1994–2000)–59 % (2001–2010) percent of native African American workers ages 16–64 reside in the South (Table 3). Thirty percent of working-age native Latinos reside in this region. However, the Southern fraction of native Hispanics is heavily weighted by the number of Mexican Americans residing in Texas, the second most populous state in the US. Texas is culturally and geographically Southern and Western, but the CPS identifies Texas as a Southern state. African Americans are 12 % of the population of Texas and mostly live in East Texas and the cities of Houston and Dallas. Mexican Americans are 36 % of the population of Texas and are predominately residents of Western, Southern, Northern, and Central Texas, and the cities of San Antonio, Dallas, Austin, Houston, and El Paso. In short, after accounting for the idiosyncrasies of Texas, far fewer than 30 % of native Hispanics live in the South. Both native and immigrant Hispanics are much more likely to reside in the West, where only 8 % of African Americans reside but 42–48 % of Latinos reside. Moreover, throughout the 1990s and 2000s about ½ of Hispanic immigrants are high school dropouts versus 20 % of native African Americans. Blacks are twice as likely to be college graduates. These regional and educational differences constrain African American—Hispanic job market competition. Immigrant African Americans have increased their presence in the South. During 1994–2000, 34 % (men) and 31 % (women) of black immigrants ages 16–64 resided in the South. By 2001–2010, 38 % of black immigrants were Southern residents. Hence, both native and immigrant African Americans are migrating to the South, which suggests increasing intra-regional competition for employment. Among males during 1994–2000, 23 % of immigrant blacks have one or more college degrees versus 11 % of native blacks; among women, 20 % of immigrant blacks have one or more college degrees versus 13 % of native blacks. Native African Americans were not more likely to compete with immigrant blacks for college jobs during the 2000s: 29 and 14 % of immigrant and native black males, respectively, had at least one college degree, while 23 and 17 % of immigrant and native black women, respectively, had at least one college degree. So, although both native and immigrant blacks are increasingly living in the South, they have different levels of education. Asian immigrants are 1.5 to 2 years older than native African Americans, predominately Western residents (41–47 %), and about 3–4 times as likely to have at least one college degree. All of which suggests prima facie evidence of limited job market competition between native African Americans and immigrant Asians. The Northeast is America’s most populous region. Native whites are the only group whose Northeastern representation did not decline during 1994–2010 and they are also the only group whose Southern representation declined during 1994–2010. All other groups, especially black immigrants, experienced decreases in Northeastern residential location and increases in Southern residential location. Indeed, immigrant blacks also had large increases in their Northcentral location. Table 4 presents immigrant shares of the workforce by age, education, and workyear. The maximum immigrant share occurs for dropouts (persons with less than 12 years of education) who are 31 to 50 years of age. The immigrant share rose from 32 % in 1994 (the highest share for any age-education group in that year) to 53 % in 2010 (also, the highest share for any age-education group in that year). For all workers with less than 12 years of education, the immigrant share rose from 22 % in 1994 to 30 % in 2010. About 1 in 5 African American workers are in this education group (Table 3). For senior workers, that is, persons 51 to 64 years of age, immigrants are less than or equal to 10 % of the labor force for persons with at least 12 years of education. For young and middle age workers, the immigrant share is about 10 to 16 % for high school graduates and is 13 % for persons with a graduate degree. The pattern of immigrant shares suggests that to the extent that immigration has a significant effect on employment and wages, the effects will be greatest for high school dropouts and high school graduates (persons with only 12 years of education), especially for prime-age workers. For 2001–2010, we note then that Table 1 shows that 59 % of native African American male workers and 54 % of native African American female workers are within the education groups facing the highest immigration shares.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Dynamics of African-American Health: A Historical Perspective
Intro: There is now a growing body of evidence pertaining to the historical health of the African American population, and this data is currently being used to uncover a number of facts about the historical dynamics of African American health. In this paper, we dispel the myth that our historical data on the health of African Americans is wholly lacking and at the same time show that one prominent myth about trends in African American health does not stand up to historical investigation. Chowkwanyun (2011) notes that analysis of health disparities requires historical investigation. This review is based on ongoing research we have performed on historical dimensions of African American health and human capital (Logan 2009; Logan and Parman 2011), and we review and reframe those previous findings in light of the myths they dispel. We conclude with a brief note about where this research is headed and what future topics should be explored in African American economic and health history. The most prominent conjecture, motivated by contemporary scholarship, is that much of what we attribute to racial differences in health over time (say, mortality or morbidity differences) can rightly be explained by socioeconomic differences such as occupation or income. The argument has intuitive appeal—if both race and socioeconomic status are related to health outcomes and if the racial distribution of socioeconomic status is skewed, then part of what we attribute to racial differences is actually due to socioeconomic differences. This same type of argument has been applied to many other areas of well-being: schooling, income, family formation and composition, labor force attachment, involvement in the criminal justice system, and the like. The general idea is that socioeconomics plays its own role in these sorts of disparities, and to the extent that African Americans are concentrated at the lower end of the socioeconomic spectrum, the results we attribute to race should be qualified. Despite the large attention paid to health disparities at present, we know very little about historical dimensions of the relationships. To unpack the myth we must collect and analyze data that looks at a long period of time and that allows us to distinguish between the racial and socioeconomic differences in mortality so that decomposition can be attempted. Building on the pioneering matching methodology described by Preston et al. (1996) and the general techniques laid out by Fogel (1993), we obtain a random sample of death certificates from the Carolinas at 5 year intervals from 1910 to 1970. The Carolina death certificates also contain the usual occupation of the deceased, which allows us to estimate the racial and socioeconomic relationships mortality relationships over the twentieth century. We also advance the field by using the detailed information on the death certificates, which list cause of death, allowing us to look at racial and socioeconomic differences in cause specific mortality over the twentieth century. We find that controlling for occupation actually increases the racial gap in mortality over the twentieth century. African Americans in high-status occupations died at earlier ages than blacks in general, and we show that this result is robust to a number of criticisms. Contrary to the claim that racial gaps in health outcomes are partially explained by socioeconomic differences, the results of our preliminary analysis suggest that racial gaps in mortality were largest at the highest socioeconomic positions over much of the twentieth century. Rather than acting as a buffer for mortality outcomes, high socioeconomic status among African Americans led to higher mortality in the past.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Hispanic Self-identification and Birth Weight Outcomes among U.S.- and Foreign-born Blacks
Intro: Economists are devoting increasing amounts of attention to understanding the long term effects of early life health for good reason: evidence demonstrates that poor health at birth affects health throughout childhood, adolescence and adulthood (Masho and Archer 2011; Fanaroff et al. 2007; Currie and Gruber 1996; Green 2011; Barker 1993). Suboptimal health is also related to low human capital acquisition and poor labor market outcomes (Aarnoudse-Moens et al. 2009; Johnson and Schoeni 2011). This issue is particularly relevant and critical for the black population in the United States. In comparison to white children, black children are more likely to be born at low birth weights and to die before the age of one (Mathews and MacDorman 2011). However, these overall infant health trends mask several key within-group differences among blacks. This paper addresses two potentially important sources of heterogeneity among blacks: Hispanic ethnicity and immigrant status. An extensive body of research reports that Hispanic immigrant mothers, despite having socioeconomic profiles similar to those of non-Hispanic blacks and lower levels of adequate prenatal care, tend to have birth outcomes (e.g. low birth weight and infant mortality) that approximate those of non-Hispanic whites. This phenomenon is widely known as the Hispanic paradox (Hummer et al. 2007). While these infant health advantages appear to diminish with the duration of maternal residence and over successive generations (Acevedo-Garcia et al. 2007; Teitler et al. 2012), overall, Hispanic mothers, both native- and foreign-born, exhibit better birth outcomes compared to those of non-Hispanic blacks (Hummer et al. 2007). Public health researchers have hypothesized that these better-than-expected outcomes can be attributed to factors such as lower rates of prenatal smoking, better nutrition, family support and protective cultural characteristics (McGlade et al. 2004; Guendelman and Abrams 1995; Weigers and Sherraden 2001; Singh and Siahpush 2002). Sociologists and economists also point out that selection on health-related factors or other characteristics may also be important factors in driving immigrant health advantages (Palloni and Arias 2004; Antecol and Bedard 2006). These patterns do not necessarily hold across all groups. For example, Landale et al. (Landale et al. 2000) find that infant mortality among Puerto Rican migrants is substantially lower among recent migrants to the U.S. mainland compared to those women remaining in Puerto Rico. Despite evidence that the salience of the Hispanic paradox differs widely across Hispanic subgroups (Acevedo-Garcia et al. 2007; Landale et al. 2000), we know very little about the birth outcomes of self-identified black Hispanics. Racial identity is a complex entity among Hispanics, with many subgroups preferring to identify with their (ancestral) land of origin. While Hispanics are also far more likely to identify as white than black (Mason 1997), recent data indicate that black Hispanics, or Afro-Latinos are a small but growing part of the black and Hispanic populations. Self-identified black Hispanics (and those with darker skin and less European features) are more likely to experience worse educational, labor market and discrimination related outcomes compared to their non-black Hispanic counterparts (Mason 1997, 2004; Arce et al. 1987; Darity et al. 1996; Cotton 1993).Footnote 1 Empirical results from studies of health-related outcomes are mixed (Codina and Montalvo 1994; Montalvo and Codina 2001), but overall, Hispanic women (and men) are also less likely than non-Hispanics to carry health insurance, and the same is true for immigrants compared to the native-born (Derose et al. 2007). While each of these socioeconomic factors may indirectly contribute to worsened birth outcomes, few studies have explored how black Hispanics compare to their non-Hispanic black counterparts. Two important exceptions are Reichman and Kenney (1998) and Howard et al. (2006). In their descriptive study of Hispanic and non-Hispanic mothers in New Jersey, Reichman and Kenney (1998) find that black Hispanic mothers (e.g. Puerto Rican and other Hispanic) are less likely than non-Hispanic blacks to give birth to low birth weight infants. Immigrants, regardless of ethnicity, are less likely than the native-born to give birth to low birth weight infants, and have lower rates of infant mortality (Reichman and Kenney 1998). Howard et al. (2006) find substantial differences in low birth weight and preterm birth across black women of varying ethnic groups. While West Indian, Brazilian and Cuban blacks seem to have similar rates of low birth weight as U.S.-born blacks, black mothers from South and Central America and Africa are comparatively less likely to have a low birth weight infant. Similarly, blacks from South and Central America and Africa are less likely to give birth prematurely. In addition, work using data from New York City suggests that Hispanic groups with greater degrees of African ancestry are more likely to have small for gestational age (SGA) infants (Stein et al. 2009). However, the above studies are of limited generalizability due to limited geographic scope (Reichman and Kenney 1998; Stein et al. 2009; Howard et al. 2006). Furthermore, it is still unclear whether significant differences exist between non-Hispanic and Hispanic blacks across nativity, especially on a national level. Prior research finds that the birth outcomes of foreign-born blacks are superior to those of U.S. blacks, including low birth weight, preterm birth, and infant mortality (David and Collins 1997; Pallotto et al. 2000; Collins et al. 2002). Similar advantages exist among black immigrant adults for a number of health-related outcomes, including self-reported health (Hamilton and Hummer 2011) and disability (Elo et al. 2011). While better health behaviors and socioeconomic advantages may explain a small part of the infant health gap (Elo and Culhane 2010; Cabral et al. 1990; Kent 2007), many of the reasons for these health differences are still unclear. Moreover, while the infants born to black immigrants generally are healthier compared to those of U.S.-born blacks, black infants as a whole are still worse off than non-black infants with respect to rates of very low birth weight and infant mortality (Pallotto et al. 2000; Green et al. In press). Less clear is whether U.S.-and foreign-born Hispanic mothers experience similar patterns of infant health outcomes (Elo and Culhane 2010; Green et al. In press; Acevedo-Garcia et al. 2005a). To remedy these gaps in the literature, this paper addresses two key questions using a large national sample of black mothers. First, I examine whether black Hispanic immigrant mothers give birth to higher birth weight infants compared to U.S.-born black Hispanic mothers. I address a similar issue among non-Hispanic black mothers. Second, I examine whether there are Hispanic/non-Hispanic birth weight differences among both the native- and foreign-born. The latter question is important because it is likely that immigrants are positively selected on health, potentially making within-nativity comparisons a more appropriate test of an ethnic health advantage (Antecol and Bedard 2006). In supplementary analyses, I test for differences in prenatal care initiation and smoking between Hispanic/non-Hispanic immigrants and native-born mothers. To my knowledge, this is the first study to address these questions using a national sample of births. The remainder of this paper will proceed as follows. Section 2 provides a description of the data and estimation sample. Section 3 briefly describes the empirical approach and Section 4 contains a summary of the empirical results. The paper concludes in Section 5 with a discussion and future directions for this research agenda.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Assets and African Americans: Attempting to Capitalize on Hopes for Children Through College Savings Accounts

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Persistent Myths of “Acting White” and Race Neutral Alternatives to Affirmative Action in Admissions
Intro: Education is a vehicle to opportunity. Better educated individuals have higher earnings (Card 1999), lower levels of unemployment, better health (Cutler and Lleras-Muney 2008), and higher levels of civic participation (Dee 2004). Given that education makes lives better, it is important that policies that purport to enhance educational outcomes are based on firm evidence. With regards to the education of blacks in the United States, two prevailing issues are performance and access. Blacks, on average, lag behind whites in academic performance along a number of dimensions-for example, high school graduation rates, standardized test scores, and college attendance. Access to selective postsecondary institutions for blacks is a controversial issue. The Theory of “Acting White”-which is best understood as a special case of the oppositional culture hypothesis (Fordham and Ogbu 1986)-has been offered as an explanation for the deficits in educational performance for blacks despite the lack of hard evidence in support of this hypothesis. Affirmative Action-which in the context of higher education allows race to be used as a factor in college admission-is a heavily debated policy that contends with race-neutral admission policies that are alleged to be as effective as policies that use race explicitly. Both “Acting White” and Affirmative Action are two politically charged topics that have been sources of misinformation and myths. The purpose of this article is to examine these topics in light of the information provided by extant scholarship. Fordham and Ogbu (1986) introduced the concept of the “Burden of ‘acting white’”, which is a special case of oppositional culture hypothesis. Oppositional culture hypothesis is a term used to explain racial disparities in educational achievement particularly in sociology. Some of the behaviors that are associated with “acting white” within this paper are speaking standard English, spending alot of time in the library studying, working hard to get good grades in school, being on time, and reading and writing poetry. The hypotheses about these behaviors and others described in the paper essentially state that blacks associate good academic performance with “acting white”, where “acting white” consists of blacks adopting behaviors that are associated with whites. The theory states that the fear of being accused of “acting white” engenders opposition to behaviors that are associated with “acting white”-for example, academic achievement- and thus leads to underachievement. Fordham and Ogbu use ethnographic techniques to investigate this hypothesis. The authors interview eight black students who discuss their experiences in school and also draw on Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s experiences as support for the hypothesis. Although this study was a weak foundation on which to build a strong argument, it has received a great deal of coverage in the press as an explanation for the black-white academic achievement gap. In his keynote address to the democratic convention in 2004, then Illinois State Senator, Barack Obama, described the phenomenon of “acting white” as a barrier to black educational progress. Despite poignant anecdotes and public proclamations, there is significant evidence that is inconsistent with the framework put forth by Fordham and Ogbu (1986). A number of ethnographic studies have examined the “acting white” hypothesis. Table 1 describes the sample of students who were interviewed in five such studies. Peterson-Lewis and Barton (2004) find that their subjects provide a positive description of “being black” with respect to fashion but articulate a negative association between “being black” and academics, behavior, disposition and impression. This lends some credence to the belief that doing well in school could be considered “acting white.” However, Bergin and Cooks (2002) find that interviewees do not shun superior academic performance for fear of being labeled as “acting white.” They also find that respondents do not perceive that they achieved superior academic performance at the expense of their ethnicity and are offended rather than demoralized by “accusations of ‘acting white.’ ” Tyson et al. (2005) find evidence consistent with the burden of “acting white” in only 2 of 40 black students that they interview. They find little evidence which suggests that the burden of "acting white" is the primary reason that blacks perform poorly in school. Diamond et al. (2007) find that relative to Caucasian students a larger fraction of African American students view their race as a determinant of their success. Interestingly, Diamond et al. (2007) also find that Caucasians are as likely as African Americans to be labeled negatively as a result of superior academic performance; that is, for their sample, superior academic performance adversely affects social standing and these effects are not limited to African Americans. Taken together, the above papers demonstrate that the qualitative evidence does not consistently support "acting white” as an explanation for the achievement gap between blacks and whites. Few quantitative papers find evidence that consistently supports “acting white” as a plausible explanation for the black white achievement gap. The quantitative papers that examine “acting white” in large data sets propose a set of suppositions that should hold in the data if the “acting white” hypothesis is salient. Cook and Ludwig (1997) examine the implications of “acting white” using the National Education Longitudinal Study of 1988 (NELS 88). They put forth three testable hypotheses that should be borne out by the data if the differences in academic performance are indeed driven by “acting white”: (1) If acting white is salient, then blacks should show more antipathy towards school than non-Hispanic whites. (2) If acting white is salient, then blacks should incur social penalties from their peers for succeeding academically. (3) If these social penalties exist, then they should be greater for blacks than they are for whites. With regards to the first testable hypothesis, Cook and Ludwig (1997) find no evidence that is consistent with blacks having more antipathy than whites with respect to schooling. They also find that whites are more likely to have ten or more days absent from school than are blacks, that African American parents areas involved in children's educations as are white parents of similar means, and that black parents are more likely than white parents to check homework. These findings are inconsistent with the first hypothesis. The authors also find little evidence that supports the second testable hypothesis. In direct contradiction to what “acting white” would predict, the authors find that “black students at predominantly black schools are rewarded by their peers for membership in an honor society.” The authors find evidence that the penalty structure differs between blacks and whites; however, the penalty scores favor blacks which is inconsistent with the third testable hypothesis. While one cannot conclude from a single analysis on a nationally representative sample of eighth graders that “acting white” does not exist, we can say that with respect to this particular sample taken at this particular time there is little to suggest that “acting white” provides a plausible explanation for black-white differences in academic performance. Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998), using the NELS 88 as a source of data, test four hypotheses that are consistent with the oppositional culture model, which includes “acting white”, being cause of the black-white gap in academic performance. In this paper, immigrant minorities are individuals who migrated to the host country of their own freewill and involuntary minorities are groups that were historically enslaved, colonized, or conquered. In their sample, Asian Americans are the immigrant minorities. Although their hypotheses discuss results in terms of comparing whites with immigrant (Asian Americans ) and involuntary minorities (blacks) ,for ease of comparison, the results will be explained in the context of black and white. The first hypothesis states that “involuntary minority students perceive fewer returns to education and more limited occupational opportunities than do dominant students or immigrant minority students.” They find no support for this hypothesis and find that “African American students are significantly more likely than white students to report that education is important to get a job and to have more optimistic occupational expectations.” The second hypothesis states the following: “involuntary minority students exhibit greater resistance to school than do dominant students or immigrant minority students.” The empirical evidence is mixed with respect to the second hypothesis. When the authors focus on skills, habits, and styles, their results are consistent with the oppositional culture model. However, when focusing on attitudes towards education, they find that African American and Asian students are more positive about school than white students. Their third hypothesis states the following: “high-achieving involuntary minority students are negatively sanctioned by their peers for their achievements.” The authors find that “African American students are especially popular when they are good students” and “African American students report more pro-school values among their peers than do white students.” This is inconsistent with the third hypothesis. The fourth hypothesis in Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998) consists of the following supposition: “resistance to school” accounts for the racial gap in school performance between involuntary students and dominant students and immigrant minority students.”Footnote 1They find little to support this hypothesis and state that “it would be a mistake to conclude that racial differences in school performance are solely a result of variations in school behavior.” Given the scant support they find for efficacy of the oppositional culture model, the authors argue that people want to believe the theory and ignore the evidence to the contrary. If this is the case, then policy responses that are based on the oppositional culture model as a primary mechanism that produces disadvantage will likely fail because they direct resources to alter a set of behaviors that explain little of the gap. In contrast to the previous papers, Ferguson (2001) examines the differences in academic performance for a smaller sample. This dataset encompasses virtually all seventh through eleventh graders in Shaker Heights at the end of the spring semester in 1999. Shaker Heights is a relatively affluent community, so by looking within this, Ferguson is attempting to compare black and white students from similar socioeconomic backgrounds.Footnote 2 Having “accounted” for socioeconomic status, it is easier than to relate observed differences in academic performance between blacks and whites to causes that are not rooted in socioeconomic differences. Ferguson makes six main points, and while the explicit purpose of the paper is not to prove or disprove "acting white" per se, the results do speak to some of the premises of "acting white." The first finding is that skills much more than effort lead to the black-white GPA gap. The second finding is that “blacks report spending as much (or more) time doing homework, but a lower rate of homework completion.” Ferguson posits that this result not only makes it appear to teachers that blacks put forth less effort, but also shows that the peer culture of black students in Shaker Heights are not more opposed to achievement. The third result is that “attitudes and behaviors are more important for predicting within- race than between-race GPA disparities.”Footnote 3 The “acting white” hypothesis posits that attitudes and behaviors are sufficient to explain between-race differences which is not found in this research. The fourth result is that achievement gaps must be clearly thought out and divided into a. what the students know, b. the pace at which they learn, c. strategies and techniques to help them learn at an improved rate, d. effort the student chooses, and e. how everyone is different. Ferguson uses an analogy of two tribes running where there are no systematic differences in effort and ability between the two tribes. For the most part the White tribe is ahead of the Black tribe. Ferguson suggests that it a set of norms and investments that the White Tribe receives that result in the differences in academic performance. How can the Black Tribe catch up without “running faster”?, when there are no shortcuts. He suggests effective coaching and addressing social pressures that place more emphasis on activities-for example, watching television-that are important socially but use time that could put towards academics. The fifth result is that all segments of the school community report negative peer pressures. Black and white students who are not in honor or AP seem more inclined to hold back effort than those in honors or AP courses and black and white students in similar courses do differ in their propensity to hold back. The sixth result is that honors and AP courses maybe socially isolating for black students, which may diminish the degree to which black students aspire to take such classes. Ferguson states that the “black-white GPA gap in Shaker Heights seems to be attributable to a gap in skills rather than a gap in effort.” He provides additional evidence that African American students do not appear to be more opposed to schooling than whites from similar backgrounds. Ferguson suggests that policy should focus on providing “more effective and efficient learning techniques and strategies, so that the pace of new learning can accelerate as the level of effort increases.” Harris (2006) provides an extensive empirical test of the oppositional culture theory using the Maryland Adolescence Development in Context Study (MADICS). Like Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998), Harris tests five hypotheses that are consistent with the oppositional culture model. The first hypothesis is the following: “Black children perceive fewer returns to education and more limited opportunities for upward social education and more limited opportunities for upward social mobility than white children.” He finds that “black students report greater returns to education and have higher educational aspirations than whites” which goes against the hypothesis. “Black children have less favorable affect toward school than whites.” He finds that “both groups experience similar rates of decline over time in school affect and feeling that class enjoyment is important for their school attendance.” These findings suggest that attitude is not the driving force behind white-black achievement differences. “Black children exhibit greater resistance to school than whites.”He finds that blacks “seek help more and spend the same amount of time on homework and educational activities than whites.” He also finds that blacks do not skip school more, but are in trouble more in school. “High achieving black children are negatively sanctioned by their peers to a greater degree than high achieving white children: the “ ‘acting white' hypothesis” His findings suggest “the fear of appearing white for performing well in school is not the reason for difference in school performance between” poor and good performing blacks. He also finds that “students’ level of school performance is not related to their ability to make friends.” “The peer groups of black children have a greater counter-educational culture than those of white children.” He finds that “black students do not have peers that engage in negative behaviors more than whites after controlling for differences in SES.” Harris’s evidence is somewhat generalizable as his results are similar to those of Cook and Ludwig (1997), Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998), and Ferguson (2001) He concludes that “black youths want to learn; they simply are not acquiring skills necessary for academic success.” Fryer and Torelli (2010) use the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health) which allows for a different measure of social status in a nationally representative sample. Social status is constructed using an index of friendship measures within the sample. The empirical analysis in the paper tests the prediction of a formal game theoretic model of “acting white” that couches the problem as a “two-audience signaling problem”. (See Fryer Jr et al. (2005)) The predictions from the game theoretic model differ from the notion of “acting white” that was put forth by Fordham and Ogbu. For example, the game theoretic model predicts that it is schools where minorities constitute a small percentage of the student body that are the types of schools where one will observe behavior consistent with “acting white” while Ogbu and Fordham argue (2) that their conceptualization of “acting white” as being applicable in schools where blacks are prevalent. In contrast to the aforementioned studies, Fryer and Torelli (2010) analyze Add Health and uncover three findings that are consistent with their notion of “acting white”: (1) The authors find a substantively large and statistically significant, relationship between popularity and grades that is robust to different empirical specifications and exists in various subsets of the data. For example, Fryer and Torelli point out that their notion of “acting white” is particularly salient for high achieving black students. (2) Fryer and Torelli find that the effects of “acting white”-that is, the relationship between popularity and grades-in schools where blacks are less than a fifth of the population is three times as large as the estimate that is obtained for the overall sample. (3) Fryer and Torelli find that eliminating the relationship between popularity and academic performance would yield significant reductions in the black-white test score gap, black-white effort gap, and the gap in the amount of time spent on homework. Fryer and Torelli perform a similar analysis using NELS 88, and find evidence consistent with the game theoretic notion of “acting white”. They conclude by acknowledging that “like Ferguson (2001) Cook and Ludwig (1997), and Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998),” they find “scant empirical support for the oppositional culture hypothesis described in Fordham and Ogbu (1986).” One reason that the "acting white" hypothesis continues to exist is that the previous results found tend to have some limitations. Cook and Ludwig (1997), Ainsworth-Darnell and Downey (1998) are both reliant on the use of self-reported data from NELS. This raises the possibility that differences in the accuracy of the information provided by black and white youths could bias the results. In their response to survey questions, black youths could be portraying themselves as being more academically committed than they actually are. Ferguson and Ronald (2001) and Harris (2006) both focus on relatively local datasets. Ferguson focuses on one school in Shaker Heights, Ohio, while Harris focuses on MADICS dataset which collects information on a sample of Maryland adolescents. In both cases it is hard to make generalizations to the larger population because of sample size issues. A limitation of Fryer and Torelli (2010) is the narrow definition of “acting white” that is academic achievement. The paper focuses solely on social status and academic achievement and implicitly assumes that high grades cause low popularity and not the inverse. In aggregate, the quantitative work that examines this topic-in particular, the work that uses large nationally representative data sets-provide little support for the conventional notion of “acting white” as a primary determinant of black-white achievement gaps. After viewing the evidence that is provided both for and against the hypothesis of the burden of “acting white” as a cause of the black-white achievement gap, we draw three main conclusions. First, the burden of being a high achiever is not something that is unique to blacks. Most studies find that whites struggle with this as well and do not support the notion that blacks are more antagonistic towards black high achievers than whites are with respect to white high achievers. Therefore it cannot be a primary cause of inter-racial gaps. Secondly, the majority of studies indicate that, on average, blacks put forth more effort and care about their performance than whites.Footnote 4 Finally, if the burden of “acting white” does occur, it occurs mainly at schools that are not predominantly black. Where does this evidence leave us? It leaves us with mixed findings in qualitative studies and scant support in the empirical studies. Again, there is little evidence that supports “acting white” as a reasonable explanation for the gaps in academic achievement; that is, the empirical evidence, on the main, does not support the notion that blacks’ attitudes towards education are a major contributor to black-white gaps in educational performance. However, there is evidence that suggests that teacher’s perceptions of minority students and their attitudes towards education impacts minority educational outcomes, primarily through teacher expectations. Ferguson (1998) finds that teachers’ expectations, perceptions, and behaviors maintain and exacerbate the racial achievement gap. Berry and III (2004) finds that the performance of African American males in math is particularly sensitive to teachers 'expectations. McKown and Weinstein (2008) find that teachers’ expectations of European American and Asian American students were between .75 and 1.00 standard deviations higher than were expectations for African American students. They estimate that the difference in expectations account for up to.36 standard deviations of the year end achievement gap. Preexisting negative stereotypes of minority intellectual ability-see, for example, Bobo (2001)-make it far too easy for teachers to fail to provide the supportive environment and appropriate standards that are necessary to encourage learning. Proposals that are currently being put forth to institute culturally sensitive teacher training can affect how teachers both perceive and interact with minority youth. Changes in teacher attitudes, along with a focus on adequate resources are likely to do more to increase academic performance than a reliance on strategies that change student attitudes to combat the “acting white” phenomenon that is not a strong explanation for performance gaps.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: You’re Fired!: The Impact of Race on the Firing of Black Head Coaches in Major College Football
Intro: Historically, college football has been characterized by an absence of black leadership at the head coaching position. In 2002, there were only four black head coaches at National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) schools, and as recently as 2008, there were just five, while around 50 % of FBS football student-athletes in each year were black (Miller 2012). In fact, in the 30 year period from 1982 to 2012, there were 546 head coaches hired in the NCAA’s Football Bowl Subdivision, but through the 2012 season only 41 black head coaches have been hired at FBS schools (Hightower 2012).Footnote 1 In 2012, while 51.6 % of FBS football student-athletes were black, there were only 15 black head coaches at the 120 FBS schools (Lapchick et al. 2013). While the majority of FBS football student-athletes are black, the vast majority of the head coaching jobs at FBS schools belong to white coaches. There are a number of reasons why so few blacks are hired to the most prominent leadership positions in college football: (1) there are very few minority athletic directors or school presidents, who are responsible for hiring head coaches, (2) there are very few minority head coaching candidates in the pipeline, and (3) there may be discrimination against black head coaching candidates.Footnote 2 However, there may also be a limited number of black head coaches at FBS schools because black head coaches are more likely to be fired, as I show in this paper. In what follows, I will provide a more in-depth discussion of the reasons why there is a disproportionally low number of black head football coaches at FBS schools. First, black candidates for head coaching positions may belong to different social networks than those making hiring decisions since there are a limited number of black athletic directors, who generally hire their school’s head football coach, and even fewer black school presidents, who generally hire the institution’s athletic director. Of the 120 institutions in the FBS, only nine of the athletic directors and five of the school presidents were African-American (Lapchick et al. 2013). Furthermore, all conference commissioners of FBS conferences were white (Lapchick et al. 2013). McDonald et al. (2009) show that differences in social network resources between whites and minorities can explain a substantial portion of the racial deficit in the number of job leads at the highest levels of supervisory authority, such as a head coaching position. According to Henry Frazier III, head football coach at Prairie View A&M, a Football Championship Subdivision school, “it has everything to do with relationships…you’re looking at presidents and athletic directors. If they don’t have relationships with minority candidates, then it’s going to be hard for them to hire them. I don’t think they just actually go out here and say, ‘I’m going to hire a white guy.’ They’re going to hire somebody that they have a relationship with to manage that organization (Turner 2009).” Additionally, there are very few black head coaching candidates at the coordinator level in the Football Bowl Subdivision. Overall, blacks held only 25.5 % of all assistant coaching positions in Division I football in 2012, but only 16.7 % of the offensive and defensive coordinator spots in the FBS were held by blacks (Lapchick et al. 2013, 2012).Footnote 3 Bozeman and Fay (2013) study the career trajectories of assistant coaches, and find that assistant coaches at certain positions are more likely to be elevated to offensive and defensive coordinators, who are then in turn more likely to be elevated to head coach. The catch-22 for blacks is that most coaches are hired to coach the position that they played at, and blacks have historically played at positions requiring a high amount of raw athletic ability, such as running back or wide receiver, than at positions requiring learned craft skills or strategy, such as quarterback, offensive line, or linebacker (Bozeman and Fay 2013).Footnote 4 In this vein, Bozeman and Fay show that among the 120 FBS head coaches, 27.3 % played quarterback, 11.8 % played offensive line, and 12.6 % played linebacker in college. Only 8.4 % and 1.7 % of current head coaches played wide receiver or running back, respectively. However, it is also possible that the correlation between coaching and position played is due to preferences for white coaches as discrimination against blacks could result in differences in position played among head coaches rather than be the reason why there are fewer black head coaches. Another potential reason for the limited number of minority hires in the head coaching ranks is that minorities are simply discriminated against. Sagas and Cunningham (2005) find that fewer promotions and further organizational proximity to the head coaching position among black assistant football coaches cannot be explained by racial differences in human or social capital.Footnote 5 Additionally, Cunningham et al. (2006) find that NCAA assistant football coaches are much more likely to view race as a barrier to getting a head coaching job than NCAA assistant basketball coaches. This may potentially be because blacks make up a much larger share of the television audience for basketball as compared to football, which athletic directors are accounting for either strategically or subconsciously. According to ESPN columnist Jemele Hill, “these athletic directors are, quite honestly, frightful that their donors and their communities won’t continue to support their schools financially if they hire a black coach” and are “using their economic situation as an excuse to continue…racist practices.” Furthermore, very few black head coaches receive a second chance. While there are currently 17 white FBS coaches that previously lost their jobs, it is well noted that Tyrone Willingham is the only black coach in NCAA history to be rehired by an FBS program after having been fired (Dillard 2013; Hightower 2012).Footnote 6 Upon his own dismissal from the University of Colorado, former head coach Jon Embree stated “We don’t get second chances. And that’s okay, you know it going into it…every minority coach knows that going into it (Hightower 2012).” It is irrefutable that the hiring rate of black head coaches in major college football is not representative of the number of student-athletes that are black. However, the main focus of this paper is that minority head coaches may be treated unfairly when athletic directors and school officials decide whether to retain or fire their institution’s current head coach. For example, Tyrone Willingham was fired from Notre Dame in 2004 with a 21–15 record after 3 years (Dillard 2013). His predecessor, Charlie Weis, produced a nearly identical 22–15 record after three seasons at Notre Dame, yet kept his job for two additional mediocre seasons. This phenomenon is not rare. In fact, the average tenure of the last eight black head coaches fired was less than three full seasons, while the average tenure of the 51 nonblack coaches released for performance reasons since the end of the 2009 season was over 5 years long (Dillard 2013).Footnote 7 As expressed by Embree, who was fired after only two seasons as head coach at Colorado, most black coaches “get bad jobs and no time to fix it (Henderson 2012).” This is an especially serious problem when compounded with the fact that almost all previously fired black coaches will not receive a second chance as a head coach. In this paper, I use a rich dataset of FBS football coaches from 1990 to 2012, which contains season- and tenure-specific performance characteristics, data describing the historical expectations of each school, and additional information about each coach, including each coach’s race and whether he was fired or retained at the end of each season.Footnote 8 Using this information, I estimate a discrete-time hazard model of the probability that an FBS head coach is fired, allowing the hazard rate of black head coaches to differ from that of white head coaches. In my full specification, I find that black head coaches are 5.28 percentage points more likely to be fired than white head coaches; this estimate is statistically significant at the 5 % level, and is robust to various modeling choices made by the researcher. Since the overall firing rate of white head coaches is 10.25 %, this represents a 52 % increase in the probability that a black coach is fired. Additionally, I find that black head coaches are more likely to be fired in the initial 3 years of tenure, and again in their seventh and eighth years, but that the difference in the probability of release between black and white head coaches in the fourth, fifth, and sixth years of tenure is small and statistically insignificant.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Are There Racial Gaps in High School Leadership Opportunities? Do Academics Matter More?
Intro:
The analysis is based on data from four longitudinal studies of high school students. The earliest is Project Talent, a study that included 5 % of all students enrolled in U.S. high schools in 1960. The others are the more familiar NCES studies: The National Longitudinal Study of the High School Class of 1972, the National Education Longitudinal Study of 1988 (1992 seniors), and the Education Longitudinal Study of 2002 (2004 seniors). All four surveys include questions about extracurricular participation and leadership roles. The statistical analysis is weighted to reflect a representative sample of U.S. high school seniors. Although each survey asks a slightly different set of questions about extracurricular participation, three of the surveys contain a subset of questions fully comparable across cohorts. Much of the analysis is limited to the five kinds of activities covered by these comparable questions: Clubs (vocational, hobby or academic), student government, student publications, performing arts, and sports.Footnote 2 The Project Talent leadership and participation questions have an entirely different structure, and are not directly comparable. However, this cohort is included in the paper because it provides historical perspective and large sample sizes. Another advantage of the 1960 Project Talent study is that it includes a personality assessment administered during high school, including a leadership scale.Footnote 3
 In longitudinal surveys, coding of race presents some challenges in cases where there are conflicting self-reports in different waves of the survey. There are two possible reasons for conflicting reports; one is that an individual self-identifies with more than one racial category (either holding multiple identities at any given point in time or undergoing change in self-identity between survey waves), the second reason is that there is miscoding of some respondents’ answers. In the case of completely random miscoding, there is likely to be a negligible number of minority group members miscoded into the larger majority group, but a relatively large number of majority group members miscoded (due to the large size of the majority group). To alleviate this final concern, individuals are included in the white category if they are ever coded as white in any survey wave. For this study, those included in the black category self-identified as black in at least one survey wave and never self-identified as white. This conservative categorization might exclude some black respondents, but avoids mistakenly including individuals who were miscoded as black in a single survey wave. In the historical 1960 Project Talent survey, the first national survey of U.S. high school students, the base year data collection effort did not include information about the race of each student. While follow-up surveys did collect this information, the sample sizes are far smaller in these follow-up surveys. Complete individual-level race data are available for a small subsample of students. Within this group with individual race self-identified, 69 % of black students were drawn from high schools that reported at least 70 % black enrollment, while only 22 % came from high schools that reported less than 30 % black enrollment (see Appendix 1, Column 3). Among students drawn from schools that reported at least 70 % black enrollment, 97 % of those with known race are black. This evidence suggests that the vast majority of students in segregated schools are black, even when we cannot directly observe the race of individual students. Therefore, rather than compare black students to white students, the primary analysis of Project Talent data compares the much larger sample of students enrolled in segregated black schools to all U.S. students in 1960. Analysis of black individuals in the small subsample followed over time offers supplemental information, and the ability to observe some black students enrolled in predominantly white schools. The 1960 estimates are not informative about long-term trends because the questions asked in the 1960 survey refer to the past 3 years, while the other surveys inquire only about the senior year of high school. However, the Project Talent data provide a remarkable opportunity to understand something new about our history.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Glass Ceiling and Relative Arrest Rates of Blacks Compared to Whites
Intro: Employers form beliefs about the reliability of prospective hires based on past experience with employees, especially with regard to the stereotypical views they have of workers along race and gender lines.Footnote 1 Of particular concern is the perception of employers on the returns to transactions with blacks relative to whites. Lundberg and Startz (2002) use a statistical discrimination modelFootnote 2 to predict how uncertainty about the returns to transactions can lead to and perpetuate discrimination against minorities. In particular, minority status signals greater uncertainty of the return even if the average return is the same for minorities and non-minorities. Their model postulates that black stereotypes may lead to lower weighting of individual productivity indicators such as education or experience. Further, Pager and Karafin (2009) use a small number of in-depth interviews to assess general perceptions about black job applicants and the extent to which employers update their stereotypes based on experience. They find that employers do not use their positive experiences with minorities to re-evaluate the black males who apply for jobs as a group. In fact negative interactions with some blacks (reported by some employers) appeared quite memorable and may have larger than warranted weight. Similarly, the Multi-City Study of Urban Inequality (MCSUI) finds negative perceptions among employers of black males hired for low-skilled jobs (Moss and Tilly 2001). Punctuality is often cited as a soft skill that is deemed important to employers (Barton 1986; Heath and Mills 2000; Hall and Berardino 2006). This paper presents a model of absenteeism (including punctuality or lack thereof) caused by disparities in criminal justice outcomes which, while exogenous to the individual, would lead to negative perceptions of black workers compared to other races. Absenteeism and arrests are directly related. Being stopped by the police may delay an employee or interviewee sufficiently to affect punctuality, even if it does not result in an arrest. If employers have experienced higher absenteeism among blacks than whites, they may believe that black candidates will be more likely to miss work or be late when compared to whites.Footnote 3 If this is the case, blacks may be less likely than whites to be placed in supervisory roles because the cost of absenteeism is higher in those jobs. As such, this paper theoretically explores absenteeism driven by arrests as a causal mechanism for differences in occupational placement for blacks compared to whites. While previous work has examined the effect of arrest rates on various labor market outcomes, the use of relative arrest as a causal mechanism for differences in relative labor market outcomes is more novel. Western and Pettit (2005), Alexander (2010), and Neal and Rick (2014) describe the impact of relatively higher incarceration of black males as biasing the standard labor market measures of inequality—given that only non-incarcerated black males appear in standard labor market surveys—to give the appearance that the relative status of blacks has improved. The literature on black-white gaps (Heckman et al. 2000; Mason 2000; Neumark 1999) has not focused on occupational segregation. One exception is Hamilton et al. (2011), who find that black men are overrepresented in low paying jobs and underrepresented in high paying jobs. Additional motivation for the study of occupational segregation is provided by Stoll et al. (2004) and Giuliano et al. (2009, 2011), who suggest that assignment of blacks into lower occupation groups may reverberate in the form of lowering hiring rates, retention and promotion of black males. This paper contributes to this understudied area. This work takes the approach of Holzer et al. (2006), who suggest that negative stereotypes of blacks as criminals might be responsible for relatively less hiring of blacks by small firms when compared to large firms. Similar to their work, this study focuses on the effect of a factor that is exogenous to the individual—relative arrest rates of blacks to whites in a city. The relationship between the relatively worse arrest rates for blacks compared to whites and relatively worse labor market outcomes is examined. Though the model cannot be tested directly, weak evidence is found consistent with the model’s prediction that black occupational placement relative to whites will be negatively affected by higher relative arrest rates for blacks compared to whites. Support is also found for another proposed channel in that relative arrest rates are found to be negatively correlated with relative hourly wages in some specifications.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Is Parental Love Colorblind? Human Capital Accumulation within Mixed Families
Intro:
A number of studies detect significant association between individual characteristics used to infer ethnic ancestry and various measures of socioeconomic success.Footnote 1 In the United States, Brazil and South Africa, for example, the intense trade of African slaves by English and Portuguese colonizers, and the Dutch displacement of indigenous populations made the color of one’s skin an indicator of European ancestry and play a key role in social stratification.Footnote 2 This historically-rooted stratification remains stark in those three countries, particularly in the case of labor markets, despite the sharp differences in patterns of economic development, institutional arrangements regarding racial segregation, and observed rates of miscegenation.Footnote 3
 There are a number of factors that could explain skin-color differentials in the labor market context. It is possible that dark-skinned individuals receive lower wages, are less likely to be employed, or have limited access to certain jobs due to discrimination by (potential) employers. Alternatively, observed differences may be the result of darker-skin individuals’ relatively lower investment in the accumulation of skills, which translates into a scarcity of economic opportunities. These are most likely simultaneously at work. With skills not being fairly rewarded, members of the group discriminated against have less incentives to invest in them.Footnote 4
 The present article focuses on the possibility that (perceived) discriminatory labor market structures influences differential investments in human capital by parents of children with differing complexion. The idea is to illustrate how optimizing mixed-race families may contribute to inequalities and to a self-sustaining stratified equilibrium − even when parents themselves do not attribute different “preferential weights” to kids of distinct skin tones. Therefore, mixed-race families’ decisions simulate an interesting laboratory for examination of the persistence of skin-color-based differences in labor market outcomes.Footnote 5 I explore this insight on the analysis that follows. In general, empirical applications targeted at identifying the forces behind minority parents’ underinvestment in human capital are plagued by the fact that predictions derived from different hypotheses are, observationally equivalent. Take the case of borrowing constraints, for example. Minority parents may face borrowing constraints that limit their ability to invest in their children. Current racial differentials on income from labor are then transmitted across generations via under-accumulation of skills. Notice, however, that the same implications can be derived from models in which, instead of borrowing constraints, the focus is on parental expectations of employers’ discriminatory behavior, or even genetic transmission of tastes and ability. This is the case because in such models wage determination is related to ancestry, with family connections unambiguously determining membership in different ethnic groups. Hence, any empirical examination of differences in human capital investment across families is bound to capture the role of all family-level characteristics, be they observed or not. In a contest of significant miscegenation in marriage markets, however, connections between ancestry and appearance are less straightforward − family backgrounds (genetic, social, or financial) are shared by siblings of different appearance. In essence, the present paper is based on the examination of how mixed-race families, through parenting practices and decisions, mediate the impact of society-wide skin color differentiation over their children. The analysis considers (without identifying) different conceptual ways by which welfare optimizing parents may generate systematic differences in the patterns of investment depending on skin color:Footnote 6 i) they may respond to differences in expected returns to human capital investments; ii) they may respond to differences in the costs of those investments (including opportunity or psychological costs); iii) they may simply prefer one skin color over another (evaluate identical outcomes differently). The interesting questions here are: Do parents operate so as to maximize or minimize the effects of genetic endowment of “whiteness” on earnings? Do parents compensate darker-skinned kids for the steeper social ladder they are likely to face, as it seems to be the case in the careful analysis of Goldsmith et al. (2006) and discussions in Mason (1997) and Mangino (2010)? This discussion clearly resonates with the ongoing debate within the United States and the United Kingdom regarding the future of racial and ethnic stratification (Hunter 2013). How are multiracials going to fit into the system of racial stratification (see Mason, 1997)? Is the growth in the number of multiracials triggering a stratification system that resembles the Latin American three-tiered system based on skin color (with the addition of a honorary white group), or would they be incorporated on the binary system that prevails today?Footnote 7 Motivated by this Latin Americanization discussion, I focus my analysis on data from Brazil containing specific information on skin-tonalities within and across families.Footnote 8 These are unique features of the Brazilian racial classification system and data collection that, combined with random aspects of the genetics of skin color, can be used to shed light on the inner workings of skin color differentiation at the family level. Moreover, Brazil is an interesting case on its own. Even though the high rate of interracial marriages and the consequent high proportion of mixed-race individuals in the population (mulatoes or browns) are frequently cited indicators of racial tolerance, there is evidence that they coexist with pertinent differences between whites and non-whites in terms of wages and other measures of living standards (see Arias et al 2004; Campante et al 2004; and Telles 2005). These findings have put racial inequality on the forefront of the Brazilian policy agenda. In fact, a recent Human Development Report(United Nations, 2005) states that skin-color differences in economic achievement is one of the main social challenges facing Brazil, suggesting that anti-discrimination policies should be a central component of any poverty reduction program implemented in that country. As with many governmental interventions, the effectiveness of these redistribution policies will ultimately depend on the variation of individual characteristics within and between families, and on intrafamilial rules regarding the allocation of resources (which may either reinforce or attenuate their impact).Footnote 9 This is particularly relevant when mixed-race families represent a large fraction of the population, since they introduce intra-family variation in skin tones into the stratification picture.Footnote 10
 Using data from the Brazilian 1991 Census of Population, I find that light-skinned children (ages 5 to 14) are 0.6 percentage points more likely to be enrolled in school or pre-school during a particular year than their siblings of darker skin tones. A dark-skinned five-year old child is approximately 2% less likely to the enrolled in school or pre-school than his/her lighter-skinned sibling, for example. These figures amount to 49.3% of the raw difference between white and non-white children in mixed-color sibships. Back of the envelope calculations also suggest that the compound effect of this difference would be that, at age fifteen, a child of light skin tone is approximately 6.5% more likely to have completed primary school than his/her darker-skinned sibling (assuming no differential grade retention and time-independent enrollment probabilities). This long term effect in the accumulation of human capital is confirmed by examination of attainment among co-residing older siblings (ages 17 to 25). These data reveal that dark-skinned young adults are 5.7% less likely to have concluded primary school than their light-skinned siblings. These effects are particularly strong for boys, following patterns of observed returns to schooling. I am not able, however, to consider wider implications of the impact of such investments over the marriage market prospects of women of different complexion, an obvisouly relevant element of socio-economic mobility (See Hamilton et al 2009 for a detailed discussion). In any case, these results are incompatible with parents seeking to compensate darker-skinned children by investing more in their formal education. Using an alternative (but much smaller) data set, from the 1989 Brazilian Survey of Nutrition and Health, I also find evidence that, conditional on enrollment, light-skinned children are more likely to attend private schools (within the family). On the other hand, there is no evidence of differences in nutrition and health outcomes. These results point to the importance of family economics for the understanding of racial and skin color differences and social stratification in general. The remainder of the paper is organized into three sections. In Section 2, I discuss the genetics of skin color and describe the data set. Section 3 presents the econometric evidence and assesses the robustness of the findings. Section 4 concludes and discusses extensions left for future research.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Skin Shade Stratification and the Psychological Cost of Unemployment: Is there a Gradient for Black Females?
Intro:
Stratification Economics is an emerging paradigm in the discipline that accounts for structural and intentional processes capable of generating and maintaining group differences in life outcomes.Footnote 1 It asserts that social phenomena such as group identity, which influence how members of a group are treated and respond to life course developments, must be considered to obtain a full understanding of difference in life outcomes both across and within groups. However, most work in this sub-field focuses on the integration of the notion of behavior guided by self-interest from economics with insights about actions from sociology and psychology to explain differences in outcomes between groups. An example is the work by Hamilton and Darity (2010) to explain the existence, and persistence, of the large racial gap in wealth. An exception is the application of the concept of colorism to explain differences in life outcomes within racial or ethnic groups. Colorism is the allocation of privilege and disadvantage according to the lightness or darkness of one’s skin, with favoritism typically granted to those with lighter skin.Footnote 2 Thus, this construct posits that pooling all blacks together may mask intra-racial and inter-racial differences in outcomes associated with complexion. Goldsmith et al. (2007) advance an explanation of why blacks with lighter skin are likely to receive preferential treatment compared to their darker skinned peers, which they describe as a preference for whiteness, grounded in theories from social psychology and anthropology. In more recent work, Hamilton et al. (2011) extend the notion of colorism to account for other phenotypical characteristics aside from skin shade, including hair color/texture and eye color. They assert that those whose constellation of features most resembles a northern European “ideal” generally receive more favorable treatment in comparison to those with a more Afrocentric phenotype.,Footnote 3
Footnote 4
 In general, given the degree of heterogeneity that commonly occurs within a group, and that groups are oftentimes defined based on at least somewhat ambiguous social classification, individuals may be arrayed along a continuum between in and out-group status, which is governed at least partially based on individual proximity to in and/or out-group characteristics. Specifically, black females vary with regards to skin complexion, and the preference for whiteness theory asserts that the dichotomous classification of black/white masks the within group heterogeneity of black women where lighter complexioned black women might receive better social treatment as a result of their closer proximity to the more socially privileged white “in-group.” This fits neatly into the framework of Stratification Economics which incorporates and extends insights from Blumer (1958) and Forbes (1997) regarding the use of social identity theory and relative group positioning theory to explain how intergroup and intragroup rivalry lead to behaviors aimed at solidifying and perpetuating material and social advantages. The underlying mechanism behind colorism is a desire for the white “in-group” to maintain privilege or advantage with recognition that social identity is more continuous rather than a simple and discrete binary description. The purpose of this paper is to use insights from colorism, and hence stratification economics, to evaluate if emotional damage associated with unemployment is greater for darker complexion black women.
