Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Trade Liberalization and Economic Growth in Guyana: An Empirical Assessment using DOLS and Error Correcting Methodologies
Intro: About twenty years after gaining its independence in 1966, Guyana was in the midst of a severe recession with per capita output falling by about 16 % between 1975 and 1988. To improve conditions in the economy, the Guyanese authorities with assistance from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the World Bank (WB), and other multilateral institutions adopted in 1988 an Economic Recovery Program. Under this program, trade liberalization was a major plank in the government’s effort to revitalize the economy. As explained by Krueger (1997, 1998) and others, trade liberalization represents a strategy for growing the economies of developing countries that is different from import substitution. For, unlike the latter strategy, trade liberalization requires the reduction or elimination of tariff and non-tariff barriers in order to create a more open economy which is expected to result ultimately in more economic growth. Unfortunately, empirical tests of the relationship between trade liberalization and economic growth have produced results that are mixed. In fact, there are studies that have found a positive relationship between trade liberalization and economic growth. At the same time, there are other studies that have found either no relationship, or a negative relationship between these two variables. These inconclusive results suggest that more empirical studies on the topic of trade liberalization and economic growth are still warranted. Moreover, in keeping with the view that there is a need for more country specific evidence on the output effects of trade liberalization, an investigation into the growth effects of trade liberalization in Guyana, using the advanced econometric tools for analyzing time series data, would be highly instructive. With that said, the purpose of this paper is to investigate with annual data for the period 1975 to 2012 the impact of trade liberalization on the economic performance of Guyana. This study will control for other factors that could influence output per worker like, investment per worker, human capital per worker and exports. This study on the effect of trade liberalization on economic performance in Guyana makes at least three important contributions to the literature. First, it makes a contribution by providing country specific evidenceFootnote 1 on the relationship between trade liberalization and economic growth for a CARICOMFootnote 2 member country. This information could be very useful to policy makers in Guyana and other CARICOM member countries as they formulate macroeconomic policies to grow their economies. Second, it makes a contribution by providing results that would complement those from other CARICOM member countries that have looked at the effects of trade liberalization on some given sector of the macroeconomy.Footnote 3 Third, it makes a contribution by investigating the long-run and short-run interrelationships among the variables in the model. To support the estimation of these relationships unit root tests and the Johansen cointegration test are performed on the relevant variables. The method of dynamic ordinary least squares and a general error correction model are used to estimate the long-run and short-run effects of trade liberalization on economic growth in Guyana. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, a brief literature review on trade liberalization and economic growth is undertaken. After that, in section 3, the trade liberalization experience of Guyana is described. Section 4, then presents the model that supports the study. The results from estimating the model using dynamic ordinary least squares are reported and discussed in section 5. The results from the unit root tests and the co-integration tests are also presented in this section of the paper. Section 6 of the paper presents a summary of the study with associated policy implications.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: ATM Fees at Black and Hispanic Owned Single Market Banks: A Comparative Analysis
Intro: A variety of evidence suggests that Black and Hispanic owned banks (BOBs and HOBs hereafter) behave differently than other banks. Historically, research suggests that these banks have lower measured efficiency (e.g., Iqbal et al. 1999) and, more recently, the banks were found to pay rates on certificates of deposits that were above those of comparable banks Kashian et al. 2014b. The analysis here extends that line of research by asking whether BOBs and HOBs charge distinct fees for ATM usage. Three fees are considered: foreign fees charged for use of a non-bank ATM by the bank’s customers, surcharges for use of bank ATMs by non-customers, and balance inquiry charges for the bank’s own customers. To develop hypotheses regarding ATM fees, we follow tradition and focus on the role of bank size and market competition. To facilitate comparison with earlier findings, the size and competition variables are comparable to those found in Hannan’s (2006) analysis of two of the fees analyzed here. Less traditionally, we additionally focus on the roles of customer incomes levels, race and ethnicity, and the possibility that banks can exploit low income depositors because those customers tend to be myopic (e.g., Campbell et al. 2010). The roles of race/ethnicity and depositor income levels are particularly salient to the present analysis because BOBs and HOBs may be closely tied to economically disadvantaged communities of color Kashian et al. 2014a. The analysis uses information on ATM fees from a sample of banks and branch offices, provided by RateWatch, covering approximately 1500 distinct banks for 2013. The data include information on 21 BOBs and 19 HOBs, and are matched with bank financial information from call reports collated by SNL, FDIC summary of deposits (SOD) data, and demographic data from the Census Bureau’s 2008–2012 American Community Survey (ACS).

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: A Policy Framework for Economic and Social Liberation: The Policy Mandala
Intro: Mandala is a Sanskrit word signifying wholeness and integration. The Policy Mandala provides a framework to help develop policies, programs and institutions that will help build wholeness in the lives of marginalized people struggling to break out from the structures of poverty and oppression (Fig. 1). The policy mandala The Policy Mandala illustrates the four major environments of the marginalized: individual, social, physiological and social. There are complex inter-relationships between and within these environments that influence the lives of the poor. The framework of the Policy Mandala calls for policy, program and organizational integration and coordination in each of the environments and among all the four environments (Corrie 1994).

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Greatest Art is The Greatest Propaganda: the Fascinating and Tragic Life of Margaret Walker Alexander

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: India’s Color Complex: One Day’s Worth of Matrimonials
Intro: Marriage, in the historical heteronormative sense, provides both men and women with a measure of social capital. Nevertheless, due the institution’s patriarchal history it is imperative for women, more than men, to first conform to the normalized idea of beauty to individually amass the necessary amount of social capital to be considered marriageable. Women’s often- abased social and economic status force them to follow a strict gender script in order to reflect society’s, or their specific culture’s, interpretation of femininity and beauty. Globally femininity and beauty are correlated with light skin; similarly, India’s complex relationship with colorism means that within the country beauty is synonymous with light complexion. Debate persists about the origins of colorism in India. Some scholars suggest that it is a direct result of European imperialism; others argue that people around the world possess a natural affinity for light skin. However, based upon research it appears that colorism is a significant factor in the mate-seeking process. Colorism complicates both race and gender politics. Arguably, colorism would fail to exist without the presence of racism, which is a symptom of the construction of race. Therefore, colorism adds a color component to the social capital women might seek to possess in order to present themselves as marriageable. Hunter (2013) defines race capital as “the way light skin and Anglo bodies operate as a form of capital.” Just as racism birthed race capital, colorism spawned color capital, which is the privilege afforded to lighter complexioned individuals with Eurocentric physical features. Color capital greatly influences women’s overall social capital. Furthermore, internationally, wealth and status are associated with people of light complexion. Consequently, women who desire to marry men of considerable wealth and/or social status must typically possess or create a high degree of social capital of their own, in this case, color capital. Women who lack the color capital necessary to make them marriageable often use skin lighting products and other cosmetic procedures to borrow the desired color capital. This study extends the work of Hunter (2002) on the international skin-tone bias women face, and Jha and Adelman (2009) on how gendered ideology and colorism affect women during the mate-seeking process on matrimonial websites. The paper highlights the origins of colorism within India and specifically how this form of discrimination affects marriage choices and the institution of marriage. Furthermore, it analyzes the relationship between social capital and skin color for both men and women globally, with an acute focus on Indian women. Most importantly, the matrimonial database composed using 1 day’s worth of advertisements from New Delhi’s Sunday Times tests Ramasubramanian’s and Jain’s (2008) hypothesis which argues that, in regards to Indian matrimonial advertisements, women announce their skin complexion more than men make known their desire for light complexioned women and few if any advertisers describe themselves as dark complexioned.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: What are You Mixed with: the Effect of Multiracial Identification on Perceived Attractiveness
Intro: Eurocentric standards of beauty reign supreme in the United States (and indeed in the world), placing increased value on features typically associated with whiteness such as light skin and straight hair, which reinforces a system of racial stratification whereby white people are privileged at the expense of black people and other people of color. One latent consequence of this preference for whiteness is intra-racial stratification among black people that also relies on skin color, affording increased privileges to those deemed closer to phenotypic whiteness. This is important because being perceived as more attractive has significant social benefits including higher income (Frieze et al. 1991), higher chances of being hired for a job (Hosoda et al. 2003). Studies consistently show that black people with more of the aforementioned white-like features, particularly skin tone, are deemed more attractive by both blacks and whites and are subsequently afforded the benefits of being attractive. But a preference for white-like features may only be part of the story. Net of skin tone, the near-universal disdain for blackness may also result in people being perceived as more attractive because they do not appear to be “completely” black (to the extent that a person’s racial group can be completely endogamous) or simply because they do not identify as “completely” black. Miscegenation is an integral, if taboo, part of United States history, and even before legal bans on the practice were lifted, the children of interracial unions benefitted materially from their multiracial heritage, especially if they were phenotypically white (Krauthamer 2013). Despite the obvious presence of multiracial citizens in America, the year 2000 Census represented the first time since the “Mulatto” category was eliminated as an official racial designation in 1930 that the United States government recognized people of multiple races. Prior to 2000, respondents were forced to choose only one racial category. (Note that even self-identification was relatively recent on the Census. People were not allowed to select their own racial classification until 1960. Prior to that year, census takers were instructed as to how to classify people according to race.) The 2000 Census allowed people to select all categories that they felt applicable. This official acknowledgement and measurement of multiracial Americans by the US Census led to a boom in studies seeking to explore the role that the more than 6 million self-identified multiracial people play in a racial structure that continues to rely on discrete racial categories (e.g., Harris and Sim 2002; Lee et al. 2003). Many studies conclude that multiracial black people—that is people whose racial background is a combination of black and other racial categories—either choose to discard their multiracial identities for a single-raced black identity, and even when they acknowledge their multiracial heritage, usually they more strongly identify with their blackness (Khanna 2010). I seek to contribute to this literature by exploring whether black people who identify as multiracial are perceived as more attractive than black people who only identify as black.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Socioeconomic Status, Religion and Health in India: an Examination of Chronic and Communicable Diseases
Intro: The literature on socioeconomic status and health suggests that those in higher positions have better health, and those in lower positions have worse health. Further, not only do the individuals with the lowest socioeconomic status exhibit the worst health, but there is also a continual gradient, from the top to the bottom of the socio-economic ladder, relating status to health (Lynch and Kaplan 2000). Beginning with the Whitehall study in 1974, subsequent research has demonstrated this SES-health gradient in multiple environments (Smith et al. 1990). The SES-health gradient has not been shown to be generalizable across populations. There is little evidence of an SES gradient in non-industrialized countries, and it is uncertain whether the health gradient established in many Western countries would apply in developing countries. Furthermore, the gradient does not necessarily remain uniform across all diseases. Chronic diseases such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes tend to exhibit the standard SES gradient in developed countries (Kaplan and Keil 1993). Evidence suggests, however, that chronic diseases may be considered “diseases of affluence” in developing countries (Rahman and Singh 2011). India presents an interesting case to examine the relationship between SES and health. First, as India is a developing country, any socioeconomic differences in health may be exacerbated by limited resources in the country as a whole (Link and Phelan 1995). This may mean that the gap in health care access is wider. High SES individuals could have greater access while lower SES individuals have little to no access to healthcare. Second, India’s caste system is traditionally marked by limited economic and social mobility across castes. Although the situation has changed substantially over time, caste remains an important social identifier (Shah et al. 2006; Thorat 2010; Thorat and Neuman 2012). The Hindu caste system includes Brahmins, high caste Hindus, Other Backwards Castes (OBCs), and Dalits – a group that includes those once called “untouchables”. If the mechanism for the relationship between social position and health is access to material resources, then individuals may face prolonged advantage or disadvantage in a fixed social system (Power et al. 2007; Singh-Manoux et al. 2004). Third, while socioeconomic status is associated with health outcomes, research suggests that health also may be associated with religion (George et al. 2002; Koenig et al. 2012). India, as a country with a number of religious groups, can offer insights about the relationship between religion and health. While the majority of India’s population is Hindu, a significant number of Muslims, Sikhs, and Christians are also present. As such, it is possible to make relevant health-status comparisons among the groups. The current direction of research on SES and health is toward investigating patterns in various contexts. Previous research has focused on developed countries. This paper examines patterns in health outcomes by caste and religion in India, a developing country. Results from a nationally representative data set, the Indian Human Development Survey, suggest that while high SES social groups report less communicable disease, they do not have better health when examining chronic diseases. High SES groups report more hypertension, heart disease, and diabetes. This provides evidence for considering chronic diseases as “diseases of affluence” in India.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Caste and Religion-Based Wage Discrimination in the Indian Private Sector: Evidence from the Indian Human Development Survey

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: At a Loss for Words: Measuring Racial Inequality in America
Intro: Most advanced societies agree that there is a certain level of social wellbeing below which not even the most undeserving individuals should be allowed to fall. The notion of government-supported well being is inseparable from ideas about democracy, equality, and social stability. Accordingly, nearly all of the nations of the West provide social services that are available to all, based either on need or worker and employer contributions. Political scientists have argued about how the provision of social services is related to democracy, political stability, and equality. Leibfried and Steffen (2008, xv) write, “Democracy and the welfare state seem to have an elective affinity for each other,” Yet they also note many examples of autocratic, racist, and fascist regimes that provide welfare. Hewitt (1977) found that, while democracy alone was not related to increased equality, use of the voting franchise in a democratic system to elect socialist governments was correlated with increased egalitarianism. In studying Germany, Jung and Uwe (2014, 69) found that, while democracy is not an automatic outcome of economic development, equitable income distribution is a key to the emergence of democracy. Furthermore, “democracy might fail if income discrepancies and redistributive tensions between the different social groups become too large. . . . Ongoing technical change and economic development that affects different groups of society in different ways, as well as increasing inequality and polarization may potentially lead to a breakdown of the democratic equilibrium and to the (re)emergence of an oligarchy or a mass dictatorship.” Economic inequality based on race diminishes the entire society and culture, if only because of the large number of minority citizens who are not being used most productively. This was true in 1969 and it seems to be just as true today (Thurow 1969). Locking people out of economic advancement means they can have no investment in their future. People without a future for themselves or their families have little reason to support the system. Thus, people outside the system are ripe for dissension and revolt. A large, potentially revolutionary mass in our midst is not good for a stable society. The prospects for genuine racial equality between America’s two largest racial groups, Blacks and Whites, are declining. There are many economic, political, and social reasons for this, but in this essay I want to stress two conceptual reasons: 1) the lack of a word in our society’s lexicon for systematic racialization, beyond the level of individual prejudice or personal bias, and 2) the failure of scholars and therefore policy makers to distinguish absolute, relative, and strategic equality from each other.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Title Nau: the Impact of Title IX on Women’s Education In the U.S. and What it Means for India

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Black-White Disparities in Test Scores: Distributional Characteristics
Intro:
This paper investigates the distributional characteristics of racial differences in mathematics achievement. It is well known that black students consistently perform lower than whites on standardized tests (Atkinson and Geiser 2009; Bloom et al. 2008; Bok and Bowen 2000; Coleman et al. 1966; Crossland 1971; Downey 2008; Espenshade and Chung 2010; Fischer et al. 1996; Fryer and Levitt 2006; Gerald and Haycock 2006; Jencks and Phillips 1998; Niu and Tienda 2010; Orfield et al. 1996; Soares 2007; Also see Special Report in The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education
2000). Various explanations for this discrepancy have been hypothesized, but the current literature on achievement tests shows persistent racial gaps even after controlling for family background and socioeconomic status (Fischer et al. 1996; Fryer and Levitt 2006; Myers et al. 2004). Although Fryer and Levitt (2006) propose that a small group of family background characteristics explains the bulk of the racial gap in test scores in early grades, at later grades too the test score gaps persist (Clotfelter et al. 2009). In a recent entry in this Review, Duncan and Sandy (2013) propose that about 50 % of the racial gap in test scores cannot be explained by a reasonable group of individual, school, and family characteristics. Two important caveats are in order when interpreting the Duncan and Sandy results. First, the decomposition uses variables, such as suspensions, that arguably are endogenous to the determination of test scores. In this paper, we account for the possible endogeneity of suspensions and examine the relationship between unexplained disparities in suspensions and the explained and unexplained portions of the test score gap. Secondly, the Duncan-Sandy results are computed at the mean of the test score distribution and fail to take into account that the portion of the racial gap that is unexplained differs between the top and the bottom of the test score distribution. For three reasons, it is not surprising that school suspensions “explain” some portion of racial gaps in test scores. One is that there are wide racial differences in suspensions—differences themselves that are often difficult to explain. Anything that is correlated with race can serve as a proxy for race in a regression model, whether or not the true relationship is causal. A second reason for suspecting a central role of suspensions in explaining racial gaps in test scores is that suspensions tautologically reduce attendance and attendance is known to affect test scores. Differential suspension rates will produce differential attendance rates and thus widen racial gaps in test scores, according to this logic. A third reason is that suspensions seen as unfair might also lead to disengagement from school and reduction of effort on tests and other academic tasks. We estimate a two-stage model of suspensions and test scores and compute the equal treatment value of suspensions for blacks to place a bound on the extent to which racial disparities in test scores might be explained by racial disparities in suspensions. A second concern with the Duncan and Sandy results revolves around the assumption that the portion of the racial gap that is unexplained is the same for low and high performing kids. It is plausible that the mechanisms explaining test performance might be different for students with lower or higher levels of prior academic preparation. Accordingly, we estimate quantile regression models and demonstrate that residual unexplained differences in scores differ between the lower tails of the test score distribution and the upper tails. The rest of the paper consists of the following four sections. First we review what is known about racial disparities in test scores and suspensions. We then sketch a two-step decomposition model designed (1) to compute the determinants of suspension rates and (2) to determine the extent to which unexplained differences in suspensions can explain the racial gap in test scores. We do this both at the mean and at each quantile. Following the model specification, we present and discuss the data and analysis results. In a concluding section, we discuss the implications of the findings and results.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Affirmative Action and Subgroup Inequality in Higher Education: Adapting Indian Policy Solutions to the American Context
Intro: India and the U.S. are heterogeneous countries marked by historic and ongoing ethnic discrimination. Similarly to America with its strong racial divisions, Indian society has long been divided hierarchically. But in India the divisions are more specifically defined among four Hindu castes known as varnas, which in total contain between two and three thousand subcastes, or jatis (Deshpande 2006). Dalits, or “untouchables,” include those jatis that fall outside the Varna caste system, and have long been subject to violent oppression. Both countries have instituted affirmative action policies in higher education to increase the proportion of underrepresented ethnic groups on their nation’s college campuses. Both India and the U.S. also rely upon broad racial and ethnic categories for allocating affirmative action benefits, a practice that subsumes distinct subgroups. This paper will analyze the extent to which affirmative-action policies have failed to achieve equitable representation of caste subgroups and black subgroups in higher education in each country. The first section briefly describes the goals and implementation processes of both countries’ affirmative action policies, and argues that subgroup inequality is a barrier to attaining the objective of equitable representation of minority groups. The next section examines the underrepresentation of subgroups in higher education, as well as explains socioeconomic and cultural differences that merit subgroup divisions. The final section discusses Indian state governments’ attempts to diminish subgroup inequality by further dividing aggregated ethnic groups, and asserts that the U.S. should adopt similar strategies. We suggest that all American colleges and universities collect demographic data for black Hispanics,Footnote 1 multiracial blacks,Footnote 2 black immigrants,Footnote 3 and black natives,Footnote 4 and consider these classifications in recruiting and admissions.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Affirmative Action and Productivity in the Indian Railways
Intro: For our study we first compiled data separately for 8 regional railway zones, from 1980 through 2002, from various annual reports on productive inputs and outputs. In specifying the variables needed for our analysis, we sought as far as possible to make use of physical rather than money measures, because the latter can easily be distorted by changing prices. The output produced by the IR consists of passenger service and freight service, measured physically in terms of passenger-kilometers and net ton-kilometers, respectively. We first generated time series indices for total passenger output and total freight output from underlying time series for passenger and freight transport of different types. We then generated time series indices for total railway output by weighting the indices for passenger output and freight output according to their percentage of total railway revenue generated. Since industry outputs are often measured in terms of gross revenue or value added, we also compiled data on railway revenues to obtain an alternative constant -price time series for total railway revenue. For labor inputs we compiled data distinguishing SCST (i.e., SC and ST) employees from non-SCST employees in four different IR job categories. The upper two job categories are comprised of administrative officers and professional workers; the lower two categories include semi-skilled and clerical staff, as well as relatively unskilled attendants, peons and cleaning staff. To take account of the effects of changes in the job-level-composition of the work force over time, we also constructed time series indices for an alternative measure of total labor input that we call “effective labor.” For the purposes of our analysis we clearly need to be able to distinguish AA beneficiaries from other employees. The IR provides data on employees who declare themselves to be SC or ST, which is necessary to avail of reservations. Almost all SCST applicants for upper-level jobs do declare their SC or ST status, because they know that their scores on the qualifying exams are unlikely to be high enough for them to gain access to an unreserved job. Any SCST applicant for a reserved job who actually scores higher than the cut-off for a non-reserved job is not included in the count of SCST employees. Thus the data on SCST employment in upper-level jobs measure fairly accurately the corresponding number of AA beneficiaries. On the other hand, many SCST applicants for lower-level jobs do not avail of reservations, because they know they can meet the qualifications for a non-reserved job; so the IR data on SCST employment in lower-level jobs significantly over-estimate the number of AA beneficiaries. In our analysis we worked with two measures of the SCST percentage: the percentage applying to all employees, and the percentage applying to upper-level employees only. The latter percentage is the better indicator of the effect of AA on IR operations, because it measures the extent to which apparently lower-qualified AA-beneficiary SCST employees have displaced apparently higher-qualified non-SCST would-be employees; and it is this displacement that most worries critics of India’s reservation policies. For capital inputs we chose to work with estimates of gross rather than net capital stock, because measures of net capital stock decline in value as the number of productive future years decline, whereas measures of gross capital stock tend to be proportional to the capital value actually consumed during a given year. We made use of the perpetual inventory method to generate time series of constant-price gross capital stocks. But these measures fail to reflect the extent to which technological progress embodied in capital increases the productive potential of a piece of constant-price capital stock from year to year. So we found it desirable to adjust our raw measure of capital input to take account of changes in capital quality associated with the age structure of capital in order to generate an alternative measure we called “effective capital input”. The main material input used by a railway system is fuel. Using standard conversion factors to convert all the measures of fuel in physical terms into their equivalent in coal-tonnes, we compiled time series of total coal-tonnes of fuel input. In the case of this input too, we saw reason to generate a second, more nuanced variable to take account of changes in fuel quality associated with changes in the proportions of different kinds of fuel utilized by the IR. The alternative measure of fuel input, which we call “effective fuel,” takes account of the gradual shift toward more efficient diesel- and electricity-powered locomotion.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Black Residential Segregation in the Era of Urban Sprawl
Intro: Segregation refers to the degree of uneven distribution, isolation from the majority, concentration into relatively few places, centralization near the urban core, and/or clustering into enclaves, of a minority population group across a metropolitan area (Massey and Denton 1988). Explanations of racial or ethnic segregation in the United States remain controversial and contested.Footnote 1 An undoubtedly short list of such explanations would include the historical legacy of formal segregation and other forms of “collective action racism” (Cutler et al. 1999), animosity towards another population group (or groups), domestic migration patterns, foreign immigration patterns, the spatial distribution of capital and employment, access to credit, and inequalities in wealth and income, among many others. Segregation is thus a key focus of contemporary and historical scholarship in urban economics and other social sciences. Theoretical and empirical research on the relationship between segregation and land use – in particular, land use patterns characterized as “sprawl” – is an intriguing and growing literature. In a sense, the convergence of the segregation and sprawl literatures is not surprising. Both investigate phenomenon whose very definitions are multi-dimensional and heavily debated. However, both have made progress in resolving methodological inconsistencies in empirical measurement. Such developments allow for more rigorous analysis of the association between the predominant settlement patterns of minorities, and the predominant spatial patterns of land use. While previous studies have contributed crucial insights, important limitations are clear and apparent. First, recent research focuses heavily on density as an attribute and measure of urban sprawl. Although a limited number of studies empirically examine the relationship between multiple measures of sprawl and segregation, an even smaller number take account of countervailing patterns of land use.Footnote 2 Metropolitan areas do not generally exhibit high-sprawl (or low-sprawl) characteristics across multiple measures. Spatial patterns of land use typically exhibit some combination, or ‘configuration,’ of both low-sprawl and high-sprawl attributes. Second, previous empirical research largely utilizes data from the 1980 to 2000 decennial Censuses. This is a significant limitation, in light of the economic and demographic changes in the United States since 2000. Third, the literature often lacks comprehensive analysis of the multiple dimensions of segregation suggested by Massey and Denton (1988). This paper contributes to the literature by exploring the relationship between alternative configurations of land use and Black segregation at a national level, using data from Census 2010. The preceding literature lacks precision in two important areas. First, how is the effect of land-use attributes on changes in segregation transmitted in metropolitan areas with a combination of high-sprawl and low-sprawl characteristics, as compared to those with uniformly high-sprawl or low-sprawl attributes? Second, why do different combinations of multiple land-use attributes contribute to increasing (or decreasing) Black segregation? Regression analysis indicates that, when defined as countervailing, multidimensional phenomenon, land use patterns have contrasting effects on changes in Black residential segregation. These complexities would not be observable by simply controlling for one attribute of land use. The paper is divided into the following sections. Section 2 reviews the literature and its major findings. Section 3 defines the theoretical framework of this paper, namely the various configurations of land use, as well as the selected dimensions and measures of segregation. Section 4 introduces summary statistics for all empirical measures. Section 5 presents the empirical model and analyzes regression results. Section 6 discusses the implications of this study, followed by an exploration of future research avenues in Section 7.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Minority Faculty Hiring Power in Academe: an Economic Model

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: An Analysis of Perceptions of Job Insecurity among White and Black Workers in the United States: 1977–2012
Intro:
One area extensively studied by labor economists is black workers’ labor market performance. In addition to the increasing and persistent black-white wage gap since 1980s (Altonji and Blank 1999), studies find that black workers are more likely to be dismissed from their jobs than white workers with similar credentials (Fairlie and Kletzer 1998; see also Settles et al. 2010, for a review). While objective measures indicate that the risk of job loss is higher for black workers than for white workers, there is little research in economics on how what workers’ expectations of job loss differ by race. I aim to contribute to the literature on black-white labor market indicators by documenting (1) the trend in perceived job insecurity by race and other observable characteristics and (2) how their perceptions of job insecurity respond to current regional unemployment rates. Though higher perceptions of job insecurity among black workers have been documented by Manski and Straub (2000), how they have been changing over time and how differently they respond to current labor market conditions have not been explored. On one hand, the last few decades are often seen as a period in the United States in which discrimination against blacks has come down, and changes in the social and legal status of black Americans brought about by the civil rights movement improved labor market opportunities for blacks.Footnote 1 Thus, one may expect that black workers are increasingly feeling more secure about their jobs. On the other hand, evidence suggests that black employment is more vulnerable than white employment. Fairlie and Kletzer (1998) find that black men were more likely to experience job displacement than were white men during the period 1982–1991 and the large part of the displacement gaps could not be explained by racial differences in education, occupation, or industry distributions. I analyze the trends for black and white workers’ perceptions of job insecurity separately by gender, age group, educational attainment, occupation and industry as well as how they react to current regional unemployment rates. I find that perceptions of job insecurity of black male workers, older black workers, and black high school graduates have increased relative to their white counterparts during the period 1977–2012. Notably, among those who attended college, it is white workers whose perceived job insecurity has increased. Black blue-collar workers’ and construction workers’ perceptions of job insecurity also have increased relative to their white counterparts. Moreover, perceptions of job insecurity among black workers in several groups (older workers, high school dropouts, managers, and construction workers) are more sensitive to regional unemployment rates than those of their white counterparts, which is consistent with the fact that blacks are more vulnerable to unemployment than whites. Labor economists have traditionally used the duration of employment and the involuntary job separation rate as proxies for job insecurity. Some readers may worry about using workers’ expectations of job loss for any useful statistical investigation because of justifiable concerns that workers’ mood at the time of the survey can bias workers’ reported perceptions of unemployment risk. Nevertheless, empirical evidence indicates that subjective job insecurity is significantly correlated with job market realities and not just a state of mind of overly pessimistic workers. Workers’ perceptions of the risk of unemployment are positively and significantly related to regional unemployment rates (Green et al. 2000) and actual unemployment experience in the subsequent year (Green et al. 2001). Also, Schmidt (1999) reports that the trends in job insecurity are largely consistent with the trends in involuntary job loss rates in the United States. Similarly, Linz and Semykina (2008) find that perceptions of job insecurity among Russian workers are largely consistent with actual labor market condition—the fear of job loss was higher during the period of economic change and uncertainty (1995–1998) and lower during the period of relative economic stability (2000–2004). These findings suggest that workers take into consideration changes in labor market conditions when assessing their chances of unemployment and their subjective assessments are to some degree reasonable predictions. More recently, Kuroki (2012) uses the deregulation in temporary employment in Japan as a natural experiment and finds that workers’ perceptions of job insecurity increased when workers experienced or anticipated an influx of cheap and readily available workers. Other recent studies include Brochu and Morin (2012) who investigate the causal link between union status and perceived job insecurity in the United States, and Garz (2012), who examines the impact of media coverage of labor market policy on perceptions of job insecurity in Germany. In short, perceived job insecurity has gained attention and been used by economists extensively in recent years. Economic implications of perceptions of job insecurity are important for economists as well as policymakers. For example, workers may suffer slower wage growth if job insecurity reduces their bargaining power (Cambell et al. 2007). It has also been pointed out that job insecurity affects worker productivity. Facing a threat of job loss, workers may decide to work harder to increase their chances of keeping their current job. However, given that job insecurity is negatively correlated with job satisfaction (e.g. Blanchflower and Oswald 1999), job insecurity may decrease productivity of workers whose motivation to work hard for their current employer has decreased. The fear of job loss also has been hypothesized to encourage workers to invest less in firm-specific human capital. Finally, the consequences of job insecurity could extend beyond the labor market to savings and consumption behavior if households have little confidence to spend due to job insecurity of wage earners. As Hamermesh (2001) points out, “more satisfied workers who are secure in their jobs have a reduced motive to undertake precautionary savings” (p. 3). The microeconomic consequences of job insecurity potentially extend beyond the individual to the macro economy by aggregation; workers’ perceptions of job insecurity can reduce output and consumption, and restrain wage growth at the macroeconomic level. If perceived job insecurity is correlated with job market realities, and given that black workers have a greater probability of involuntary displacement (e.g. Fairlie and Kletzer 1998), then it is likely that black workers have higher perceived job insecurity than white workers. It is also important to keep in mind that perceived job insecurity is likely to be correlated with racial discrimination in the labor market. That is, if black workers feel that they are discriminated in the workplace, they are likely to have higher perceived job insecurity. Even though the experience of racial discrimination is often not straightforward but subjective, there is a plenty of evidence that black workers experience racial discrimination in the workplace.Footnote 2 For example, Stauffer and Buckley (2005) find that white supervisors are more likely to give white workers higher performance ratings than black works, compared to black supervisors rating the same workers. It has been also pointed out that organizational status is negatively correlated with the likelihood that one will be more frequently targeted and discriminated (e.g. Buchanan and Fitzgerald 2008). Thus, it is not surprising that white workers, who are more likely to hold positions of power, perceive lower job insecurity. On the contrary, black workers are less likely to have seniority than white workers in many occupational sectors and thus have higher perceived job insecurity. There are several sociological studies that examine perceived job insecurity among white and black workers. Wilson et al. (2006), using the 1996 and 1998 General Social Survey, find that black workers have higher perceived job insecurity than white workers with similar human capital credentials and job/labor market characteristics, and racial differences in the determinants of perceived job insecurity are more pronounced in the private than in the public sector. Wilson and Mossakowski (2009) find that black workers in privileged occupations (professionals and managers) have higher perceived job insecurity than their white counterparts. Yang and Zheng (2015) find that an organizational commitment to avoid layoffs seems to increase the black-white gap in perceived job insecurity. This study contributes to the sociological literature by examining how perceptions of job insecurity among white and black workers have been changing over time and how differently they respond to current labor market conditions. I use the 1977–2012 American General Social Surveys (GSS). GSS data are available in most of the years from 1977 to 1993, for which the size of sample averages around 1500 individuals per annum, and continues every second year from 1994 through 2012 with a larger sample size.Footnote 3 Since 1977, the GSS have asked workers a question eliciting their expectations of job loss: “Thinking about the next 12 months, how likely do you think it is that you will lose your job or be laid off—very likely, fairly likely, not too likely, or not at all likely?” I define job insecurity on a four-point scale, ordered from 1 signifying “not at all likely” to 4 signifying “very likely”. Regarding the race of respondents, the GSS classifies them as “white,” “black,” or “other.” In order to focus on the white-black differentials, I will only focus on white and black workers throughout this paper. The “other” category comprises approximately 5 % of all respondents. Table 1 summarizes perceptions of job insecurity among black and white workers. Mean job insecurity is substantially higher for black workers than for white workers (1.74 vs. 1.48). Breaking the job insecurity variable into each category reveals that 8 % of black workers answered “very likely to lose job” compared to 4 % of white workers. 54 % of black workers answered “not at all likely to lose job” compared to 65 % of white workers. Figure 1 shows mean job insecurity for white workers and black workers over time along with national unemployment rates.Footnote 4 Unemployment rates and workers perceptions of job insecurity show a strikingly similar trend. Not surprisingly, data reveal that black workers’ mean perceived job insecurity are always higher than those of white workers. National Unemployment and Mean Job Insecurity of White and Black Workers: 1977–2012 Summary statistics shown Table 1 are the raw means, which are likely to be correlated with not only with a number of observable characteristics but also time trends and regional economic conditions. Thus, next I estimate the following equation: where i, r, and t denote an individual, the region in which the individual currently resided, and the year in which that individual was surveyed by the GSS, respectively. The dependent variable JI

irt
 is the job insecurity variable discussed above. X

irt
 represents a set of demographic and other control variables: indicator variables for employment status (full and part-time), education variables (<high school, high school, junior college, bachelor’s degree, and graduate degree), union membership, and self-employment. UnempRate represents regional unemployment rates obtained from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.Footnote 5
θ

r
 represents census region dummies. Column 1 in Table 2 shows results from the regression that controls only for exogenous demographic characteristics (age, gender, native-born, and race) and includes regional dummies. Standard errors are clustered at the region-year level. To make the interpretation of the estimates easier, OLS estimation, rather than ordered probit or logit estimations, is presented.Footnote 6 Both white and black workers’ perceptions of job insecurity have risen over time, but the coefficient of (Black×Trend) is greater than that of (White×Trend) by 0.001 ~ 2. However, the p-value from testing whether the coefficients of (Black×Trend) are statistically significantly different from those of (White×Trend) suggests that the differences between the black and white trends are not statistically significantly different from one another. Because the regression in column 1 ignores the role played by other factors known to affect job insecurity such as education and occupation, columns 2 and 3 show results from the regressions that control for socioeconomic characteristics and occupations and industry, respectively. Columns 2 and 3 show that the statistical significance and the difference between the size of the coefficients on time trend virtually remain the same whether or not socioeconomic, occupation, industry are controlled. Turning to regional unemployment rates, they are highly statistically significant across different specifications for both whites and blacks. A one percentage point increase in regional unemployment rates is predicted to increase perceptions of job insecurity by 0.043 ~ 46 for black workers and by 0.034 ~ 37 on a four-point scale for white workers. That black workers’ fear of job loss is slightly more responsive to unemployment rates than white workers indicates that workers’ expectations is consistent with the reality that black men experience higher rates of job displacement than white workers (Fairlie and Kletzer 1998). However, again, the p-values suggest that there is little evidence that black workers’ perceptions of job insecurity react differently to the regional unemployment rates from those of white workers. Given that, in aggregate, both black and white workers have become more insecure about their jobs, it seems useful to examine subgroups of workers. I explore how the black-white gap in perceptions of job insecurity has been changing among different demographic groups. First, I divide the sample into men, women, and four age groups. Because including socioeconomic factors and industry/occupation controls did not affect the coefficients of interest substantially in Table 2, I control only for exogenous demographic characteristics (gender, age, native-born) and regions of residence. The results are shown in Table 3. Column 1 reveals that black men have experienced a larger decline in perceptions of job security over time than white men, and the difference is statistically significant. The coefficient of (Black×Trend) is statistically significant while that of white is not. This suggests that, over the 35 years (1977–2012), the black-white gap has increased approximately by 0.006×35 ≈ 0.2 on a four-point scale for men. The column 2 shows that the coefficient of (Black×Trend) is not statistically significant for female black workers but is statistically significant for female white workers, suggesting that black female workers may have experienced a relative decrease in job insecurity during the period. However, the difference in trends is not statistically significant; thus, trends in the gap by race offer no evidence of particularly higher job security for black female workers relative to that of white female workers. Moreover, for female workers, the coefficient of Black is large (0.23) and highly statistically significant, suggesting that black women still have higher perceptions of job insecurity than white women. Both male and female black workers’ perceived job insecurity again tends to be more sensitive to regional unemployment rates, but the differences are not statistically significant. Columns 3–6 report regression equations for different age groups. While there is no statistically significant black-white difference for workers aged 18–54, older black workers (55+) are feeling more insecure over time, and the black-white difference is statistically significant. For this group, the black-white gap has increased approximately by (0.013–0.003)×35 ≈ 0.35. However, black workers aged 55+ felt on average 0.36 points more secure than their white counterparts in 1977, as indicated by the coefficient of Black. This suggests that older black workers who used to feel more secure are no longer feeling more secure than older white workers. Also, older black workers’ perceived job insecurity is much more sensitive to regional unemployment rates that that of older white workers (0.08 vs. 0.03). Tables 4, 5, and 6 change from subgroups with only exogenous characteristics and report the regression results for other subgroups of the population. Of course, we must proceed with awareness that people are not randomly selected into different groups, and there might have been changing selection through time into education and occupations. Table 4 shows the results for workers with different amounts of education and contains interesting differences between blacks and whites. Both white and black high school graduates have experienced an increase in perceived job insecurity over time, but the size is larger for black workers, and the difference is statistically significant. For this group, the black-white gap has increased approximately by (0.007–0.002)×35 ≈ 0.18. Notably, among those who attended college, only white workers have been experiencing higher perceived job insecurity over time. For this group, the black-white gap has decreased approximately by (0.005)×35 ≈ 0.18. However, this finding may be confounded by the choice to go to college. For example, it may be that white “worriers” may be increasingly self-selecting into higher education to get a college degree over time. If this is the case, the fear of job loss is likely to increase among educated white workers relative to black counterparts. Finally, while there is no statistically significant difference between the black and white trends for high school dropouts, black high school dropouts’ perceived job insecurity is more responsive to regional unemployment (0.13 vs. 0.05), and the difference is statistically significant. Table 5 shows the results by occupation. To avoid statistical imprecision that may come from the small sample of blacks in the GSS, I use only broad occupation categories. Again there are some interesting differences between black and white workers. Among black workers, blue collar workers are increasingly feeling insecure. Among white workers, managers and professionals and white-collar workers’ perceptions of job insecurity has increased over time, though the differences between the black and white trends are not statistically significantly different from one another for these occupations. Finally, black managers are more likely to develop a fear of job loss when regional unemployment rates go up than white managers. In Table 6, the sample is divided into different industries. Again, I use only broad categories for industry. It is notable that, as the black dummy indicates, black workers in the construction/mining industry were on average 0.84 points more secure than white counterparts in 1977. However, black workers in the construction/mining industry have experienced a large increase in perceptions of job insecurity over time (0.03 per year), so black workers in these industries have higher perceived job insecurity in 2012. Also, their perceived job insecurity increases more with regional unemployment rates. Those black-white differences are statistically significant, as suggested by the p-values. But because the number of workers in the construction/mining industry is small, it is hard to draw any concrete inference.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: For Economic Advantage or Something Else? A Case for Racial Identification Switching
Intro: Racial identity is made and shaped by experiences over a long-term process. It affects whom we associate with, the political views and cultural attitudes we hold. Akerlof and Kranton (2000) go further and state that the “choice of identity may be the most important “economic” decision people make.” Research has confirmed that identity has an effect on economic outcomes (Gorinas 2014; Russo and Hooft 2011; Benjamin et al. 2010; Espenshade et al. 2004, and Bertrand and Mullainathan 2004). In light of the economic importance of identity, work by Antman and Duncan (2015) and Francis and Tannuri-Pianto (2013) shows that an individual’s racial identity responds to economic incentives (Mason 2004a). Antman and Duncan (2015) show that in states with affirmative action bans the share of self-reported African-American group drops while the Asian group grows. The authors reconcile this by suggesting that when the penalty for being Asian (a group hurt by affirmative action university admission policies) and economic benefit for being African-American (implied advantage in university admission decisions) are removed a fraction are likely to switch their racial identity. This suggests that the choice of racial identity may be a function of perceived external (economic, cultural, social) benefits and costs and in/out group interactions (Stewart 2009 and Darity et al. 2006). In other words, racial identity is a social construct (Mason 2004b, and Harris and Sim 2002). Extensive research supports the view that identity choice is influenced by external factors (Mason 2004b). The objective of this paper is to add to the existing empirical literature of race identity. Specifically, we take advantage of the affirmative action bans around the year 2000 as a form of exogenous variation to evaluate factors that drive race switching. The first and fourth wave of the NELS 1988 dataset allows us to measure race consistency over a 12-year period. We find that those who reside in an affirmative action ban state alter how they respond to the race question. We show that in the immediate aftermath (or environment leading up to) of an affirmative action ban individuals are more likely to hold on to childhood racial identity (Asian and Black). Second, we show that switchers are predominately multiracial who reside in states that do not adopt affirmative action bans. Our findings suggest that race identity is not permanently fixed across time for a non-trivial fraction of our sample of 26 year-olds. The fourth wave, which takes place in the year 2000, does not allow us parse out economic and/or social-political incentives produced by the timing of the ban on racial identification. We find that at the time of the ban all race groups are either less likely (non-Hispanic Asian and Black) or no more likely (Hispanic) than non-Hispanic Whites to switch race. This suggests that in the short-run social-political factors at the time of a ban dominate long-term economic benefit/damage that may come about from the policy change. A wave 5 (non-existing) would help bring clarity to the long-term effect of the ban. Sherif et al. (1955) shows that when individuals (strangers) are brought together and made to share common goals they will collaborate to counter/respond to a (second) hostile group. This explanation of group identification is consistent with our findings that switching is far less likely in states that adopt affirmative action bans. We propose that affirmative action bans are likely understood by minorities at the time of the ban as being political acts against their group’s interest. To illustrate this point, consider California’s Proposition 209 passed by California voters in 1996 (taking effect in 1997). Proposition 209 was a voter approved constitutional amendment that prohibited state government institutions from using race or sex when making decisions dealing with public employment, contracts, and public education. The ban potentially benefits Whites and Asians (Arcidiacono et al. 2016). For example, Asians were the group most hurt by affirmative action admissions based decisions into the University of California system. However, Proposition 209 was followed and preceded by a number of ballot initiatives that at the time of Governor Pete Wilson’s tenure appeared to be against the interests of minorities. For instance, Proposition 227 was a ballot initiative passed in 1998 by California voters to eliminate bilingual education (Frank 1998, and Crawford 1998). Proposition 187 (Save Our State) passed in a referendum in 1994 made it a crime to offer public services (healthcare, education, etc.) to undocumented immigrants (Evelyn 1999). In social-political environments where minority groups’ interests appear to be under attack, even the most agnostic apolitical individuals may find themselves supporting/aiding their groups cause. Walter Isaacson’s biography of Albert Einstein paints him as secular in his worldviews while having a strong sense of obligation to his own group. Albert Einstein is quoted as saying: Despite my internationalist beliefs, I have always felt an obligation to stand up for the persecuted and morally oppressed members of my tribe… According to the Los Angeles Times Poll of the November 1996 election 37% of Whites, 74% of Blacks, 76% Latino, and 61% of Asians voted against Proposition 209.Footnote 1 Only Whites as a group overwhelmingly supported Proposition 209. Asians who potentially had the most to gain from Proposition 209 (the majority) voted against it. The results we present support an argument that policies perceived to undermine the interest of minorities makes one more (consciously) aware of one’s own minority identity. We show that systematically, in the time around the affirmative action bans in California, Texas, Washington, and Florida racial identity switching becomes far less likely. The data does not allow us to see if the pattern of race switching changes years after the adoption of the bans. In addition, we cannot get at the effect that affirmative action bans had on those more directly impacted (i.e. college bound students). However, work by Antman and Duncan (2015) suggests that in the long-run Asian and African-American identification move in opposite directions as years after the ban elapse. In March 2014, California abandoned Senate Constitutional Amendment 5 (SCA5) that would have largely undone the effects of Proposition 209. The Chinese-American lobby is largely credited with helping kill these efforts (Mason 2014). The paper is organized as follows. “Identity” section reviews identity and related literature. “Identification Strategy” section introduces our estimating strategy and data. “Results” section presents our empirical results. “Conclusion” section provides concluding remarks. Identity has many domains. Individuals have an identity over race, religion, political ideology, sexuality, work, family, etc. Each of these identities carries qualities and attributes that define who one is at a particular space and time. Identity therefore, serves to filter external stimuli and give meaning to our actions and social interactions. This is important as it suggests that biases, prejudices, predispositions, etc. as defined by our identities can potentially have significant social, cultural, and economic implications. In particular, the stereotype literature has shown that individuals act out (behave in accordance to) their identities (Benjamin et al. 2010; Gonzales et al. 2002; Shih et al. 1999; Steele and Aronson 1995; Steele 1997). We learn from social psychology literature that cognitive ability, intellectual curiosity, and current identity are predictors of personal identity development (Grotevant 1987; Marcia 1966; Berman et al. 2001). These factors are also likely to be significant predictors of social identity development. Identity formation is therefore a process of experimentation and self-discovery whose consolidation leads to the adaptation of our identities (Berman et al. 2001 and Grotevant 1987). Darity et al. (2006) produced a game theoretical framework to study alternative racial identity (“labeling”) social norms. In their model, social identity norms are established out of social interactions within and between groups. The predictions of their model in part depend on phenotype (ability to “pass”), resources (exclusivity), and group identification of others. Among the set of dominant strategies, they find that a mixed equilibrium will give rise to “passing” or assimilation. The ability to pass is in part facilitated/hindered by individual’s own physical characteristics. Antman and Duncan (2015) focus on multiracial individuals because of their ability to (more easily) “pass” for a member of another group. If identity is in part explained by economic payoffs, as predicted by Darity et al. 2006, then an affirmative action ban will cause a non-trivial fraction of multiracial individuals to adopt a race choice consistent with the economic benefit/damage of group affiliation.Consistent with this prediction, Antman and Duncan (2015) find a drop in the share of multiracial African-Americans following an affirmative action ban. The literature on identity faces many empirical limitations. For example, the absence of individual-specific observations is a problem. Work by Antman and Duncan (2015) exploit racial variations in group identity shares by state. They are not able to identify the actual switcher. They show that differences in population shares controlling for migration patterns can be explained mostly by the exogenous affirmative action ban. The significant differences in shares of Asian and African-American population following an affirmative action ban suggest that systematically some proportion of the population choose a different racial identity. Unfortunately, they were not able to evaluate the characteristics of individuals that changed race. Measurement error is a problem in racial identity studies. Work by Liebler and Halpern-Manners (2008) and Harris and Sim (2002) emphasize that racial identity is sensitive to the survey employed. The work by Harris and Sim (2002) using the Add Health dataset show that responses to multiple race questions are sensitive to the location where the survey is administered. For example, adolescent interviewees were far more likely to be multiracial if answering the survey at school then if answering at home (Harris and Sim 2002). These studies highlight potential estimating concerns when employing self-reported multiracial variables. However, according to this same literature race choice is understood to be a social construct. Harris and Sim (2002) finding that racial ancestry is influenced by the location of the interview further support the view that identity is space-time dependent. Additionally, measurement error was likely introduced in 2000 when the US Census and (other government entities) changed the way race was asked on survey forms. In particular, the Census adopted a two-part race question (1. Are you Hispanic? 2. Race?). Harris and Sim (2002) exclude Hispanics from their analysis partly because it is understood that the change to the race question created confusion in the part of interviewees. The implied consequence of the two-part question is that the social construct of race identity is not adequately expressed. That is, the expression of identity is partly biased by the wording, questions, and/or order the questions appear on the survey (Hirschman et al. 2000). To the extent that biases affect our estimates they are likely from the surveys collection methods and time of collection. We are not aware of any concerns raised by previous research using this dataset about sample and survey collection biases. Our results are limited to a national representative sample of 8th graders in 1988. This omits 14 year-olds who were no longer enrolled in school.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Political Economy of Guyana’s Underdevelopment

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: What Have Remittances Done to Development? Evidence from the Caribbean Community and Common Market
Intro: Global remittances have reached $557 billion in 2013 and are projected to grow at a rate of about 4% to $636 billion by 2017 (World Bank 2015). Approximately 75% of the money goes to developing countries. The flows to Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) was substantial, reaching $61 billion in 2013 although the growth has slowed down, growing at a little more than 1% in the last two years. The Caribbean Community and Common Market (CARICOM), an integrated region consisting of Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Haiti, Jamaica, Montserrat, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and Grenadines, Suriname, and Trinidad and Tobago, received roughly $4.5 billion in 2012 (World Bank 2013).Footnote 1 Due to small population the per-capita receipts are substantial in most countries. St. Kitts and Nevis, Jamaica and Guyana ranked among the top 10 per-capita recipients, receiving $842, $791 and $590, respectively (Lim and Simmons 2015). The impact of remittances on overall development depends on how remittances are utilized. Samuel (1996) indicates if remittances are used mainly for conspicuous consumption, they might induce growth in the short run, but at the expense of long-run economic development. Given the high percentage of importation content in the consumption pattern of CARICOM countries, there can be negative impact on balance of payments and limited spill over for the contribution to economic development. However, if remittances are used for investment and essential consumption to improve health, education, and other productive activities of the society, development of the society can be greatly enhanced. Given the economic challenges of many countries in CARICOM, it is generally assumed that in the absence of remittances the economies would have significantly more severe socio-economic challenges. There are priori indications that the increased flows of remittances have facilitated substantial socio-economic development in the region but no definitive empirical studies have been done to substantiate or provide evidence on such outcome. Often times, the Caribbean region is studied in conjunction with Latin America and the region’s identity is often minimized within the aggregate analysis. World Bank (2006) shows that remittances are growth-enhancing though the magnitude is relatively small while Mundaca (2009) finds a more pronounced impact of remittances on economic growth, especially when financial development is accounted for. Nsiah and Fayissa (2013) and Ramirez and Sharma (2008) use cointegration test and provide evidence for the long-run relationship between per-capita growth and remittance flows. Unlike these studies, Lim and Simmons (2015) examine specifically the homogeneous part of the region, CARICOM, and find no long-run relationship between remittances and income but a relationship with consumption. The main purpose of the paper is to analyze the impact of remittances on the socio-economic development of CARICOM countries. If remittances has not boosted long-run economic growth in this region; then, what have they done? More specifically, we examine data from 1970 to 2013 on the long-run impact of remittances on four areas of social development including health, education, communication infrastructure, and demographic changes. To our knowledge, the paper is the first that empirically examines the relationship between remittances and social development in this region. The paper adds to the current knowledge about the role remittances play in the social development of the region. Further, the findings of this study provide insights which are useful for assessing the performance of each country and are a useful tool for policy makers who formulate policies that deal with immigration, migrant workers, and remittance transfers.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Nineteenth Century Black and Mixed-Race Physical Activity, Calories, and Life Expectancy: Nutrition, Sanitation, or Medical Intervention?
Intro: Nineteenth century African-Americans experienced considerable degrees of political and economic exclusion. From its founding, US economic arrangements were based on inequality, and blacks were at an institutionalized disadvantage to whites. This inequality extended not only to black material conditions but also to their physical activity, nutrition, and life expectancy. While inferior to whites under slavery, the variety and quality of black diets were sufficient to maintain slave health (Fogel and Engerman 1974; Sutch 1976), and as slave owner property, slave masters had incentives to maintain slave health and extend slave life expectancies. After emancipation, economic arrangements changed, and Southern agricultural productivity decreased (Ransom and Sutch, 1997, pp. 151–155; Irwin 1994); however, we are uncertain how black and mixed-race individual’s physical activity and nutrition varied with the transition from bound to free labor. After generations under slavery, when given a choice, black workers may have chosen to work less, and their physical activity levels would have decreased (Ransom and Sutch 1977, pp. 41–47). It is also unclear how black life expectancy changed with the transition and the change in nutrition associated with slavery’s demise. As a result, this study considers how nineteenth century US institutional change altered the nutrition, physical activity, and life expectancy facing African-Americans. Individual height and weight reflect the cumulative net difference between calories consumed less those required for work and to fend off disease. An individual’s height reflects genetic factors but also environmental and nutritional circumstances between conception and maturity (Cole 2003). Their weight is partially a function of their height but is a snapshot of their nutritional status at the time of measurement, and heights, weights, and physical activity levels are used here to estimate cumulative and current net nutrition when other material welfare measures are scarce or unreliable. An important extension to weight, height, and BMI measures is to use these values to estimate calories required to achieve and maintain weight and height (Harris and Benedict 1919; Mifflin et al. 1990). Fogel and Engerman (1974, pp. 109-115) and Fogel (1989, pp. 132–138) show that slaves received more calories per day than whites. Steckel (1979, pp. 373-375) documents early that fairer complexioned blacks were taller than their darker complexioned counterparts. Bodenhorn (1999) also shows that mixed-race African-Americans had taller statures than darker complexioned blacks. Rees et al. (2003) show how slave owners allocated nutritional resources over a slave’s life to maximize slave-holder wealth with respect to slave diets and activity levels. However, while these measures provide important insight into biological conditions during economic development, they provide less information about the physical activity and calories required to maintain weight and health. At the same time that anthropometric studies have created a need to more clearly evaluate nutrition during US economic development, research from nutrition and health studies have extended techniques to estimate the nutrition required to sustain an individual’s physical activity, weight, and height (Mifflin et al. 1990; Weijs et al. 2008). Even when wage and income data are available, calories and nutrition are important measures for non-pecuniary conditions facing a population. Various historical calorie and nutrition measures are available from such diverse sources as slave plantation records, aggregate food balance sheets, and dietaries (Floud et al. 2011; Dirks 2016). Estimated calories reported here are from energy equations and represent calories required per day to maintain an individual’s weight, height, and physical activity (Harris and Benedict 1918; Mifflin et al. 1990). Komlos (1987, p. 909) illustrates that US antebellum calories decreased with economic development and attributes it to the separation of food production from food consumption (Dirks 2016, p. 62). Throughout the nineteenth century, there were nutritional imbalances among the labor force. Increasing urbanization, immigration, and the growth of the industrial sector were greater than the growth in agricultural productivity, which put US national food supplies under stress. Moreover, dietary compositions changed with urbanization and economic development, and the US agricultural sector could not supply the growing demands for proteins, amino acids, and dairy products. In sum, a considerable body of nutrition and anthropometric studies show that slaves and free blacks received sufficient nutrition to perform work, which was associated with changes in their physical measurements. It is against this backdrop that this study considers three paths of inquiry into nineteenth century black physical activity, nutrition, and life expectancy. First, how did late 19th and early twentieth century black physical activity and calories vary over time and across their respective distributions? Throughout the late 19th and early 20th centuries, black and mixed-race BMRs and calories decreased while their life expectancies increased, indicating that black life expectancy increased despite diminishing calories associated with their transition to a free labor force. Second, how did black physical activity and calories vary by occupations and socioeconomic status? Physically active farmers had greater BMRs and required more calories per day than workers in other occupations. Third, how did black BMRs and calories vary by residence within the US? Rural Southern blacks had greater BMRs and required more calories per day than blacks in the Upper South, and Northeastern blacks had both the lowest BMRs and received the fewest calories per day, indicating that urban workers were physically less active and required fewer calories per day than workers in rural locations.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Indirect Displacement Hypothesis: a Case Study in Washington, D.C.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Black Power and the Power of Protest: Re-Examining Approaches for Radical Economic Development
Intro:
African Americans have established a long legacy of preserving their humanity by resisting structural inequality and systemic racism that reduce their cultural agency and access to necessary resources for a decent living (Gammage 2011; Countryman 2006; Sullivan 1963; James 1930). When exploring this history of resistance after 1865, we can clearly identify a central theme around economic self-sufficiency. This article does not propose that economic stability would lead to the dismantling of oppressive institutions and/or ideologies that seek to disadvantage people of African descent, it simply observes that access to economic resources and equal opportunity to economic mobility was and continues to be a core principle for many social movements spearheaded by the African American community.
