Economic development is commonly defined as the process of improving the standard of living of people at the national, state and local level (Malecki 1997; Arndt 1987).Footnote 1 The process of economic development can include, but is not limited to, initiatives geared toward job creation, technological advancement, opportunities for wealth accumulation, and professional skill development. The central objective is to improve quality of living. Thus, economic development is vast and encompasses the economy, education, government and infrastructural design (Malecki 1997; Schumpeter 2011).Footnote 2
 This research utilizes the term economic development to focus on the process or processes used by African Americans to engage their national, state and local economies to maximize their participation for the purpose of improving economic standings in regards to employment, wealth holdings and economic mobility. It must be noted that at times these processes expand the traditional scope of economic development due to the social and political reality of African American communities. Thus, this research identifies act by African Americans to improve their economic standing as a form of economic development. Historically, African American led social movements geared toward, or including a component for, economic development sought to address a critical issue that has yet to be solved. While much of the Black leadership up until the 1960s committed itself to liberalist approach for economic development, more radical constituencies concluded that liberalism was insufficient for addressing African Americans economic challenges (Carmichael 1963; Sullivan 1963). In fact, the inability of legislation, the thrust of liberal reformists, to produce fair employment practices motivated a wide abandoning of the liberalist approach and brought into question capitalism as a system. For many, capitalism represented a system that produces economic instability and inherently exploited the labor of the poor. It must be noted that the various movements differ in aims, scope, objectives and tactics used to obtain its desired outcomes. Examples of these movements are the inception of the reparations movement foraged by the National Ex-Slave Mutual Relief, Bounty and Pension Association, the solidification of early models of Black Capitalism through organization like the National Negro Business League, direct action protest models like economic boycotting such as the ‘Don’t buy where you can’t work movements” used in Harlem, Chicago, Philadelphia and other large Black communities in metropolitan cities. Although these movements unfolded in different time periods and in different geographical places helped to refine and identify effective models for addressing economic development. These movements not only illustrate the resilience of people of African descent, it also, however, exposes the shortcomings and the need to assess and possibly shift future objectives. This research offers a much need evaluation of the methods used by African Americans to engage economic development and the objectives outlined by our various communities to assess the feasibility of acquiring success. In addition, it explores past assertion that challenges the practicality of economic development within a capitalistic system that finds its roots firmly embedded in white supremacy and exploitation. The discourse on capitalism and the viability of Black economic development is central to the construction of objectives for future movements geared toward African American economic development. To be clear, if African American economic development and capitalism have no positive correlation, more radical objectives must be developed to explore new economic systems that are conducive for Blacks acquiring economic security. A look at movements organized and carried out in Philadelphia aimed at economically empowering African Americans could be useful in assessing degrees of success toward identified objectives and in evaluating gains toward addressing the critical question of economic self-sufficiency. The African American community in Philadelphia has a lengthy history of social activism and was successful in establishing early legislation protecting African American employment rights. This paper surveys demonstrations in Philadelphia geared toward improving African Americans’ collective economic reality. Next, it assesses the success of the demonstrations in Philadelphia toward their desired objectives. Then, it analyzes the significance of these movements toward addressing the central concern of economic stability. Lastly, it recommends necessary shifts in objectives to adequately address economic self-sufficiency.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Dreaming and Doing at Georgia HBCUs: Continued Relevancy in ‘Post-Racial’ America

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Not Black-Alone: The 2008 Presidential Election and Racial Self-Identification among African Americans
Intro:
Historically, “passing” and “acting white” have been two forms of acculturation available to African Americans. “Passing” occurs when European-phenotype persons of African descent select a white-alone racial identity. If there is a relatively larger economic payoff to white identity, there will be strong incentives for European-featured Africans to identity as white. “Acting white” permits acculturation for some African Americans who are otherwise unable to pass. For instance, mixed-race self-identification can be an individualistic acculturation strategy for those seeking to arbitrage the differences in economic inequality associated with market and social premia obtained by white-alone persons relative to black-alone persons. Consequently, a mixed-race self-identity strategy may not get a person into an advantaged group (e.g., white-alone in the US) but it may allow a person to more or less successfully distance himself from a disadvantaged group (e.g., black-alone in the US). Identity differences among African Americans were widespread during the nineteenth century. In their analysis of 1860 census data of the urban South, Bodenhorn and Ruebeck (2003) found that light-skinned mixed-race persons, “mulattoes,” often had economic incentives to distinguish themselves from blacks. By rejecting blackness and “acting white” it was sometimes possible for mulattoes to obtain better education, higher occupational status, and greater wealth accumulation (Bodenhorn and Ruebeck 2007). Simply separating themselves from black-alone or darker African Americans was not sufficient for mulattoes to achieve greater socioeconomic wellbeing, the separation also had to occur in a context whereby it was beneficial to whites. Further, the advantages of mixed-race identity varied by region and by the demographic composition of the population. Black-white persons of the Lower South (and the Caribbean) were most frequently the children of affluent white males and (free or enslaved) black women; hence, they secured advantages not available to persons who were black-alone, for example, manumission, some degree of education, and inheritance from fathers. (See Bodenhorn 2003 and accompanying references). Black-white persons of the Upper South were most frequently the children of poor white males and enslaved black women. Hence, the mulatto-black economic differential in the Upper South was smaller than the mulatto-black economic differential in the Lower South. Matching individuals from the 1880 and 1900–1940 US federal census, Nix and Qian (2015) find that over 19% of African American males passed for white at some point during their lifetime and that about 10% of these passing males later reverse-passed to a black identity. Importantly, Nix and Qian note that “passing was accompanied by geographic relocation to “whiter” communities; reverse passing was common and accompanied by relocation to “blacker” communities (page 37).” Most often, passing occurred in Northern states. Passing from black to white was positively associated with better political-economic and social opportunities for whites relative to blacks (page 4). Although the Nix and Qian results are strongly consistent with the predictions of Darity et al. (2006), it should be noted that the racial identities of persons in these censuses was determined by the census enumerator, not by the head of household or other respondent. Further, for the 1880, 1910, and 1920 censuses the racial categories are white, mulatto, and black, while white and black are the categories for 1900, 1930, and 1940 censuses, with the mulatto category merged into the black category. The racial classification instructions for enumerators were vague and mostly depended on visual inspection by the enumerator. Liebler et al. (2014) provide a descriptive analysis of changes in racial self-identity for a panel of persons linked from the 2000 and 2010 federal censuses. Among African Americans, fewer persons selected into the black-alone identity than selected out of this identity, regardless of the initial identity in 2000. For example, among the top 20 identity response changes: 112,882 persons changed from black-alone to white-alone and 102,464 persons changed from white-alone to black-alone; 130,788 persons transferred from black-alone to black-and-white, while 90,086 persons switched from black-and-white to black-alone (Liebler et al. 2014: 32). Similarly, among Non-Hispanic blacks 71,382 persons changed from black-alone to black-and-American Indian/Alaska native, but just 50,000 made the opposite change; 90,086 Non-Hispanic blacks who self-identified as black-and-white in 2000 changed to black-alone in 2010, but 130,788 changed from black-alone to black-and-white (Liebler et al. 2014: 26). Among Hispanic African Americans who self-identified as black-alone during 2000 (238,070 persons), 77% joined that category in 2010, but 55% left that category by 2010. Hispanic African Americans who self-identified as black-and-white had identity persistence of just 11%, with 77% leaving that category and 115% joining. Liebler, et al. do not provide information on the relationship between nativity and changes in racial self-identification, but there are a large fraction of first and second generation immigrants among Hispanics and African American immigrants may originate from countries with more fluid and gradational racial categories than the United States, for example, the Caribbean and Central America. As such, nativity may be a significant determinate of identity change. Importantly, also, Leibler, et al. show that among those who self-identify as Non-Hispanic black-alone identity stability increases with age, moving from 95% (persons no more than 29 years of age) to 98% (persons at least 45 years of age); however, identity stability declines with age among Non-Hispanic African Americans who self-identity as black-and-white, moving from 63% (persons no more than 14 years of age) to 20% (persons at least 45 years of age). Recent regression studies have added nuance to our empirical knowledge of racial identity selection. For example, Antman and Duncan (2015) and Contreras (2016) examine the effects on racial self-identification when state governments ban the utilization of affirmative action policies in higher education, contracting, and employment. Both studies find that the racial identification effects of an affirmative action ban depend on the age and ancestral origin of the person. Working with concatenated cross-sectional data, Antman and Duncan find that for African Americans under 25 years of age and with a multiracial ancestral heritage an affirmative action ban reduces by about 15% the probability of self-identifying as black. But, for African Americans ages 26–34 and with a black-alone ancestral heritage an affirmative action ban increases by about 0.20% the probability of self-identifying as black; this probability falls to 0.10% for persons 35–59 years of age. Also, for Asian Americans with a multiracial ancestral heritage an affirmative action ban increases by about 15% the probability of self-identifying as Asian. Similarly, for Asian Americans with an Asian-alone ancestral heritage an affirmative action ban increases by about 1.0% the probability of self-identifying as Asian. Antman and Duncan argue that when an affirmative action ban occurs persons affiliated with underrepresented ancestral groups are less likely to self-identity as a member of the racial group, while persons affiliated with overrepresented ancestral groups are more likely to self-identity as a member of the racial group. Hence, when affirmative action bans are implemented persons of African ancestral origin are less likely to self-identity as black, while persons of Asian ancestral origin are more likely self-identify as Asian. Persons 18–25 years of age represent a group that is immediately affected by an affirmative action ban. When Antman and Duncan confine their analysis to this group of currently enrollees, they find that African Americans with a multiracial ancestry are 19% less likely to self-identify as black while African Americans with no relevant racial ancestry are 0.40% more likely to enroll in college. But, there are no statistically significant effects for African Americans not enrolled in college. Persons of multiracial and Asian-alone ancestry are more likely to self-identify as Asian, regardless of college enrollment status. But, persons of no relevant Asian ancestry are less likely to self-identify as Asian. Stewart (1997), the inaugural paper on the economics of identity, provides an explanation for the heterogeneity of the Antman and Duncan results. Specifically, age and ancestral origin are proxies for what Stewart calls the stock of race identity.Footnote 1 Younger persons and persons with a multicultural ancestral origin may have lower stock or a different quality of stock of race identity than older persons or persons with a black-alone ancestral origin. Hence, heterogeneity across persons within a racial group in the quantity or quality of the stock of race identity, that is, the degree of attachment to a racial group, will facilitate heterogeneity in responses to exogenous factors (such as an affirmative action) that affect individual self-identification.Footnote 2
 Contreras uses longitudinal data that is limited to persons who are 26 years of age, a sample of persons who are not immediately affected by an affirmative action ban on college admissions. He compares identity selection in affirmative action ban states for persons at age 26 relative to their identity selection at age 14. Per the considerations of Stewart (1997) and Darity et al. (2006), racial and ethnic minorities view an affirmative action ban as attack against their social group’s social, economic, and political interests. Contreras argues that public “policies perceived to undermine the interest of minorities makes one more (consciously) aware of one’s own minority identity.” Hence, rather than undermining the incentive to self-identify as an African American such policies might increase this probability. Contreras confirms that “in the time around the affirmative action bans in California, Texas, Washington, and Florida racial identity switching becomes far less likely.” African Americans living in affirmative action ban states are 3% less likely to change their racial identity in response to a ban, regardless of ancestry origin, while Asian Americans are 5% less likely to change their racial identity. Multiracial Hispanics are 20% less likely to switch racial identity in response to an affirmative action ban, though Native Americans are 19% more likely to change their racial identification.Footnote 3
 Mason and Matella (2014) also provide evidence that when political and social actions are internalized by persons as an attack against their social group, such attacks will strengthen the person’s sense of group identity and push the person away from acculturating the toward alternative group perceived as initiating the hostile actions. Mason and Matella use inter- and intra-state variation in hate crimes after the September 11, 2001 attacks to explain changes in racial self-identification among Americans of Arab and Islamic descent. (See also Gould and Klor 2015). The increase in anti-Muslim hate crimes encouraged a rise in the fraction of Arab and Islamic Americans self-identifying as non-white, viz., either “other” or black. Golash-Boza and Darity (2008) find that interview-identified skin shade is a predictor of race among Hispanics. Stewart (2009) finds currently existing institutional rules and procedures designed to reduce the intensity of pre-enlistment racial identity and to increase the intensity of post-enlistment military identity have limited efficacy. In their analysis of black racial identity in Brazil, Mitchell-Walthour and Darity (2014) find that the extent of a person’s exposure to racial discrimination (“other-group antagonism”) and a sense of black-linked fate (“own-group altruism”) are positively related to black identification. Saperstein and Penner (2012) show that alternative measures of inequality and socioeconomic status have a substantive effect on both interviewer-identified and self-identified race. (See also Kramer et al. 2016; Alba et al. 2016; Saperstein and Penner 2016).

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Competitive Swimming and Racial Disparities in Drowning

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Educational Attainment, Citizenship, and Black American Women in Elected and Appointed National Leadership Positions

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: Skin Tone and Self-Employment: is there an Intra-Group Variation among Blacks?
Intro: Colorism is the “allocation of privilege and disadvantage according to the lightness or darkness of one’s skin, with favoritism typically granted to those with lighter skin” (Diette et al. 2015, page 156). Colorism explains intra-group variations among Blacks on a variety of outcomes. Darker skin tone Blacks have lower education, income, occupational prestige (Harvey et al. 2005; Keith and Herring 1991), social status (Hersch 2006) and poorer health (Borrell et al. 2006). Darker skin tone is not associated with differences in abilities—even after controlling for parent’s socioeconomic status and a variety of individual characteristics, skin tone led to systematic differences in future income and status (Keith and Herring 1991; Mason 2004). Recent studies have continued to find support for wage differentials based on skin tone (Goldsmith et al. 2006; Kreisman and Rangel 2015). One less explored area in this literature is the influence of skin tone on self-employment. Despite persistence of inter-group differences in self-employment between Blacks and Whites (Lofstrom and Bates 2013), colorism could explain intra-group variations in self-employment among Blacks. If darker skin tone Blacks face discrimination in traditional labor markets, then to mitigate effects of discrimination in traditional workplaces and improve economic returns to their human capital they may seek self-employment to close gaps in status and income. Although self-employment could be desirable among darker skin tone Blacks, based on a review of the literature on colorism and endowments necessary for self-employment, they may be less likely to engage in self-employment for two reasons – lower accumulation of human capital relative to their lighter skin tone counterparts and possible discrimination and hindrances in self-employment efforts from inter- and intra-group stakeholders. Key endowments for entry into self-employment are education, cognitive ability, diverse occupational experiences, financial resources and social capital (Dunn and Holtz-Eakin 2000; Parker 2004). Empirical findings on colorism show that skin tone is negatively associated with accumulation of human capital from an early age and continues to influence income and occupational prestige in later life (Hunter 2007; Monk 2014). Darker skin tone individuals have lower inter- and intra-group social capital, and due to inter-group bias, they could be perceived as more ‘Black’ in lending markets (Fairlie 1999) and may face greater consumer discrimination (Borjas and Bronars 1989). Such limited accumulation of endowments necessary for self-employment could limit darker skin tone Blacks from engaging in self-employment. Persistent effects of skin tone over lifetime (Adams et al. 2016) may continue to restrain darker skin tone Blacks from engaging in self-employment as they may expect continued inter- and intra-group discrimination that could hinder self-employment activities. However, darker skin tone individuals who attain these human capital endowments may realize higher returns. Bridging colorism with the literature on studies examining intra-group variations in socioeconomic status (Bates 1997), location (Boyd 1991), and cohort (Fairlie and Meyer 2000) leading to self-employment differences among Blacks, we ask: (i) whether variations in skin tone among Blacks influence the likelihood of engaging in self-employment? and (ii) whether influence of skin tone persists, such that higher human capital or other characteristics related to self-employment do not mitigate the lower likelihood of engaging in self-employment? As such, the purpose of the paper fits into stratification economics, where structural and intentional processes generate and maintain persistent differences in life outcomes for darker skin tone Blacks (Diette et al. 2015). Focus on intra-group variations in self-employment complement studies examining the inter-group differences between Black and White self-employment (Blanchflower 2004; Fairlie 1999; Le 1999). Darker skin tone, an additional basis of disadvantage among Blacks in seeking self-employment, is a finding particularly relevant given NLSY 1997 data used in this study includes millennials, a generation where social narratives seem to suggest that discrimination may be on the decline. Findings show that the influence of skin tone in explaining self-employment is significant among Black millennials. It must be noted that that we do not disentangle the skin tone effects from mixed-race effects. As first generation mixed race Blacks may have lighter skin-tone than other Blacks, differences in resources necessary for self-employment could also be explained by mixed race. Offsprings of mixed race couples may have higher endowments, explaining correlation between skin tone and self-employment resources.

Journal Name: The Review of Black Political Economy
Title: The Production of Black Ph.D.’s in Economics at Harvard University, 1905–1955
Intro:
Harvard University, established in 1637, has a reputation for being a trendsetter in higher education (Greene 2011; About Department of Economics).Footnote 1 It was one of the first major research universities to guarantee full financial aid to all low-income students admitted (Otani 2015); it pioneered the use of a core curriculum (Bombardieri, 2004); was an early adopter of the SAT examination as a requirement for admission (History of the SAT); and notably, has been a leader in targeted admissions of students from underrepresented racial minority groups (Roberts 2015). There is a saying: “Harvard leads and higher education follows.”Footnote 2
 Harvard’s Department of Economics, founded in 1897 (Mason and Lamont 1982), produced its first Ph.D. in 1905 (Harvard University 1900). Many faculty members throughout the first half of the twentieth Century received their doctorates from Harvard, creating a distinct and identifiable school of thought that ultimately became one of the dominant schools of thought in the United States (Harvard/Radcliffe). Key areas in the Economics Department at Harvard included the analysis of monopolistic competition, the extension of international trade theory, and in later years, it became a center for Keynesian economics in the United States (Mason and Lamont 1982). The Department helped to shape the training of economics throughout the entire nation throughout much of the twentieth Century. This essay is rooted in dining room conversations with my father, Samuel L. Myers, Sr., a 1949 graduate of the Ph.D. Program in Economics at Harvard University. My father had produced a programmed textbook for teaching introductory economics at Morgan State College.Footnote 3 He talked about his professors at Morgan who inspired him; his professors at Boston University who supported his interest in economic analysis of the Negro; and he detailed his experiences in the Ph.D. program in economics at Harvard University, recounting his interactions with Joseph A. Schumpeter, Gottfried Haberler, Alvin Hanson, John Dunlop, John Kenneth Galbraith, and most of all, John D. Black.Footnote 4 It was during these conversations that my father modestly revealed that he was “only the fifth” black to obtain the Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University. This kernel of information apparently has remained unchallenged and unappreciated by economic historians and others interested in the role of race in the profession. Clearly, if my father were the fifth black to receive the Ph.D. in economics from Harvard, then there must be some record of the first, second, third and fourth recipients of this coveted degree. This essay is designed to document the evidence available concerning the production of black economists at Harvard from 1905 until 1955. At my father’s 95th birthday party, celebrated first at the Spring 2014 meeting of Gamma Boulé of Sigma Pi Phi FraternityFootnote 5 and then at the headquarters of Minority Access, Inc.,Footnote 6 I recounted more recent conversations with him designed to establish conclusively the identities of the doctoral recipients who preceded him at Harvard. With fading memory, my father speculated that the first might have been W.E.B. Dubois; the second probably was Abram Harris; the third possibly was someone by the name of Greene, who did mathematical location theory. This ordering conflicted with the widely documented evidence that the graduate economics department at Harvard had not yet been formed at the time that Dubois received his degreeFootnote 7; that Abram Harris received his degree from Columbia, not Harvard.Footnote 8 And, a quick search of graduates of Harvard produced no one by the name of Greene with a thesis on location economics. In an entirely unguarded moment, I jokingly mentioned during the ceremonies that since the person my modest father thought was the first, could not have been the first; since the person who putatively was the second clearly was not first or second; and since the person who apparently was the third could not be found, that meant that perhaps my father was the first. Given that the audience included major business executives, college presidents, top elected officials, and prominent leaders of the African American community in Baltimore, I immediately sensed the folly of making such casual claims. I was fortunate to have the assistance of a talented undergraduate student participating in the University of Minnesota’s Ronald McNair summer mentorship program interested in the famed agricultural economist, John D. Black, whose picture adorns the graduate seminar room of the University of Minnesota’s Department of Applied Economics. Black had been one of my father’s senior mentors at Harvard with many vital links to Minnesota. Lawrence Karongo, with the help of Cheniqua Johnson, another undergraduate at the University of Minnesota, spent the summer of 2014 tracking down the dissertations of all doctoral recipients from Harvard’s economics department and combing through public records, census records, newspaper and magazine accounts to identify the race and ethnicity of each of the 609 Ph.D. recipients in economics from 1905 to 1955. This essay is the story of these efforts and provides insights into the production of black Ph.D.’s at, arguably, the leading economics department in the United States by the end of World War II. I will begin by discussing the methodology used to document the six black Harvard Ph.D.’s in economics during the period under review. In producing the list, I also report the dissertation topics, the dissertation advisors, and connections that heretofore have not been fully articulated. Then, I present estimates from a simple model that asks and answers the question: what are the key factors that contributed to the production of black Harvard Ph.D.’s in economics in any given year? The concluding section offers insights about the patterns, themes and linkages and their implications for the production of minority Ph.D.’s in the twenty-first Century.
